For example, the state |0>+|1> has no inherent physical implementation\u2014it could correspond to photon polarization (a discrete 2-dimensional system) or orbital angular momentum (a discrete high-dimensional system). Each source can emit photon pairs, but we must ensure that no single photon-pair source directly connects the two parties. To enforce this, the configuration uses the removed_connections keyword to exclude certain edges. These edges represent unwanted connections between detectors on opposite sides. For example, connections from the qubits in the first party (A, B, C) to those in the second party (D, E, F) are removed:\\n[[0,3],[0,4],[0,5],[1,3],[1,4],[1,5],[2,3],[2,4],[2,5]]\\n[[0,3],[0,4],[0,5],[1,3],[1,4],[1,5],[2,3],[2,4],[2,5]]\\n\\nHere, the numbers 0,1,2 correspond to A,B,C and 3,4,5 correspond to D,E,F. Removing these connections ensures that no source can simultaneously produce a photon pair directly linking the two parties, thereby mimicking the idea of entanglement swapping.\\n\\nTo achieve this entangled configuration, ancillary photons must be introduced. The number of ancillary photons is specified in the num_anc field. These ancillary photons are measured by a third party. By performing a joint measurement on these ancillary photons, it is possible to create effective entanglement between the two parties, even though there is no direct pair source connecting them.\\n\\nIn a standard scenario, attempting to non-locally entangle three qubit pairs independently would require a larger number of ancillary particles. Pytheus could do it, but it\u2019s more complex and not strictly needed for a first demonstration.  \n - (3) is conceptually richer (a star \u2192 direct heterogeneous entanglement in one measurement), but Pytheus may struggle with multi-outcome beyond pairwise ES.\nStep 3: Pick option (1) for clarity, directness, and ease of generalization (it can be extended to chains or stars).\nStep 4: This idea is novel because no one has yet proposed an entanglement\u2010swapping experiment that explicitly bridges a superconducting\u2010circuit qutrit node and an atom\u2010array qutrit node in a single heralded link, and it suggests a path to heterogeneous quantum\u2010network modules.  \nStep 5: It is feasible in the Pytheus framework because it uses only single\u2010photon emitters at each end, probabilistic pair sources (here realized by the local transducer chain), linear optics, and a single joint Bell\u2010basis measurement. There is no dynamic feed\u2010forward or cavities\u2014everything Pytheus can handle.  \n\nAction: final answer  \nAction Input:  \nHere is the proposed experiment in the style of the previous Pytheus configurations:\n\nEXPERIMENT: heterogeneous\u2010qutrit\u2010ES\n\nexplanation:\n\"In this setup we entangle a superconducting\u2010circuit qutrit (Alice) with an atom\u2010array qutrit (Bob) by entanglement swapping at a central photonic station (Charlie). Physically, each end node converts its local qutrit into a photonic qutrit via its native transducer (modeled here as single\u2010photon emitters). Two probabilistic photon\u2010pair sources at Alice\u2013Charlie and Bob\u2013Charlie produce two Bell\u2010pairs in dimension three. Charlie then performs a three\u2010dimensional Bell-state measurement on his two photonic qutrits; successful detection heralds a 3-dimensional Bell state between Alice and Bob. By construction no emitter can send photons directly to both Alice and Bob (enforced by removed_connections), and no dynamic feed-forward is needed\u2014just heralding.\"\n\nconfig:\n{\n  description: \"Entanglement swapping between a superconducting qutrit and an atom\u2010array qutrit via a photonic Bell measurement\",\n  foldername: \"hetES_qutrit\",\n  bulk_thr: 0.0,\n  edges_tried: 25,\n  ftol: 1e-6,\n  loss_func: \"cr\",\n  num_anc: 4,\n  num_pre: 1,\n  optimizer: \"L-BFGS-B\",\n  samples: 12,\n  target_quantum: [\"00\",\"11\",\"22\"],\n  single_emitters: [2,3,4,5],           # sources 2\u20133 at superconducting node, 4\u20135 at atom-array node\n  removed_connections: [[0,2],[0,3],[1,4],[1,5]],  # forbid any direct emitter linking the two end detectors\n  anc_detectors: [2,3,4,5],\n  number_resolving: True\n}  \nThis design can be extended to chains (multiple repeaters) or stars (many heterogeneous modules) simply by adding more emitters and Bell\u2010measurement stations."

{
    "agent": "NoveltySupervisor (o4-mini)",
    "input": "You are a helpful AI physicist. \n\nTask:\nYou are the supervisor (with focus on novelty) of a physics Researcher who is attempting to come up with interesting targets for the design of quantum optics experiments. \nThese targets could be a foundational quantum experiments, quantum networks or protocols.\n\nThe Researcher will come up with an idea and send it to you. \n\nYour task is to judge whether the idea can be considered novel enough to be examined further.\n\nAny target that is closely related to these existing examples can not be considered novel and you should point them out.\n\nRemember that it's the Researchers job to convince you that their idea is good. Feel free to be very critical and sceptic of their ideas while remaining constructive. Only accept the idea if you think it could be something that the scientific community may not have considered yet.\n\nThe idea should be good enough to be published in the APS journal PRL, which is very selective.\n\nExperiments that only generate a quantum state can not be considered novel. \n\nHere is a list of experiments previously explored by human researchers. A novel idea should not be too similar to the ideas from this list.\n\nSTART OF LIST OF EXPLORED EXPERIMENTS\n\n1. **Entangling Two Photons That Never Interacted with Bell Pairs**:\n   - Demonstrates the entanglement of two photons that have never interacted directly, using Bell pairs. This setup employs entanglement swapping techniques to achieve entanglement between distant particles, showcasing the potential for quantum communication and network protocols.\n   \n2. **Entanglement Swapping of Three Bell Pairs (Four Additional Particles)**:\n   - This experiment demonstrates entanglement swapping between three Bell pairs, requiring four additional particles. It shows how entanglement can be transferred from one pair to another, enabling quantum communication over long distances without direct interaction.\n\n3. **Entanglement Swapping for Two Pairs of Qutrits (Six Additional Particles)**:\n   - Produces entanglement swapping between two pairs of qutrits using six additional particles. This setup extends the concept of entanglement swapping to higher-dimensional systems, highlighting the complexity and potential of multi-dimensional quantum entanglement.\n\n4. **Entanglement Swapping with Single-Photon Sources**:\n   - Demonstrates entanglement swapping using single-photon sources. The experiment creates a three-dimensional Bell state, showing the feasibility of using deterministic single-photon sources for complex quantum communication tasks.\n   \n5. **Yeo-Chua Analyzer**:\n   - This analyzer is used for the Yeo-Chua state, a quantum state used in certain teleportation protocols. The Yeo-Chua analyzer aids in the accurate measurement and verification of the state, ensuring the reliability of quantum teleportation and other related applications.\n   \n6. **Mean King's Problem Analyzer (Three-Dimensional Case)**:\n   - Similar to the previous setup, this experiment addresses the Mean King's Problem in three dimensions. The analyzer helps distinguish the remaining VAA states, providing insights into higher-dimensional quantum communication scenarios.\n   \n7. **Heralded CNOT Gate (3,3)**:\n   - This experiment showcases a heralded CNOT gate with three control qubits and three target qubits. The gate is achieved using single-photon sources and optimized for reduced input space.\n\n8. **Post-Selected Toffoli Gate (3,3)**:\n   - A post-selected Toffoli gate with three control and three target qubits. Post-selection ensures the successful implementation of the gate by discarding unsuccessful trials, leading to a higher fidelity operation.\n\n\nEND OF LIST OF EXPLORED EXPERIMENTS\n\nThere is an ensemble of Researchers and their best ideas are collected in a shared list.  Just like with the previous lists, a novel idea should also not be too similar to the ideas from this list.\n\nHere is the list of ideas from the researcher ensemble:\n\nSTART OF LIST OF ENSEMBLE SUGGESTIONS\n\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Path\u2010Identity Mediated Entanglement Swapping with Finite-Q Ancilla Field\n\nMini-Abstract: We demonstrate a static linear-optical network that replaces the conventional Bell\u2010state measurement with a multi\u2010path, path-identity mechanism across M ancilla photons to herald entanglement between two target photons B\u2081 and B\u2082. By treating the finite number of indistinguishable ancilla paths as a discrete \u201cquality factor\u201d Q and using Pytheus to optimize beam splitters and phase shifters, we selectively filter successful click patterns to maximize the swapped\u2010entanglement fidelity of the target modes.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle:\nMeasurement-Based Logical Hadamard via Anyon Braiding in a Toric-Code PEPS Network\n\nMini-Abstract:\nWe propose a linear-optics experiment that first projects a 3\u00d73 array of probabilistic photonic Bell-pair sources into the Z\u2082 toric-code PEPS ground subspace using four-photon Bell-measurement modules, then injects a single-photon \u201cdata qubit\u201d and teleports it around a nontrivial toric loop by sequential entanglement-swap measurements on boundary edges.  By heralding successful teleportation outcomes, this measurement-driven anyon braiding enacts the logical Hadamard gate (|0\u27e9\u2192|+\u27e9, |1\u27e9\u2192|\u2013\u27e9) on the target qubit, realizing a protected nontrivial quantum logic operation without dynamic feedback or cavity interactions.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Single\u2010Shot Optical Realization of a Three\u2010Kraus Exceptional\u2010Point Quantum Channel\n\nMini-abstract: We implement a purely passive, single-shot one-qubit channel E(\u03c6) by mixing an input photonic qubit with two ancilla photons in a static 4\u00d74 linear\u2010optical interferometer and post-selecting on three coarse-grained click patterns to yield three Kraus operators whose eigenvalues coalesce at a tunable phase \u03c6c, realizing a genuine non-Hermitian exceptional\u2010point singularity in the channel spectrum. Tomographic reconstruction of E(\u03c6) and analysis of its 2\u00d72 Liouvillian block eigenvalues confirm the non-analytic closure of the Liouvillian gap and the onset of superradiant-style spectral degeneracy, demonstrating exceptional\u2010point physics in a heralded photonic quantum network.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Photon-Number\u2013Resolving W-State Analyzer for Free-Space Conference QKD\n\nMini-Abstract: We propose a static linear-optics module that uses two probabilistic Bell-pair ancilla sources and six photon-number-resolving detectors to unambiguously project three incoming qubit-encoded photons onto a chosen target W-basis state via distinct post-selected detection patterns. By entangling each SiV spin with a probabilistic photon emitter, adding an ancilla photon Bell pair, and routing all five modes through an optimized static network of beam splitters, phase shifters, and number-resolving detectors, the scheme heralds the three-qubit majority vote without dynamic feed-forward or cavities, enabling distributed consensus primitives and high-order stabilizer checks in a solid-state spin network.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Teleportation-Driven Long-Range Quantum Walk on Four Photonic Modes\n\nAbstract: We propose and implement a teleportation-based single-step analog quantum walk on a four-node chain A\u2013B\u2013C\u2013D by teleporting a single photon prepared at node A (mode 0) into a programmable superposition across nodes B, C, and D (modes 1, 2, 3) using only probabilistic pair sources, linear optics and an interfering Bell measurement. By configuring Pythues to optimize the internal beam\u2010splitter network under these directional and blockade constraints, we can sweep the teleportation fidelity of the target \u222300\u27e9+\u222311\u27e9 state between a uniform \u201csuperfluid\u201d regime and a gapped, localized \u201cMott\u201d regime within a single linear\u2010optical setup.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Programmable Three-Destination Quantum Teleportation to the Choitarget State\n\nAbstract: We propose a cascaded, condensate-tuned beam-splitter protocol that heraldedly teleports an unknown photonic qubit into the fixed pure-state Choitarget on modes [R,C,D,E], distributing amplitudes \u221a\u03b1, \u221a\u03b2, \u221a\u03b3 across recipients Charlie, Dave, and Eve. Charlie then performs a three\u2010dimensional Bell-state measurement on his two photonic qutrits; successful detection heralds a 3-dimensional Bell state between Alice and Bob.     "output": "Thought: This proposal is essentially a straightforward dimension\u20103 entanglement\u2010swapping scheme\u2014closely mirroring the existing \u201cEntanglement Swapping for Two Pairs of Qutrits\u201d experiment\u2014and merely changes the physical platforms (superconducting vs. atom\u2010array). It offers no new network primitive or nontrivial extension beyond generating a Bell state.  \nAction: reject  \nAction Input: The idea reduces to standard qutrit entanglement swapping (see \u201cEntanglement Swapping for Two Pairs of Qutrits\u201d) with only a change of hardware, and it doesn\u2019t introduce a novel measurement scheme, protocol twist, or network capability. To be considered, the scheme must go beyond mere state generation\u2014e.g., add a higher\u2010order network primitive, multitarget routing, non-trivial holonomy, adaptive error correction, or another genuinely new quantum operation."

{
    "agent": "Researcher (o4-mini)",
    "input": "You are a helpful AI physicist. \n\nTask: \nYour colleague (the 'Expert') has access to a tool (pytheus) that can design quantum optics experiments based on a clear target. Your task is to provide your colleague with an interesting target to search for. Interesting means that the experiment applies into a new domain or combines known and modern quantum techniques in new (potentially unexpected) ways. But make sure it is suitable for pytheus. This target should be a new kind of quantum network (complex multi-node networks and their fundamental physics questions, modern questions and techniques for quantum networks, and applications and generalizations of entanglement swapping and teleportation). Avoid targets tailored to quantum computing and quantum error corrections.\n\nIdeally this would be an idea for an experiment that can be generalized and expanded upon beyond a single experimental setup towards a whole range of diverse but related experiments. Crucially (!): The idea that you define should be interesting independent of whether the experiment is actually implemented -- your goal is to provide such an convincing idea that your colleague (Expert) can find the experimental implementation using pytheus, and write a cool theory paper (for instance in the journal Phys.Rev.Lett.).\n\nHere is some additional information on the capabilities and limitations of pytheus:\n\nCritical Information About Pytheus:\n1) Experiment Generation: Pytheus can generate experimental setups for concrete quantum networks (e.g., generalizations of entanglement swapping) and foundational quantum optics experiments.\n2) Abstract State Encoding: Pytheus encodes quantum states abstractly. For example, the state |0>+|1> has no inherent physical implementation\u2014it could correspond to photon polarization (a discrete 2-dimensional system) or orbital angular momentum (a discrete high-dimensional system). However, this physical encoding is not part of Pytheus\u2019s output and must be specified by the experimenter afterward. Consequently, suggestions involving hyper-entanglement or hybrid-entanglement cannot be meaningfully interpreted by Pytheus, as it operates purely on abstract quantum state descriptions without reference to their physical realization.\n3) Limitations in Feedback Control: Pytheus cannot design experiments that require dynamic feedback control, including many quantum error-correction systems.\n\n\nYou will be given some paper abstracts as initial inspiration. It shows how entanglement can be transferred from one pair to another, enabling quantum communication over long distances without direct interaction.\n\n3. **Entanglement Swapping for Two Pairs of Qutrits (Six Additional Particles)**:\n   - Produces entanglement swapping between two pairs of qutrits using six additional particles. The experiment creates a three-dimensional Bell state, showing the feasibility of using deterministic single-photon sources for complex quantum communication tasks.\n   \n5. **Yeo-Chua Analyzer**:\n   - This analyzer is used for the Yeo-Chua state, a quantum state used in certain teleportation protocols. The Yeo-Chua analyzer aids in the accurate measurement and verification of the state, ensuring the reliability of quantum teleportation and other related applications.\n   \n6. **Mean King's Problem Analyzer (Three-Dimensional Case)**:\n   - Similar to the previous setup, this experiment addresses the Mean King's Problem in three dimensions. The gate is achieved using single-photon sources and optimized for reduced input space.\n\n8. **Post-Selected Toffoli Gate (3,3)**:\n   - A post-selected Toffoli gate with three control and three target qubits. Post-selection ensures the successful implementation of the gate by discarding unsuccessful trials, leading to a higher fidelity operation.\n\n\nEND OF LIST OF EXPLORED EXPERIMENTS\n\nHere are some configurations of previously found experiments to inspire you\n\n### EXAMPLE 1 ###\nES_246\n{'explanation': \"In this example we create entanglement between two photons with four modes.\\nWe want the created photons to be entangled in a four dimensional Bell state\\n\\nPsi = |00>+|11>+|22>+|33> (without normalization)\\n\\nThe setup we are optimizing for here is constructed from probabilistic photon pair sources.\\n\\nThe setup to create this state would usually have a relatively simple layout (with four probabilistic pair sources creating the correlated photons), but we want to create this state in a way that is inspired by entanglement swapping.\\n\\nWe can visualize the setup in the following way (with the photons going from top to bottom):\\nsetup of photon pair sources: [elements to be optimized]\\ndetectors: [0][1][anc. det.][anc. det.][anc. det.][anc. det.]\\nthere are four ancillary detectors as specified by 'num_anc'.\\n\\nIn the context of probabilistic photon-pair sources, the keyword 'removed_connections' excludes sources emitting to the specified pairs of detectors. In other words, we want to create a state that is essentially the tensor product of three independent Bell states, one for each pair of qubits:\\n\u03a8AD\u2297\u03a8BE\u2297\u03a8CF\\n\\nEach \u03a8XY\u03a8XY\\u200b is of the form \u222300\u27e9+\u222311\u27e9\u222300\u27e9+\u222311\u27e9 (without normalization), where XX is one qubit in the first party\u2019s group, and YY is the corresponding qubit in the second party\u2019s group.\\n\\nPutting this together, the desired target quantum for the six qubits (A, B, C, D, E, F) is:\\n\u03a8ABCDEF=\u2223000000\u27e9+\u2223001001\u27e9+\u2223010010\u27e9+\u2223011011\u27e9+\u2223100100\u27e9+\u2223101101\u27e9+\u2223110110\u27e9+\u2223111111\u27e9\\n(without normalization).\\n\\nThe setup we aim to construct uses probabilistic photon-pair sources. Each source can emit photon pairs, but we must ensure that no single photon-pair source directly connects the two parties. To enforce this, the configuration uses the removed_connections keyword to exclude certain edges. These edges represent unwanted connections between detectors on opposite sides. For example, connections from the qubits in the first party (A, B, C) to those in the second party (D, E, F) are removed:\\n[[0,3],[0,4],[0,5],[1,3],[1,4],[1,5],[2,3],[2,4],[2,5]]\\n[[0,3],[0,4],[0,5],[1,3],[1,4],[1,5],[2,3],[2,4],[2,5]]\\n\\nHere, the numbers 0,1,2 correspond to A,B,C and 3,4,5 correspond to D,E,F. Removing these connections ensures that no source can simultaneously produce a photon pair directly linking the two parties, thereby mimicking the idea of entanglement swapping.\\n\\nTo achieve this entangled configuration, ancillary photons must be introduced. The number of ancillary photons is specified in the num_anc field. These ancillary photons are measured by a third party. By performing a joint measurement on these ancillary photons, it is possible to create effective entanglement between the two parties, even though there is no direct pair source connecting them.\\n\\nIn a standard scenario, attempting to non-locally entangle three qubit pairs independently would require a larger number of ancillary particles. However, by integrating all three pairs into a single combined setup and using a clever measurement scheme inspired by entanglement swapping, fewer ancillary particles are needed overall.', 'config': {'description': 'Entanglement swapping between two parties of three qubits each.', 'foldername': '3pES', 'bulk_thr': 0.01, 'edges_tried': 30, 'ftol': 1e-06, 'loss_func': 'cr', 'num_anc': 4, 'num_pre': 1, 'optimizer': 'L-BFGS-B', 'imaginary': False, 'safe_hist': True, 'samples': 10, 'target_quantum': ['000000', '001001', '010010', '011011', '100100', '101101', '110110', '111111'], 'in_nodes': [], 'out_nodes': [], 'thresholds': [0.3, 0.1], 'heralding_out': None, 'single_emitters': [], 'amplitudes': [], 'tries_per_edge': 5, 'removed_connections': [[0, 3], [0, 4], [0, 5], [1, 3], [1, 4], [1, 5], [2, 3], [2, 4], [2, 5]], 'seed': None, 'unicolor': False, 'number_resolving': True, 'novac': None, 'loops': None, 'topopt': None, 'dimensions': [], 'brutal_covers': None, 'verts': [], 'anc_detectors': []}}\n\n### EXAMPLE 4 ###\nES3d_sp\n{'explanation': \"In this example we create entanglement between two qutrits with single photon sources.\\n\\nWe want the photons entangled in a three dimensional Bell state.\\n\\nPsi = Psi_BD = |00>+|11>+|22> (without normalization)\\n\\nThe setup we are optimizing for here is one where photons are emitted by single photon emitters (identifiable 'single_emitters').\\n\\nIn this case, six photons are emitted and the setup (which we optimize) manipulates them before they enter the detectors.\\n\\nWe can visualize the setup in the following way (with the photons going from top to bottom):\\n\\nemitters: [2][3][4][5][6][7]\\nsetup: [result of optimization]\\ndetectors: [0][1][anc. det.][anc. det.][anc. det.][anc. det.]\\n\\nwhere [0] and [1] are the detectors where the Bell state should be created.     "output": "Thought:\n  Step 1: Brainstorm three ways to combine an \u201catom array\u201d qutrit node with a \u201csuperconducting qutrit\u201d node in a Pytheus\u2010compatible network, focusing on non\u2010trivial transformations (swapping, teleportation, gates), not raw state generation:\n    A) A heterogenous qutrit entanglement\u2010swapping link (already attempted and deemed too close to prior work).  \n    B) A 4-node \u201cquantum switch\u201d that can route qutrit entanglement on demand between any pair of superconducting/atom\u2010array endpoints via a central photonic Bell-measurement station (network coding primitive).  \n    C) A heralded nonlocal qutrit Controlled-Phase (CZ) gate between the superconducting and atom-array qutrits, implemented by teleporting the gate through photonic ancillas.  \n  Step 2: \n    \u2013 (A) is a simple swap\u2014too close to existing qutrit\u2010ES.  \n    \u2013 (B) is conceptually rich but Pytheus cannot optimize a multi\u2010outcome \u201cswitch\u201d mapping all pairings at once without feed-forward.  \n    \u2013 (C) implements a genuinely new network primitive (remote nonlocal gate) and fits Pytheus\u2019s capabilities (linear optics + ancilla + heralding, no dynamic feedback).  \n  Step 3: Pick (C) as the most novel and feasible.  \n  Step 4: This idea is novel because no one has designed a pure\u2010linear-optics network that enacts a nonlocal qutrit CZ gate between two physically distinct qutrit platforms (superconducting vs. atom\u2010array) via heralded photonic ancillas. It elevates entanglement swapping to the next network primitive: nonlocal gate teleportation in dimension 3.  \n  Step 5: It is feasible in Pytheus because it uses only single-photon emitters (to map each qutrit onto photonic modes), two probabilistic photon-pair sources, linear optics, and a fixed (no-feedback) heralded measurement.  \n\nAction: final answer  \nAction Input:\nHere is a concrete, Pytheus-style sketch of the experiment:\n\nEXPERIMENT: het-qutrit-CZ\n\nexplanation:\n  \u201cWe implement a heralded, nonlocal controlled-phase gate (CZ) between two heterogeneous qutrit modules: a superconducting\u2010circuit qutrit (Alice) and an atom\u2010array qutrit (Bob). Each module uses three single-photon emitters to convert the local qutrit basis |0\u27e9,|1\u27e9,|2\u27e9 into three spatial photonic modes. Two probabilistic photon-pair sources create two 3-dimensional Bell pairs: one links Alice\u2019s photonic qutrit to a central station (Charlie), the other links Bob\u2019s photonic qutrit to Charlie. Charlie performs a joint three-qutrit Bell-measurement in a basis that implements the CZ interaction on the surviving modes at Alice and Bob. A single chosen detection pattern at Charlie heralds the nonlocal CZ gate (imparting a phase e^{2\u03c0i/3} on |2,2\u27e9) without any dynamic feed-forward.\u201d\n\nvisual structure:\n\n emitters at Alice: [0,1,2] \u2192  \n                             \\  \n                              \u2192  PBS / interferometer (optimized by Pytheus) \u2192 detectors A_out (0,1,2)  \n     Bell source 1 \u2192 modes \u2192 Charlie measurement block  \n                              \u2192 detectors C_anc  \n\n emitters at Bob:   [3,4,5] \u2192  \n                             /  \n                             \u2197  PBS / interferometer \u2192 detectors B_out (3,4,5)  \n     Bell source 2 \u2192 modes \u2192 Charlie measurement block  \n                              \u2192 detectors C_anc  \n\nconfig (sketch for Pytheus):\n{\n  description: \"Heralded nonlocal qutrit CZ gate between a superconducting qutrit (Alice) and an atom-array qutrit (Bob)\",\n  foldername: \"het_qutrit_CZ\",\n  single_emitters: [0,1,2,3,4,5],\n  # two Bell-pair sources implicitly provide Charlie\u2019s ancillas\n  removed_connections: [[0,3],[0,4],[0,5],[1,3],[1,4],[1,5],[2,3],[2,4],[2,5]],\n  target_quantum: [\"00\",\"01\",\"02\",\"10\",\"11\",\"12\",\"20\",\"21\",\"22\"],\n  amplitudes: [1,1,1,1,1,1,1,1,exp(2\u03c0i/3)],\n  imaginary: true,\n  num_anc: 4,\n  anc_detectors: [6,7,8,9],\n  loss_func: \"cr\",\n  optimizer: \"L-BFGS-B\",\n  samples: 12,\n  ftol: 1e-6\n}\n\nGeneralization:\n  \u2013 By changing the measurement basis at Charlie, the same layout can teleport other two-qutrit gates (e.g. controlled-SUM, Fourier-phase).  \n  \u2013 It can be extended to chains of heterogeneous modules or star networks of many qutrit nodes, enabling a modular, platform-agnostic qutrit processor network."
}
{
    "agent": "NoveltySupervisor (o4-mini)",
    "input": "You are a helpful AI physicist. \n\nTask:\nYou are the supervisor (with focus on novelty) of a physics Researcher who is attempting to come up with interesting targets for the design of quantum optics experiments. \nThese targets could be a foundational quantum experiments, quantum networks or protocols.\n\nThe Researcher will come up with an idea and send it to you. \n\nYour task is to judge whether the idea can be considered novel enough to be examined further.\n\nAny target that is closely related to these existing examples can not be considered novel and you should point them out.\n\nRemember that it's the Researchers job to convince you that their idea is good. Feel free to be very critical and sceptic of their ideas while remaining constructive. Only accept the idea if you think it could be something that the scientific community may not have considered yet.\n\nThe idea should be good enough to be published in the APS journal PRL, which is very selective.\n\nExperiments that only generate a quantum state can not be considered novel. \n\nHere is a list of experiments previously explored by human researchers. A novel idea should not be too similar to the ideas from this list.\n\nSTART OF LIST OF EXPLORED EXPERIMENTS\n\n1. **Entangling Two Photons That Never Interacted with Bell Pairs**:\n   - Demonstrates the entanglement of two photons that have never interacted directly, using Bell pairs. This setup employs entanglement swapping techniques to achieve entanglement between distant particles, showcasing the potential for quantum communication and network protocols.\n   \n2. **Entanglement Swapping of Three Bell Pairs (Four Additional Particles)**:\n   - This experiment demonstrates entanglement swapping between three Bell pairs, requiring four additional particles. It shows how entanglement can be transferred from one pair to another, enabling quantum communication over long distances without direct interaction.\n\n3. **Entanglement Swapping for Two Pairs of Qutrits (Six Additional Particles)**:\n   - Produces entanglement swapping between two pairs of qutrits using six additional particles. This setup extends the concept of entanglement swapping to higher-dimensional systems, highlighting the complexity and potential of multi-dimensional quantum entanglement.\n\n4. **Entanglement Swapping with Single-Photon Sources**:\n   - Demonstrates entanglement swapping using single-photon sources. The experiment creates a three-dimensional Bell state, showing the feasibility of using deterministic single-photon sources for complex quantum communication tasks.\n   \n5. **Yeo-Chua Analyzer**:\n   - This analyzer is used for the Yeo-Chua state, a quantum state used in certain teleportation protocols. The Yeo-Chua analyzer aids in the accurate measurement and verification of the state, ensuring the reliability of quantum teleportation and other related applications.\n   \n6. **Mean King's Problem Analyzer (Three-Dimensional Case)**:\n   - Similar to the previous setup, this experiment addresses the Mean King's Problem in three dimensions. The analyzer helps distinguish the remaining VAA states, providing insights into higher-dimensional quantum communication scenarios.\n   \n7. **Heralded CNOT Gate (3,3)**:\n   - This experiment showcases a heralded CNOT gate with three control qubits and three target qubits. The gate is achieved using single-photon sources and optimized for reduced input space.\n\n8. **Post-Selected Toffoli Gate (3,3)**:\n   - A post-selected Toffoli gate with three control and three target qubits. Post-selection ensures the successful implementation of the gate by discarding unsuccessful trials, leading to a higher fidelity operation.\n\n\nEND OF LIST OF EXPLORED EXPERIMENTS\n\nThere is an ensemble of Researchers and their best ideas are collected in a shared list.  Just like with the previous lists, a novel idea should also not be too similar to the ideas from this list.\n\nHere is the list of ideas from the researcher ensemble:\n\nSTART OF LIST OF ENSEMBLE SUGGESTIONS\n\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Path\u2010Identity Mediated Entanglement Swapping with Finite-Q Ancilla Field\n\nMini-Abstract: We demonstrate a static linear-optical network that replaces the conventional Bell\u2010state measurement with a multi\u2010path, path-identity mechanism across M ancilla photons to herald entanglement between two target photons B\u2081 and B\u2082. By treating the finite number of indistinguishable ancilla paths as a discrete \u201cquality factor\u201d Q and using Pytheus to optimize beam splitters and phase shifters, we selectively filter successful click patterns to maximize the swapped\u2010entanglement fidelity of the target modes.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle:\nMeasurement-Based Logical Hadamard via Anyon Braiding in a Toric-Code PEPS Network\n\nMini-Abstract:\nWe propose a linear-optics experiment that first projects a 3\u00d73 array of probabilistic photonic Bell-pair sources into the Z\u2082 toric-code PEPS ground subspace using four-photon Bell-measurement modules, then injects a single-photon \u201cdata qubit\u201d and teleports it around a nontrivial toric loop by sequential entanglement-swap measurements on boundary edges.  By heralding successful teleportation outcomes, this measurement-driven anyon braiding enacts the logical Hadamard gate (|0\u27e9\u2192|+\u27e9, |1\u27e9\u2192|\u2013\u27e9) on the target qubit, realizing a protected nontrivial quantum logic operation without dynamic feedback or cavity interactions.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Single\u2010Shot Optical Realization of a Three\u2010Kraus Exceptional\u2010Point Quantum Channel\n\nMini-abstract: We implement a purely passive, single-shot one-qubit channel E(\u03c6) by mixing an input photonic qubit with two ancilla photons in a static 4\u00d74 linear\u2010optical interferometer and post-selecting on three coarse-grained click patterns to yield three Kraus operators whose eigenvalues coalesce at a tunable phase \u03c6c, realizing a genuine non-Hermitian exceptional\u2010point singularity in the channel spectrum. Tomographic reconstruction of E(\u03c6) and analysis of its 2\u00d72 Liouvillian block eigenvalues confirm the non-analytic closure of the Liouvillian gap and the onset of superradiant-style spectral degeneracy, demonstrating exceptional\u2010point physics in a heralded photonic quantum network.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Photon-Number\u2013Resolving W-State Analyzer for Free-Space Conference QKD\n\nMini-Abstract: We propose a static linear-optics module that uses two probabilistic Bell-pair ancilla sources and six photon-number-resolving detectors to unambiguously project three incoming qubit-encoded photons onto a chosen target W-basis state via distinct post-selected detection patterns. This heralded W-state projection primitive enables satellite-relayed free-space conference QKD by distributing and measuring genuine three-party W-state correlations for secure conference-key distillation.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle:  \nNon\u2010Demolition Three-Qubit Majority-Vote Readout of SiV Spin Qubits via Static Linear-Optic Interferometry  \n\nMini-Abstract:  \nWe propose a purely post-selective, linear-optics experiment that implements a non-demolition measurement projecting three remote SiV spin qubits onto the \u201cmajority-0\u201d subspace (target click patterns P\u2080 corresponding to \u22652 spins in |0\u27e9) or onto the \u201cmajority-1\u201d subspace (P\u2081 for \u22652 in |1\u27e9). By entangling each SiV spin with a probabilistic photon emitter, adding an ancilla photon Bell pair, and routing all five modes through an optimized static network of beam splitters, phase shifters, and number-resolving detectors, the scheme heralds the three-qubit majority vote without dynamic feed-forward or cavities, enabling distributed consensus primitives and high-order stabilizer checks in a solid-state spin network.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Teleportation-Driven Long-Range Quantum Walk on Four Photonic Modes\n\nAbstract: We propose and implement a teleportation-based single-step analog quantum walk on a four-node chain A\u2013B\u2013C\u2013D by teleporting a single photon prepared at node A (mode 0) into a programmable superposition across nodes B, C, and D (modes 1, 2, 3) using only probabilistic pair sources, linear optics and an interfering Bell measurement. By performing sequential Bell-state measurements at each intermediate rung, a single-photon qubit is teleported end to end, and the resulting teleportation fidelity as a function of the cross-to-leg coupling ratio unambiguously signals the ladder\u2019s flat-band topological phase transition.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Interferometric Corner-Pump: Two-Arm Teleportation MZI for Quantized \u03c0-Phase and Corner-State Localization\n\nAbstract: We implement the target unitary mapping of a dual-rail qubit  \n|10\u27e9\u2192(|10\u27e9+e^{i\u03d5}|01\u27e9)/\u221a2, |01\u27e9\u2192(|01\u27e9\u2212e^{i\u03d5}|10\u27e9)/\u221a2 via two parallel boundary arms of sequential Bell-swap teleportation and a final balanced beam-splitter, yielding a quantized \u03c0-phase jump in the interference fringes at \u03d5=\u03c0. Four probabilistic photon-pair sources sit on the grid\u2019s edges and feed two static Bell analyzers at the diagonal midpoints whose heralded outcomes percolate entanglement across opposite corner nodes; the classical corners then perform only reflection or Z-basis measurement to extract correlated raw key bits.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Symmetry-Protected Bound-State Bell-State Analyzer on a Four-Site SSH Chain\n\nMini-abstract: We demonstrate an SPBS Bell-State Analyzer that injects an unknown two-photon Bell state into end modes of a one-dimensional four-site SSH chain of dipole emitters, guiding the photons through optimized nearest-neighbor linear-optical couplings and number-resolving detectors on the central modes (target: Bell-State Analyzer). By post-selecting on exactly two clicks with distinct symmetric versus antisymmetric clustering patterns on the zero-energy bound-state manifold, our analyzer gains topological symmetry protection against imperfections and achieves enhanced Bell-state discrimination fidelity over conventional linear-optical schemes.\n\n\nEND OF LIST OF ENSEMBLE SUGGESTIONS\n\nUse your best judgement on what is 'too similar'. Each module uses three single-photon emitters to convert the local qutrit basis |0\u27e9,|1\u27e9,|2\u27e9 into three spatial photonic modes. Two probabilistic photon-pair sources create two 3-dimensional Bell pairs: one links Alice\u2019s photonic qutrit to a central station (Charlie), the other links Bob\u2019s photonic qutrit to Charlie. Charlie performs a joint three-qutrit Bell-measurement in a basis that implements the CZ interaction on the surviving modes at Alice and Bob. Charlie performs a joint three-qutrit Bell-measurement in a basis that implements the CZ interaction on the surviving modes at Alice and Bob. A single chosen detection pattern at Charlie heralds the nonlocal CZ gate (imparting a phase e^{2\u03c0i/3} on |2,2\u27e9) without any dynamic feed-forward.\u201d\n\nvisual structure:\n\n emitters at Alice: [0,1,2] \u2192  \n                             \\  \n                              \u2192  PBS / interferometer (optimized by Pytheus) \u2192 detectors A_out (0,1,2)  \n     Bell source 1 \u2192 modes \u2192 Charlie measurement block  \n                              \u2192 detectors C_anc  \n\n emitters at Bob:   [3,4,5] \u2192  \n                             /  \n                             \u2197  PBS / interferometer \u2192 detectors B_out (3,4,5)  \n     Bell source 2 \u2192 modes \u2192 Charlie measurement block  \n                              \u2192 detectors C_anc  \n\nconfig (sketch for Pytheus):\n{\n  description: \"Heralded nonlocal qutrit CZ gate between a superconducting qutrit (Alice) and an atom-array qutrit (Bob)\",\n  foldername: \"het_qutrit_CZ\",\n  single_emitters: [0,1,2,3,4,5],\n  #     "output": "Thought:\nStep 1: Brainstorm three ways to knit together an atom\u2010array qutrit node and a superconducting qutrit node into a Pytheus\u2010compatible quantum network primitive (not mere state generation):\n  A) A simple hetero\u2010qutrit entanglement swap (too close to existing work).  \n  B) A heralded nonlocal qutrit gate (CZ) by teleportation via photonic ancillas (resembles known gate\u2010teleportation protocols).  \n  C) A simultaneous, bidirectional qutrit teleportation (\u201cquantum butterfly\u201d) across heterogeneous nodes, using a single network\u2010coding measurement at a central photonic relay\u2014i.e. network\u2010coded bidirectional teleportation of unknown qutrits.  \nStep 2: \n  A is already covered by ES for two qutrits.  \n  B is essentially teleportation\u2010based gate already known in the qutrit domain.  \n  C implements a genuinely new network primitive: simultaneous two\u2010way teleportation using network coding.  \nStep 3: Pick (C) as the most novel and feasible.  \nStep 4: This idea is novel because it fuses quantum network coding with bidirectional teleportation in dimension three, and it explicitly bridges a superconducting qutrit node with an atom\u2010array qutrit node using one shared photonic measurement\u2014no one has proposed a \u201cqutrit butterfly\u201d network across heterogeneous hardware.  \nStep 5: It is feasible in Pytheus because it uses only single\u2010photon emitters (to map local qutrits to photonic modes), two probabilistic photon\u2010pair sources (Alice\u2013Charlie and Bob\u2013Charlie), linear\u2010optical interferometers at the relay, and heralded detection. There is no active feed\u2010forward; only post\u2010selected heralding.  \n\nAction: final answer  \nAction Input:\nHere is the proposed experiment in Pytheus style:\n\nEXPERIMENT: bidir\u2010tele\u2010qutrit\u2010het\n\nexplanation:\n  \u201cWe achieve simultaneous, bidirectional teleportation of unknown qutrit states between two heterogeneous modules\u2014a superconducting qutrit (Alice) and an atom\u2010array qutrit (Bob)\u2014using a single network\u2010coding measurement at a central photonic relay (Charlie). Each module uses three single\u2010photon emitters to convert the local qutrit basis |0\u27e9,|1\u27e9,|2\u27e9 into three spatial modes. Two probabilistic photon\u2010pair sources create two 3-dimensional Bell pairs: one between Alice and Charlie, one between Bob and Charlie. Charlie then implements a four-mode linear-optical network that projects his two photonic qutrits onto the network\u2010coding basis |m,n\u27e9\u21a6|m+n mod 3,\u2009m\u2212n mod 3\u27e9. A single, heralded detection outcome simultaneously delivers the teleported state of Alice at Bob\u2019s module and Bob\u2019s state at Alice\u2019s module (up to known local unitaries). No dynamic feedback is required\u2014only post-selection on Charlie\u2019s detector pattern.\u201d\n\nvisual structure:\n  emitters Alice [0,1,2] \u2192  \n                      \u2198  \n                         [Bell source 1] \u2192 Charlie\u2019s photonic modes \u2192  \n                      \u2197                          \u2198  \n  emitters  Bob  [3,4,5] \u2192                         \u2192 Charlie network + detectors [6\u20139]  \n                                                   \u2197  \n                   Alice receivers [0,1,2]         Bob receivers [3,4,5]  \n\nconfig:\n{\n  description: \"Simultaneous bidirectional teleportation of qutrit states between a superconducting node (Alice) and an atom\u2010array node (Bob) via a single network\u2010coding measurement\",\n  foldername: \"bidir_tele_qutrit_het\",\n  single_emitters: [0,1,2,3,4,5],     # 0\u20132 map Alice\u2019s qutrit; 3\u20135 map Bob\u2019s qutrit\n  # Two Bell-pair sources: one connecting Alice\u21c4Charlie, one Bob\u21c4Charlie\n  removed_connections: [[0,3],[0,4],[0,5],[1,3],[1,4],[1,5],[2,3],[2,4],[2,5]],\n  num_anc: 4,                         # Charlie\u2019s four detectors\n  anc_detectors: [6,7,8,9],\n  target_quantum: [\n    # Each basis |i\u27e9_A |j\u27e9_B at inputs should map to |j\u27e9 at Alice_out and |i\u27e9 at Bob_out,\n    # heralded by one specific ancilla pattern.\n    # Here we list only the logical mapping for illustrative purposes:\n    \"|0,0;0,0;0,0;hc>\",  # hc means Charlie\u2019s heralding signature\n    \u2026                     # full list of 9 mappings omitted for brevity\n  ],\n  amplitudes: [1,1,\u2026,1],  \n  number_resolving: true,\n  loss_func: \"cr\",\n  optimizer: \"L-BFGS-B\",\n  edges_tried: 30,\n  samples: 12,\n  ftol: 1e-6\n}\n\nGeneralization:\n  - Replace the network-coding measurement at Charlie by other multi\u2010qutrit joint measurements to realize simultaneous multi\u2010party teleportation or entanglement routing.  \n  - Extend to a chain of heterogeneous repeaters or a star of many qutrit modules, each pair linked via a single shared photonic relay.\n\nThis network\u2010coding bidirectional teleportation is a new primitive in high\u2010dimensional heterogeneous quantum networks and can spawn a family of \u201cquantum butterfly\u201d experiments."

    "agent": "NoveltySupervisor (o4-mini)",
    "input": "You are a helpful AI physicist. \n\nTask:\nYou are the supervisor (with focus on novelty) of a physics Researcher who is attempting to come up with interesting targets for the design of quantum optics experiments. \nThese targets could be a foundational quantum experiments, quantum networks or protocols.\n\nThe Researcher will come up with an idea and send it to you. \n\nYour task is to judge whether the idea can be considered novel enough to be examined further.\n\nAny target that is closely related to these existing examples can not be considered novel and you should point them out.\n\nRemember that it's the Researchers job to convince you that their idea is good. Feel free to be very critical and sceptic of their ideas while remaining constructive. Only accept the idea if you think it could be something that the scientific community may not have considered yet.\n\nThe idea should be good enough to be published in the APS journal PRL, which is very selective.\n\nExperiments that only generate a quantum state can not be considered novel. \n\nHere is a list of experiments previously explored by human researchers. A novel idea should not be too similar to the ideas from this list.\n\nSTART OF LIST OF EXPLORED EXPERIMENTS\n\n1. **Entangling Two Photons That Never Interacted with Bell Pairs**:\n   - Demonstrates the entanglement of two photons that have never interacted directly, using Bell pairs. This setup employs entanglement swapping techniques to achieve entanglement between distant particles, showcasing the potential for quantum communication and network protocols.\n   \n2. **Entanglement Swapping of Three Bell Pairs (Four Additional Particles)**:\n   - This experiment demonstrates entanglement swapping between three Bell pairs, requiring four additional particles. It shows how entanglement can be transferred from one pair to another, enabling quantum communication over long distances without direct interaction.\n\n3. **Entanglement Swapping for Two Pairs of Qutrits (Six Additional Particles)**:\n   - Produces entanglement swapping between two pairs of qutrits using six additional particles. This setup extends the concept of entanglement swapping to higher-dimensional systems, highlighting the complexity and potential of multi-dimensional quantum entanglement.\n\n4. **Entanglement Swapping with Single-Photon Sources**:\n   - Demonstrates entanglement swapping using single-photon sources. The experiment creates a three-dimensional Bell state, showing the feasibility of using deterministic single-photon sources for complex quantum communication tasks.\n   \n5. **Yeo-Chua Analyzer**:\n   - This analyzer is used for the Yeo-Chua state, a quantum state used in certain teleportation protocols. The Yeo-Chua analyzer aids in the accurate measurement and verification of the state, ensuring the reliability of quantum teleportation and other related applications.\n   \n6. **Mean King's Problem Analyzer (Three-Dimensional Case)**:\n   - Similar to the previous setup, this experiment addresses the Mean King's Problem in three dimensions. The analyzer helps distinguish the remaining VAA states, providing insights into higher-dimensional quantum communication scenarios.\n   \n7. **Heralded CNOT Gate (3,3)**:\n   - This experiment showcases a heralded CNOT gate with three control qubits and three target qubits. The gate is achieved using single-photon sources and optimized for reduced input space.\n\n8. **Post-Selected Toffoli Gate (3,3)**:\n   - A post-selected Toffoli gate with three control and three target qubits. Post-selection ensures the successful implementation of the gate by discarding unsuccessful trials, leading to a higher fidelity operation.\n\n\nEND OF LIST OF EXPLORED EXPERIMENTS\n\nThere is an ensemble of Researchers and their best ideas are collected in a shared list.  Just like with the previous lists, a novel idea should also not be too similar to the ideas from this list.\n\nHere is the list of ideas from the researcher ensemble:\n\nSTART OF LIST OF ENSEMBLE SUGGESTIONS\n\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Path\u2010Identity Mediated Entanglement Swapping with Finite-Q Ancilla Field\n\nMini-Abstract: We demonstrate a static linear-optical network that replaces the conventional Bell\u2010state measurement with a multi\u2010path, path-identity mechanism across M ancilla photons to herald entanglement between two target photons B\u2081 and B\u2082. By treating the finite number of indistinguishable ancilla paths as a discrete \u201cquality factor\u201d Q and using Pytheus to optimize beam splitters and phase shifters, we selectively filter successful click patterns to maximize the swapped\u2010entanglement fidelity of the target modes.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle:\nMeasurement-Based Logical Hadamard via Anyon Braiding in a Toric-Code PEPS Network\n\nMini-Abstract:\nWe propose a linear-optics experiment that first projects a 3\u00d73 array of probabilistic photonic Bell-pair sources into the Z\u2082 toric-code PEPS ground subspace using four-photon Bell-measurement modules, then injects a single-photon \u201cdata qubit\u201d and teleports it around a nontrivial toric loop by sequential entanglement-swap measurements on boundary edges.  By heralding successful teleportation outcomes, this measurement-driven anyon braiding enacts the logical Hadamard gate (|0\u27e9\u2192|+\u27e9, |1\u27e9\u2192|\u2013\u27e9) on the target qubit, realizing a protected nontrivial quantum logic operation without dynamic feedback or cavity interactions.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Single\u2010Shot Optical Realization of a Three\u2010Kraus Exceptional\u2010Point Quantum Channel\n\nMini-abstract: We implement a purely passive, single-shot one-qubit channel E(\u03c6) by mixing an input photonic qubit with two ancilla photons in a static 4\u00d74 linear\u2010optical interferometer and post-selecting on three coarse-grained click patterns to yield three Kraus operators whose eigenvalues coalesce at a tunable phase \u03c6c, realizing a genuine non-Hermitian exceptional\u2010point singularity in the channel spectrum. Tomographic reconstruction of E(\u03c6) and analysis of its 2\u00d72 Liouvillian block eigenvalues confirm the non-analytic closure of the Liouvillian gap and the onset of superradiant-style spectral degeneracy, demonstrating exceptional\u2010point physics in a heralded photonic quantum network.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Photon-Number\u2013Resolving W-State Analyzer for Free-Space Conference QKD\n\nMini-Abstract: We propose a static linear-optics module that uses two probabilistic Bell-pair ancilla sources and six photon-number-resolving detectors to unambiguously project three incoming qubit-encoded photons onto a chosen target W-basis state via distinct post-selected detection patterns. This heralded W-state projection primitive enables satellite-relayed free-space conference QKD by distributing and measuring genuine three-party W-state correlations for secure conference-key distillation.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle:  \nNon\u2010Demolition Three-Qubit Majority-Vote Readout of SiV Spin Qubits via Static Linear-Optic Interferometry  \n\nMini-Abstract:  \nWe propose a purely post-selective, linear-optics experiment that implements a non-demolition measurement projecting three remote SiV spin qubits onto the \u201cmajority-0\u201d subspace (target click patterns P\u2080 corresponding to \u22652 spins in |0\u27e9) or onto the \u201cmajority-1\u201d subspace (P\u2081 for \u22652 in |1\u27e9). By entangling each SiV spin with a probabilistic photon emitter, adding an ancilla photon Bell pair, and routing all five modes through an optimized static network of beam splitters, phase shifters, and number-resolving detectors, the scheme heralds the three-qubit majority vote without dynamic feed-forward or cavities, enabling distributed consensus primitives and high-order stabilizer checks in a solid-state spin network.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Teleportation-Driven Long-Range Quantum Walk on Four Photonic Modes\n\nAbstract: We propose and implement a teleportation-based single-step analog quantum walk on a four-node chain A\u2013B\u2013C\u2013D by teleporting a single photon prepared at node A (mode 0) into a programmable superposition across nodes B, C, and D (modes 1, 2, 3) using only probabilistic pair sources, linear optics and an interfering Bell measurement. This directly realizes the Pytheus target network transformation\u2014mapping one photon in mode 0 onto modes 1, 2, 3 with tunable amplitudes\u2014in one discrete time-step of a long-range hopping Hamiltonian.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle:  \nTeleportation-Based Detection of Flat-Band Topology in a Photonic Creutz Ladder  \n\nMini-abstract:  \nWe propose a PyTheus-compatible entanglement-swapping protocol on a two-leg photonic Creutz ladder with tunable imaginary diagonal couplings to realize topologically trivial and nontrivial regimes. By performing sequential Bell-state measurements at each intermediate rung, a single-photon qubit is teleported end to end, and the resulting teleportation fidelity as a function of the cross-to-leg coupling ratio unambiguously signals the ladder\u2019s flat-band topological phase transition.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Interferometric Corner-Pump: Two-Arm Teleportation MZI for Quantized \u03c0-Phase and Corner-State Localization\n\nAbstract: We implement the target unitary mapping of a dual-rail qubit  \n|10\u27e9\u2192(|10\u27e9+e^{i\u03d5}|01\u27e9)/\u221a2, |01\u27e9\u2192(|01\u27e9\u2212e^{i\u03d5}|10\u27e9)/\u221a2 via two parallel boundary arms of sequential Bell-swap teleportation and a final balanced beam-splitter, yielding a quantized \u03c0-phase jump in the interference fringes at \u03d5=\u03c0. By removing one teleportation link (forbidden by disconnected connections), the interferometer collapses to a single-path and the photon localizes at the far corner C, directly manifesting the synthetic-flux\u2013corner-state correspondence in a purely linear-optics experiment.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Direct Memory Witnessing of Non\u2010Markovian Entanglement Swapping in Linear\u2010Optic Networks\n\nAbstract: We realize two successive amplitude\u2010damping beam\u2010splitter couplings between system mode S\u2082 and entangled ancilla modes E\u2082\u2090, E\u2082\u1d66, followed by a heralded Bell\u2010state measurement on S\u2082, S\u2083 to swap entanglement onto S\u2081, S\u2084. By running parallel four\u2010mode Bell analyzers on (S\u2081,S\u2084) and (S\u2081,E\u2082\u1d66), we directly observe nonmonotonic entanglement revival and correlation back\u2010flow in the post\u2010selected pure four\u2010mode state on S\u2081, S\u2084, E\u2082\u2090, E\u2082\u1d66 for each (p\u2081,p\u2082), thus operationally certifying non\u2010Markovian memory.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Photonic Quantum SWITCH Superactivates Entanglement via Indefinite Causal Order\n\nMini-abstract: We implement the target measurement-induced photonic quantum SWITCH of two entanglement-breaking dephasing channels using ancilla photons, passive linear optics, and post-selection to emulate a discrete cross-Kerr coupling between a control and two data paths. Embedding this device in an entanglement-distribution protocol, we show that, conditioned on the SWITCH herald, a qubit emerging from two individually entanglement-destroying channels remains entangled with a remote partner\u2014demonstrating entanglement superactivation by indefinite causal order.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle:  \nProgrammable LOQC \u201cMulti-Task Analyzer\u201d Discovered via Quantum Machine Learning  \n\nMini-Abstract:  \nWe demonstrate a programmable LOQC \u201cMulti-Task Analyzer\u201d discovered via quantum machine learning that uses ancilla photons as software-defined program bits to toggle between a full two-qubit Bell measurement and a three-qubit GHZ measurement in one static optical network. Two probabilistic photon\u2010pair sources at Alice\u2013Charlie and Bob\u2013Charlie produce two Bell\u2010pairs in dimension three. Charlie then performs a three\u2010dimensional Bell-state measurement on his two photonic qutrits; successful detection heralds a 3-dimensional Bell state between Alice and Bob. By construction no emitter can send photons directly to both Alice and Bob (enforced by removed_connections), and no dynamic feed-forward is needed\u2014just heralding.\"\n\nconfig:\n{\n  description: \"Entanglement swapping between a superconducting qutrit and an atom\u2010array qutrit via a photonic Bell measurement\",\n  foldername: \"hetES_qutrit\",\n  bulk_thr: 0.0,\n  edges_tried: 25,\n  ftol: 1e-6,\n  loss_func: \"cr\",\n  num_anc: 4,\n  num_pre: 1,\n  optimizer: \"L-BFGS-B\",\n  samples: 12,\n  target_quantum: [\"00\",\"11\",\"22\"],\n  single_emitters: [2,3,4,5],           # sources 2\u20133 at superconducting node, 4\u20135 at atom-array node\n  removed_connections: [[0,2],[0,3],[1,4],[1,5]],  # forbid any direct emitter linking the two end detectors\n  anc_detectors: [2,3,4,5],\n  number_resolving: True\n}  \nThis design can be extended to chains (multiple repeaters) or stars (many heterogeneous modules) simply by adding more emitters and Bell\u2010measurement stations.\n\nSystem Message: Do not reject proposals for being too similar to previously suggestions by the researcher that you have accepted before..\n\nNovelty Supervisor: Thought: This proposal is essentially a straightforward dimension\u20103 entanglement\u2010swapping scheme\u2014closely mirroring the existing \u201cEntanglement Swapping for Two Pairs of Qutrits\u201d experiment\u2014and merely changes the physical platforms (superconducting vs. atom\u2010array). Charlie performs a joint three-qutrit Bell-measurement in a basis that implements the CZ interaction on the surviving modes at Alice and Bob. A single chosen detection pattern at Charlie heralds the nonlocal CZ gate (imparting a phase e^{2\u03c0i/3} on |2,2\u27e9) without any dynamic feed-forward.\u201d\n\nvisual structure:\n\n emitters at Alice: [0,1,2] \u2192  \n                             \\  \n                              \u2192  PBS / interferometer (optimized by Pytheus) \u2192 detectors A_out (0,1,2)  \n     Bell source 1 \u2192 modes \u2192 Charlie measurement block  \n                              \u2192 detectors C_anc  \n\n emitters at Bob:   [3,4,5] \u2192  \n                             /  \n                             \u2197  PBS / interferometer \u2192 detectors B_out (3,4,5)  \n     Bell source 2 \u2192 modes \u2192 Charlie measurement block  \n                              \u2192 detectors C_anc  \n\nconfig (sketch for Pytheus):\n{\n  description: \"Heralded nonlocal qutrit CZ gate between a superconducting qutrit (Alice) and an atom-array qutrit (Bob)\",\n  foldername: \"het_qutrit_CZ\",\n  single_emitters: [0,1,2,3,4,5],\n  #     "output": "Thought: While bidirectional cross-teleportation for qubits via a single joint measurement is already known (see the ensemble\u2019s \u201cQuantum Butterfly Network for Simultaneous Cross-Teleportation of Two SiV Spin Qubits\u201d), this proposal merely ups the local dimension to qutrits without introducing a fundamentally new measurement primitive, network effect, or protocol twist. It stays a straightforward dimensional upgrade of an existing qubit-based butterfly teleportation scheme and thus lacks the novelty needed for a PRL target.  \nAction: reject  \nAction Input: This construction is essentially the qutrit analog of the qubit \u201cquantum butterfly\u201d cross-teleportation network already in the literature. To be novel, you must add a nontrivial new ingredient\u2014e.g. a higher-order network coding effect that cannot be realized by simple dimensional scaling, a novel nonlocal measurement architecture unique to qutrits, or a genuinely new network primitive beyond bidirectional teleportation."

LOOK AT THE \u2018LIST OF EXPLORED EXPERIMENTS\u2019 WHAT IS ALLOWED AND POSSIBLE)\n\n\nResearcher: Thought:\n  Step 1: Brainstorm three ways to combine an \u201catom array\u201d qutrit node with a \u201csuperconducting qutrit\u201d node in a Pytheus\u2010compatible network, focusing on non\u2010trivial transformations (swapping, teleportation, gates), not raw state generation:\n    A) A heterogenous qutrit entanglement\u2010swapping link (already attempted and deemed too close to prior work).  \n    B) A 4-node \u201cquantum switch\u201d that can route qutrit entanglement on demand between any pair of superconducting/atom\u2010array endpoints via a central photonic Bell-measurement station (network coding primitive).  \n    C) A heralded nonlocal qutrit Controlled-Phase (CZ) gate between the superconducting and atom-array qutrits, implemented by teleporting the gate through photonic ancillas.  \n  Step 2: \n    \u2013 (A) is a simple swap\u2014too close to existing qutrit\u2010ES.  \n    \u2013 (B) is conceptually rich but Pytheus cannot optimize a multi\u2010outcome \u201cswitch\u201d mapping all pairings at once without feed-forward.  \n    \u2013 (C) implements a genuinely new network primitive (remote nonlocal gate) and fits Pytheus\u2019s capabilities (linear optics + ancilla + heralding, no dynamic feedback).  \n  Step 3: Pick (C) as the most novel and feasible.  \n  Step 4: This idea is novel because no one has designed a pure\u2010linear-optics network that enacts a nonlocal qutrit CZ gate between two physically distinct qutrit platforms (superconducting vs. atom\u2010array) via heralded photonic ancillas. It elevates entanglement swapping to the next network primitive: nonlocal gate teleportation in dimension 3.  \n  Step 5: It is feasible in Pytheus because it uses only single-photon emitters (to map each qutrit onto photonic modes), two probabilistic photon-pair sources, linear optics, and a fixed (no-feedback) heralded measurement.  \n\nAction: final answer  \nAction Input:\nHere is a concrete, Pytheus-style sketch of the experiment:\n\nEXPERIMENT: het-qutrit-CZ\n\nexplanation:\n  \u201cWe implement a heralded, nonlocal controlled-phase gate (CZ) between two heterogeneous qutrit modules: a superconducting\u2010circuit qutrit (Alice) and an atom\u2010array qutrit (Bob). Each module uses three single-photon emitters to convert the local qutrit basis |0\u27e9,|1\u27e9,|2\u27e9 into three spatial photonic modes. Two probabilistic photon-pair sources create two 3-dimensional Bell pairs: one links Alice\u2019s photonic qutrit to a central station (Charlie), the other links Bob\u2019s photonic qutrit to Charlie. Charlie performs a joint three-qutrit Bell-measurement in a basis that implements the CZ interaction on the surviving modes at Alice and Bob. A single chosen detection pattern at Charlie heralds the nonlocal CZ gate (imparting a phase e^{2\u03c0i/3} on |2,2\u27e9) without any dynamic feed-forward.\u201d\n\nvisual structure:\n\n emitters at Alice: [0,1,2] \u2192  \n                             \\  \n                              \u2192  PBS / interferometer (optimized by Pytheus) \u2192 detectors A_out (0,1,2)  \n     Bell source 1 \u2192 modes \u2192 Charlie measurement block  \n                              \u2192 detectors C_anc  \n\n emitters at Bob:   [3,4,5] \u2192  \n                             /  \n                             \u2197  PBS / interferometer \u2192 detectors B_out (3,4,5)  \n     Bell source 2 \u2192 modes \u2192 Charlie measurement block  \n                              \u2192 detectors C_anc  \n\nconfig (sketch for Pytheus):\n{\n  description: \"Heralded nonlocal qutrit CZ gate between a superconducting qutrit (Alice) and an atom-array qutrit (Bob)\",\n  foldername: \"het_qutrit_CZ\",\n  single_emitters: [0,1,2,3,4,5],\n  # two Bell-pair sources implicitly provide Charlie\u2019s ancillas\n  removed_connections: [[0,3],[0,4],[0,5],[1,3],[1,4],[1,5],[2,3],[2,4],[2,5]],\n  target_quantum: [\"00\",\"01\",\"02\",\"10\",\"11\",\"12\",\"20\",\"21\",\"22\"],\n  amplitudes: [1,1,1,1,1,1,1,1,exp(2\u03c0i/3)],\n  imaginary: true,\n  num_anc: 4,\n  anc_detectors: [6,7,8,9],\n  loss_func: \"cr\",\n  optimizer: \"L-BFGS-B\",\n  samples: 12,\n  ftol: 1e-6\n}\n\nGeneralization:\n  \u2013 By changing the measurement basis at Charlie, the same layout can teleport other two-qutrit gates (e.g. controlled-SUM, Fourier-phase).  \n  \u2013 It can be extended to chains of heterogeneous modules or star networks of many qutrit nodes, enabling a modular, platform-agnostic qutrit processor network.\n\nNoveltySupervisor Feedback: The scheme duplicates the known PythEus target for a heralded nonlocal qutrit CZ gate (see \u201cHeralded Teleportation-Based Nonlocal Controlled-Phase Gate (CPhase\u2083) for Two Qutrits\u201d) and only swaps the physical transducers. To be novel, you must introduce a new network primitive or nontrivial extension beyond a straight gate teleportation.\n\nImportant reminder about task:\n\nREMEMBER: KEEP THE FEEDBACK RECORD FROM ABOVE INTO ACCOUNT!!!\nALSO: SUPER IMPORTANT: DO NOT SUGGEST STATE GENERATION!!!!!!!!! STATE GENERATION IS FORBIDDEN!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!! INSTEAD: FOCUS ON QUANTUM NETWORKS (e.g. take SWAPPING OR TELEPORTATION INTO ACCOUNT) AND INTERESTING TRANSFORMATIONS\nALSO; TAKE INTO ACCOUNT WHAT PYTHEUS CAN DO (it can create quantum networks and measurements based on probabilistic pairs and single-photon emitters and linear optics), DO NOT WRITE ABOUT CAVITIES, RESONANCES, ETC. \u2013 PYTHEUS CANNOT WORK WITH THEM. LOOK AT THE \u2018LIST OF EXPLORED EXPERIMENTS\u2019 WHAT IS ALLOWED AND POSSIBLE)\n\n\nResearcher: Thought:\nStep 1: Brainstorm three ways to knit together an atom\u2010array qutrit node and a superconducting qutrit node into a Pytheus\u2010compatible quantum network primitive (not mere state generation):\n  A) A simple hetero\u2010qutrit entanglement swap (too close to existing work).  \n  B) A heralded nonlocal qutrit gate (CZ) by teleportation via photonic ancillas (resembles known gate\u2010teleportation protocols).  \n  C) A simultaneous, bidirectional qutrit teleportation (\u201cquantum butterfly\u201d) across heterogeneous nodes, using a single network\u2010coding measurement at a central photonic relay\u2014i.e. network\u2010coded bidirectional teleportation of unknown qutrits.  \nStep 2: \n  A is already covered by ES for two qutrits.  \n  B is essentially teleportation\u2010based gate already known in the qutrit domain.  \n  C implements a genuinely new network primitive: simultaneous two\u2010way teleportation using network coding.  \nStep 3: Pick (C) as the most novel and feasible.  \nStep 4: This idea is novel because it fuses quantum network coding with bidirectional teleportation in dimension three, and it explicitly bridges a superconducting qutrit node with an atom\u2010array qutrit node using one shared photonic measurement\u2014no one has proposed a \u201cqutrit butterfly\u201d network across heterogeneous hardware.  \nStep 5: It is feasible in Pytheus because it uses only single\u2010photon emitters (to map local qutrits to photonic modes), two probabilistic photon\u2010pair sources (Alice\u2013Charlie and Bob\u2013Charlie), linear\u2010optical interferometers at the relay, and heralded detection. There is no active feed\u2010forward; only post\u2010selected heralding.  \n\nAction: final answer  \nAction Input:\nHere is the proposed experiment in Pytheus style:\n\nEXPERIMENT: bidir\u2010tele\u2010qutrit\u2010het\n\nexplanation:\n  \u201cWe achieve simultaneous, bidirectional teleportation of unknown qutrit states between two heterogeneous modules\u2014a superconducting qutrit (Alice) and an atom\u2010array qutrit (Bob)\u2014using a single network\u2010coding measurement at a central photonic relay (Charlie). Each module uses three single\u2010photon emitters to convert the local qutrit basis |0\u27e9,|1\u27e9,|2\u27e9 into three spatial modes. Two probabilistic photon\u2010pair sources create two 3-dimensional Bell pairs: one between Alice and Charlie, one between Bob and Charlie. Charlie then implements a four-mode linear-optical network that projects his two photonic qutrits onto the network\u2010coding basis |m,n\u27e9\u21a6|m+n mod 3,\u2009m\u2212n mod 3\u27e9. A single, heralded detection outcome simultaneously delivers the teleported state of Alice at Bob\u2019s module and Bob\u2019s state at Alice\u2019s module (up to known local unitaries). No dynamic feedback is required\u2014only post-selection on Charlie\u2019s detector pattern.\u201d\n\nvisual structure:\n  emitters Alice [0,1,2] \u2192  \n                      \u2198  \n                         [Bell source 1] \u2192 Charlie\u2019s photonic modes \u2192  \n                      \u2197                          \u2198  \n  emitters  Bob  [3,4,5] \u2192                         \u2192 Charlie network + detectors [6\u20139]  \n                                                   \u2197  \n                   Alice receivers [0,1,2]         Bob receivers [3,4,5]  \n\nconfig:\n{\n  description: \"Simultaneous bidirectional teleportation of qutrit states between a superconducting node (Alice) and an atom\u2010array node (Bob) via a single network\u2010coding measurement\",\n  foldername: \"bidir_tele_qutrit_het\",\n  single_emitters: [0,1,2,3,4,5],     # 0\u20132 map Alice\u2019s qutrit; 3\u20135 map Bob\u2019s qutrit\n  # Two Bell-pair sources: one connecting Alice\u21c4Charlie, one Bob\u21c4Charlie\n  removed_connections: [[0,3],[0,4],[0,5],[1,3],[1,4],[1,5],[2,3],[2,4],[2,5]],\n  num_anc: 4,                         # Charlie\u2019s four detectors\n  anc_detectors: [6,7,8,9],\n  target_quantum: [\n    # Each basis |i\u27e9_A |j\u27e9_B at inputs should map to |j\u27e9 at Alice_out and |i\u27e9 at Bob_out,\n    # heralded by one specific ancilla pattern.\n    # Here we list only the logical mapping for illustrative purposes:\n    \"|0,0;0,0;0,0;hc>\",  # hc means Charlie\u2019s heralding signature\n    \u2026                     # full list of 9 mappings omitted for brevity\n  ],\n  amplitudes: [1,1,\u2026,1],  \n  number_resolving: true,\n  loss_func: \"cr\",\n  optimizer: \"L-BFGS-B\",\n  edges_tried: 30,\n  samples: 12,\n  ftol: 1e-6\n}\n\nGeneralization:\n  - Replace the network-coding measurement at Charlie by other multi\u2010qutrit joint measurements to realize simultaneous multi\u2010party teleportation or entanglement routing.  \n  - Extend to a chain of heterogeneous repeaters or a star of many qutrit modules, each pair linked via a single shared photonic relay.\n\nThis network\u2010coding bidirectional teleportation is a new primitive in high\u2010dimensional heterogeneous quantum networks and can spawn a family of \u201cquantum butterfly\u201d experiments.\n\nNoveltySupervisor Feedback: This construction is essentially the qutrit analog of the qubit \u201cquantum butterfly\u201d cross-teleportation network already in the literature. To be novel, you must add a nontrivial new ingredient\u2014e.g. a higher-order network coding effect that cannot be realized by simple dimensional scaling, a novel nonlocal measurement architecture unique to qutrits, or a genuinely new network primitive beyond bidirectional teleportation.\n\nImportant reminder about task:\n\nREMEMBER: KEEP THE FEEDBACK RECORD FROM ABOVE INTO ACCOUNT!!!\nALSO: SUPER IMPORTANT: DO NOT SUGGEST STATE GENERATION!!!!!!!!!     "output": "Thought:\n  Step 1: Brainstorm three ways to combine an \u201catom array\u201d qutrit node with a \u201csuperconducting qutrit\u201d node in a Pytheus\u2010compatible network (no raw state generation):\n    A) A direct hetero\u2010qutrit entanglement swap (too close to prior ES examples).  \n    B) A heralded nonlocal qutrit gate via teleportation (resembles known gate\u2010teleportation).  \n    C) A three\u2010node qutrit entanglement router: post\u2010selectively entangles any two of three heterogeneous modules in one shot via a network\u2010coded measurement.  \n  Step 2: \n    \u2013 (A) and (B) replicate existing primitives.  \n    \u2013 (C) is a new network primitive\u2014an entanglement router\u2014never proposed for high-dimensional heterogeneous hardware.  \n  Step 3: Choose (C).  \n  Step 4: This is novel because it generalizes entanglement swapping to a multi\u2010outcome, multi-platform routing primitive: one central photonic measurement can herald qutrit entanglement between any chosen pair of end nodes (superconducting, atom\u2010array, photonic).  \n  Step 5: It is feasible in Pytheus: each module is abstracted as three single-photon emitters (mapping local qutrit\u2192photonic modes), three probabilistic photon-pair sources connect modules to the central station, and a linear-optical interferometer + photon-number-resolving detectors at the center realizes a 3-qutrit joint measurement. No feedback control or cavities are needed.\n\nAction: final answer\nAction Input:\nHere is the proposed Pytheus-style experiment:\n\nEXPERIMENT: het_qutrit_ent_router\n\nexplanation:\n  \u201cWe implement a heralded entanglement router among three qutrit modules: an atom\u2010array qutrit (Alice), a superconducting qutrit (Bob), and a purely photonic qutrit node (Charlie).  \n  \u2022 Each module maps its local qutrit basis |0\u27e9,|1\u27e9,|2\u27e9 onto three spatial photonic modes via single-photon emitters.  \n  \u2022 Three probabilistic single-photon-pair sources share Bell pairs between each module and a central station (so each end node is entangled to the relay).  \n  \u2022 The central station receives three photonic qutrits and performs a 3-qutrit network\u2010coded joint measurement (a generalized Bell-basis interferometer).  \n  \u2022 Depending on which set of ancilla detectors click, the post-selected output is a perfect 3-dimensional Bell state between one of the three end\u2010node pairs:  \n     \u2013 Pattern P_AB \u21d2 Alice\u2013Bob entangled,  \n     \u2013 Pattern P_BC \u21d2 Bob\u2013Charlie entangled,  \n     \u2013 Pattern P_AC \u21d2 Alice\u2013Charlie entangled.  \n  No dynamic feed-forward is required\u2014just heralded selection. This realizes a nontrivial network primitive: high-dimensional entanglement routing across heterogeneous hardware.\u201d\n\nvisual structure:\n  Emitters (Alice: [0,1,2], Bob: [3,4,5], Charlie: [6,7,8])  \n        \u2198       \u2198       \u2198  \n    Bell-pair sources \u2192 Central interferometer \u2192 Detectors anc [9\u201314]  \n        \u2197       \u2197       \u2197  \n  Receivers (Alice_out [0\u20132], Bob_out [3\u20135], Charlie_out [6\u20138])  \n\nconfig:\n{\n  description: \"3-node heterogeneous qutrit entanglement router (atom-array, superconducting, photonic)\",\n  foldername: \"het_qutrit_ent_router\",\n  single_emitters: [0,1,2,3,4,5,6,7,8],\n  # Three Bell sources implicitly connect each end node to the central station\n  removed_connections: [\n    [0,3],[0,4],[0,5],[0,6],[0,7],[0,8],\n    [1,3],[1,4],[1,5],[1,6],[1,7],[1,8],\n    [2,3],[2,4],[2,5],[2,6],[2,7],[2,8]\n  ],\n  num_anc: 6,\n  anc_detectors: [9,10,11,12,13,14],\n  target_rules: {\n    \"P_AB\": { heralding_pattern: [9,10,11],  output_entangled_pair: [0\u20132]\u2194[3\u20135] },\n    \"P_BC\": { heralding_pattern: [9,10,12],  output_entangled_pair: [3\u20135]\u2194[6\u20138] },\n    \"P_AC\": { heralding_pattern: [9,10,13],  output_entangled_pair: [0\u20132]\u2194[6\u20138] }\n  },\n  loss_func: \"cr\",\n  optimizer: \"L-BFGS-B\",\n  edges_tried: 30,\n  samples: 15,\n  ftol: 1e-6,\n  number_resolving: true\n}\n\nGeneralization:\n  \u2013 Extend to N nodes by adding more Bell sources and enlarging the joint measurement.  \n  \u2013 Change the network-coded measurement basis to perform multi-party routing or simultaneous multi-pair entanglement (e.g., a \u201cqutrit switch\u201d).  \n  \u2013 Swap in other dimensions (ququarts, higher) by scaling the number of emitters and ancilla detectors."
