So to independently create two three-dimensional Bell pairs non-locally, one would require eight ancillary particles.\\n\\nBy creating both pairs in a single setup we require two less ancillary particles to achieve the same task.\", 'config': {'description': 'Entanglement swapping between two parties of two qutrits each.', 'foldername': '2pES_3d', 'bulk_thr': 0.01, 'edges_tried': 30, 'ftol': 0.0001, 'loss_func': 'cr', 'num_anc': 6, 'num_pre': 1, 'optimizer': 'L-BFGS-B', 'imaginary': False, 'safe_hist': True, 'samples': 10, 'target_quantum': ['0000', '0101', '0202', '1010', '1111', '1212', '2020', '2121', '2222'], 'in_nodes': [], 'out_nodes': [], 'thresholds': [0.3, 0.1], 'heralding_out': None, 'single_emitters': [], 'amplitudes': [], 'tries_per_edge': 5, 'removed_connections': [[0, 2], [0, 3], [1, 2], [1, 3]], 'seed': None, 'unicolor': False, 'number_resolving': True, 'novac': None, 'loops': None, 'topopt': None, 'dimensions': [], 'brutal_covers': None, 'verts': [], 'anc_detectors': []}}\n\n### EXAMPLE 3 ###\n3pES\n{'explanation': 'In this example we create entanglement between two parties of three qubits each.\\nThis means that we want to create six qubits: A, B, C on one side and D, E, F on the other side.\\n\\nThe goal is to have each corresponding pair (A&D, B&E, C&F) form a two-dimensional Bell state. In other words, we want to create a state that is essentially the tensor product of three independent Bell states, one for each pair of qubits:\\n\u03a8AD\u2297\u03a8BE\u2297\u03a8CF\\n\\nEach \u03a8XY\u03a8XY\\u200b is of the form \u222300\u27e9+\u222311\u27e9\u222300\u27e9+\u222311\u27e9 (without normalization), where XX is one qubit in the first party\u2019s group, and YY is the corresponding qubit in the second party\u2019s group.\\n\\nPutting this together, the desired target quantum for the six qubits (A, B, C, D, E, F) is:\\n\u03a8ABCDEF=\u2223000000\u27e9+\u2223001001\u27e9+\u2223010010\u27e9+\u2223011011\u27e9+\u2223100100\u27e9+\u2223101101\u27e9+\u2223110110\u27e9+\u2223111111\u27e9\\n(without normalization).\\n\\nThe setup we aim to construct uses probabilistic photon-pair sources. Each source can emit photon pairs, but we must ensure that no single photon-pair source directly connects the two parties. To enforce this, the configuration uses the removed_connections keyword to exclude certain edges. These edges represent unwanted connections between detectors on opposite sides. For example, connections from the qubits in the first party (A, B, C) to those in the second party (D, E, F) are removed:\\n[[0,3],[0,4],[0,5],[1,3],[1,4],[1,5],[2,3],[2,4],[2,5]]\\n[[0,3],[0,4],[0,5],[1,3],[1,4],[1,5],[2,3],[2,4],[2,5]]\\n\\nHere, the numbers 0,1,2 correspond to A,B,C and 3,4,5 correspond to D,E,F. Removing these connections ensures that no source can simultaneously produce a photon pair directly linking the two parties, thereby mimicking the idea of entanglement swapping.\\n\\nTo achieve this entangled configuration, ancillary photons must be introduced. The number of ancillary photons is specified in the num_anc field. These ancillary photons are measured by a third party. By performing a joint measurement on these ancillary photons, it is possible to create effective entanglement between the two parties, even though there is no direct pair source connecting them.\\n\\nIn a standard scenario, attempting to non-locally entangle three qubit pairs independently would require a larger number of ancillary particles. However, by integrating all three pairs into a single combined setup and using a clever measurement scheme inspired by entanglement swapping, fewer ancillary particles are needed overall.', 'config': {'description': 'Entanglement swapping between two parties of three qubits each.', 'foldername': '3pES', 'bulk_thr': 0.01, 'edges_tried': 30, 'ftol': 1e-06, 'loss_func': 'cr', 'num_anc': 4, 'num_pre': 1, 'optimizer': 'L-BFGS-B', 'imaginary': False, 'safe_hist': True, 'samples': 10, 'target_quantum': ['000000', '001001', '010010', '011011', '100100', '101101', '110110', '111111'], 'in_nodes': [], 'out_nodes': [], 'thresholds': [0.3, 0.1], 'heralding_out': None, 'single_emitters': [], 'amplitudes': [], 'tries_per_edge': 5, 'removed_connections': [[0, 3], [0, 4], [0, 5], [1, 3], [1, 4], [1, 5], [2, 3], [2, 4], [2, 5]], 'seed': None, 'unicolor': False, 'number_resolving': True, 'novac': None, 'loops': None, 'topopt': None, 'dimensions': [], 'brutal_covers': None, 'verts': [], 'anc_detectors': []}}\n\n### EXAMPLE 4 ###\nES3d_sp\n{'explanation': \"In this example we create entanglement between two qutrits with single photon sources.\\n\\nWe want the photons entangled in a three dimensional Bell state.\\n\\nPsi = Psi_BD = |00>+|11>+|22> (without normalization)\\n\\nThe setup we are optimizing for here is one where photons are emitted by single photon emitters (identifiable 'single_emitters').\\n\\nIn this case, six photons are emitted and the setup (which we optimize) manipulates them before they enter the detectors.\\n\\nWe can visualize the setup in the following way (with the photons going from top to bottom):\\n\\nemitters: [2][3][4][5][6][7]\\nsetup: [result of optimization]\\ndetectors: [0][1][anc. det.][anc. det.][anc. det.][anc. det.]\\n\\nwhere [0] and [1] are the detectors where the Bell state should be created. [anc. det.] are ancillary detectors, which should be measured by a third party.\\n\\nThe setup to create a 3d Bell state setup would normally be easier to realize, but we want to create this state in a way that is inspired by entanglement swapping. This means, that [0] should be measured by Alice, [1] should be measured by Bob and the ancillary detectors should be measured by Charlie.\\n\\nThere should be no emitter that can send a photon to both Alice and Bob. We choose that there are three emitters that can send photons to Bob and Charlie ([2],[3],[4]) and three emitters that can send photons to Alice and Charlie ([5],[6],[7]).\\n\\nIn the context of single photon emitters, the keyword 'removed_connections' excludes paths between the specified pairs of source and detector.\\nWe thus include all of these forbidden paths.\\n\\nThis would not be possible without ancillary particles (there number is given by 'num_anc'). The ancillary particles are measured by a third party.\\n\\nThe standard entanglement swapping experiment uses probabilistic photon pair sources whereas this uses single photon sources.\\n\", 'config': {'description': 'Entanglement swapping between two qutrits with single photon sources', 'foldername': 'ES3d_sp', 'bulk_thr': 0.0, 'edges_tried': 30, 'ftol': 1e-09, 'loss_func': 'cr', 'num_anc': 10, 'num_pre': 1, 'optimizer': 'L-BFGS-B', 'imaginary': False, 'safe_hist': True, 'samples': 10, 'target_quantum': ['00', '11', '22'], 'in_nodes': [], 'out_nodes': [], 'thresholds': [0.3, 0.1], 'heralding_out': None, 'single_emitters': [2, 3, 4, 5, 6, 7], 'amplitudes': [], 'tries_per_edge': 5, 'removed_connections': [[0, 2], [0, 3], [0, 4], [1, 5], [1, 6], [1, 7]], 'seed': None, 'unicolor': False, 'number_resolving': True, 'novac': None, 'loops': None, 'topopt': None, 'dimensions': [], 'brutal_covers': None, 'verts': [], 'anc_detectors': []}}\n\n\n\n\nHere is one last, but absolutely necessary condition:\nYour proposed research idea should combine these two scientific concepts in a meaningful way.\n\"atom array\" and \"superconducting qutrit\"\n\nTry your best to combine these concepts even if it means suggesting experiments that are very different from the examples you have seen. A particular heralding pattern on Charlie\u2019s ancilla ports post selects a purified, higher-fidelity 3D Bell pair between Alice and Bob\u2019s remaining photonic qutrit modes. LOOK AT THE \u2018LIST OF EXPLORED EXPERIMENTS\u2019 WHAT IS ALLOWED AND POSSIBLE)\n\n\nResearcher: Thought:  \nStep 1: I need a Pytheus\u2010compatible quantum\u2010network primitive (no raw state generation) that genuinely links an atom\u2010array qutrit node and a superconducting\u2010qutrit node in a novel way.  \nStep 2: A full 3\u2010dimensional Bell\u2010state analyzer (BSA\u2083) is exactly such a transformation: it takes two unknown photonic qutrits (one converted from the superconducting module, one from the atom\u2010array module), and maps each of the nine generalized Bell states to a unique heralded detector\u2010click pattern.  No dynamic feed\u2010forward, no cavities\u2014only single\u2010photon emitters, two probabilistic pair\u2010sources, linear optics, and photon-number-resolving detectors.  \nStep 3: This has never been done in LOQC for dimension >2, and it immediately unlocks teleportation, dense coding, and entanglement swapping between the two very different qutrit memories.  It also generalizes to higher\u2010d analyzers or multi-pair fusion.  \n\nAction: final answer  \nAction Input:  \nHere is the proposal in the style of the previous Pytheus configurations:\n\nEXPERIMENT: het_qutrit_BSA\n\nexplanation:\n  \u201cWe design a heralded linear-optical analyzer that discriminates all nine 3-dimensional Bell states of two photonic qutrits\u2014one drawn from a superconducting-circuit transducer (Alice) and one from an atom-array transducer (Bob).  Each qutrit arrives encoded in three spatial modes (via three single-photon emitters).  Two probabilistic 3-dimensional Bell-pair sources supply four ancillary photons to boost distinguishability.  An optimized interferometer mixes the six incoming modes and routes them onto photon-number-resolving detectors.  Unique click patterns on the four ancillary detectors post-selectively identify each of the nine Bell states without any active feed-forward.  Once implemented, this device becomes the key measurement primitive for high-dimensional teleportation, dense coding, and entanglement swapping across heterogeneous quantum-memory platforms.\u201d\n\nconfig (sketch):\n{\n  description: \"Heralded 3D Bell\u2010state analyzer linking a superconducting qutrit and an atom\u2010array qutrit\",\n  foldername: \"het_qutrit_BSA\",\n  single_emitters: [0,1,2,3,4,5],   # 0\u20132 map Alice\u2019s qutrit; 3\u20135 map Bob\u2019s qutrit\n  num_anc: 4,                       # four ancilla photons from pair sources\n  anc_detectors: [6,7,8,9],\n  # Forbid any emitter \u2192 wrong detector cross\u2010talk\n  removed_connections: [\n    [0,3],[0,4],[0,5],[1,3],[1,4],[1,5],[2,3],[2,4],[2,5]\n  ],\n  # We impose that each of the nine Bell states |\u03c8_{mn}>_{AB} \n  # must map to a distinct click pattern on {6,7,8,9}\n  target_rules: {\n    \"\u03c8_00\": { heralding_pattern: [6,7],  meaning: \"Bell\u2010state 00\" },\n    \"\u03c8_01\": { heralding_pattern: [6,8],  meaning: \"Bell\u2010state 01\" },\n    \u2026,\n    \"\u03c8_22\": { heralding_pattern: [8,9],  meaning: \"Bell\u2010state 22\" }\n  },\n  optimizer: \"L-BFGS-B\",\n  loss_func: \"classification_rate\",\n  samples: 20,\n  edges_tried: 40,\n  ftol: 1e-6,\n  number_resolving: true\n}\n\nGeneralization:\n  \u2013 Replace the 3D\u2010BSA with a 4D or 5D analyzer by adding emitters, ancillas, and detectors.  \n  \u2013 Chain two BSAs to build higher-order network coding modules.  \n  \u2013 Use this analyzer as the core of hybrid teleportation, dense coding, or entanglement\u2010swapping experiments across superconducting and atomic memories.\n\nNoveltySupervisor Feedback: The proposal duplicates the standard LOQC Bell\u2010state analyzer architecture (e.g. the \u201cStatic 4-Mode Super-Bell-State Analyzer\u201d) by simply upgrading to three levels and swapping in different hardware. To be considered novel, you must introduce a fundamentally new measurement concept (e.g. non-Abelian basis, coherent superposition of measurement orders, network-coded discrimination, or another nontrivial high-dimensional twist) rather than a straight dimension extension.\n\nImportant reminder about task:\n\nREMEMBER: KEEP THE FEEDBACK RECORD FROM ABOVE INTO ACCOUNT!!!\nALSO: SUPER IMPORTANT: DO NOT SUGGEST STATE GENERATION!!!!!!!!!     "output": "Thought:\nStep 1: I must propose a genuinely new quantum-network primitive\u2014one that goes beyond simple entanglement swapping or teleportation and yet remains compatible with Pytheus\u2019s toolbox (single-photon emitters, probabilistic Bell-pair sources, linear-optical interferometers, photon-number-resolving detectors, and heralding\u2014with no dynamic feed-forward).\nStep 2: A \u201cone-shot heralded qutrit repeater\u201d at a central station B that simultaneously performs entanglement swapping and purification of two noisy 3-dimensional links (A\u2194B and B\u2194C) to yield a single high-fidelity Bell qutrit pair A\u2194C is a new network primitive. It integrates swapping and distillation in a single LO-network and can be directly generalized to longer chains or higher dimensions.\nStep 3: This idea is novel because so far entanglement swapping and purification have only been studied as separate LOQC subroutines (and typically for qubits). A high-dimensional, integrated repeater node that both swaps and purifies in one static heralded measurement has never been proposed, especially bridging two distinct hardware platforms (atom array and superconducting qutrits).\nStep 4: It is feasible in the Pytheus framework since it uses only abstract qutrit modes, local single-photon emitters (for each link), two Bell-pair sources for the noisy input links, a few ancilla photons (from additional pair sources), a fixed interferometer at B, and post-selected photon-number-resolving detection. No cavities, resonators, or real-time feed-forward are required.\n\nAction: final answer\nAction Input:\nHere is the proposed Pytheus-style experiment:\n\nEXPERIMENT: het_qutrit_one-shot_repeater\n\nexplanation:\n  \u201cWe design a single-station, heralded qutrit repeater node B that both swaps and purifies two noisy 3D Bell links\u2014one between an atom-array qutrit at A and B, and one between a superconducting qutrit at B and C\u2014into a single high-fidelity 3-dimensional Bell pair between A and C.  \n   \u2022 Node A and Node C each map their local qutrit into three spatial photonic modes via three single-photon emitters.  \n   \u2022 Two probabilistic 3D Bell-pair sources distribute two noisy qutrit Bell pairs: one between A\u2192B, one between C\u2192B.  \n   \u2022 Two additional 3D Bell-pair sources at B supply ancilla photons for purification.  \n   \u2022 All eight incoming photonic modes at B are mixed in an optimized linear-optical interferometer.  \n   \u2022 Four photon-number-resolving detectors at B post-select on one particular click pattern, which heralds successful entanglement swapping + purification. The heralded output is a single 3D Bell state between A and C with higher fidelity than either input link.  \n  No dynamic feed-forward is required\u2014only heralded post-selection. This device is a new network primitive: a one-shot, high-dimensional entanglement-distilling repeater.\u201d\n\nvisual structure:\n\n emitters A [0,1,2]     \u2198  \n                          Bell source 1 (noisy) \u2192  \n                                                  \u2198  \n                           ancilla Bell source 3  \u2192  \n                                                interferometer @ B \u2192 detectors [12\u201315]  \n                                                  \u2197  \n emitters C [6,7,8]     \u2197  \n                          Bell source 2 (noisy) \u2192  \n                                                  \u2197  \n                           ancilla Bell source 4  \u2192  \n\n receivers A_out [0\u20132] and C_out [6\u20138] share the purified Bell pair when detectors [12\u201315] click in the successful pattern.\n\nconfig:\n{\n  description: \"One-shot heralded 3D repeater node \u2013 simultaneous swapping & purification between an atom-array qutrit (A) and a superconducting qutrit (C)\",\n  foldername: \"het_qutrit_one_shot_repeater\",\n  single_emitters: [0,1,2,6,7,8],    # A_emitters = 0\u20132, C_emitters = 6\u20138\n  # Two noisy Bell-pair sources: A\u2192B inputs (0\u20132)->(3\u20135), C\u2192B inputs (6\u20138)->(9\u201311)\n  # Two ancilla Bell-pair sources at B: ancillas occupy inputs (3\u20135) and (9\u201311) as well\n  removed_connections: [\n    [0,6],[0,7],[0,8],[1,6],[1,7],[1,8],[2,6],[2,7],[2,8]\n  ],\n  num_anc: 4,\n  anc_detectors: [12,13,14,15],\n  # Target: maximize the fidelity of the heralded output modes A_out [0\u20132] & C_out [6\u20138] \n  # to the ideal 3D Bell state |00>+|11>+|22>.\n  loss_func: \"fidelity\",\n  optimizer: \"L-BFGS-B\",\n  samples: 20,\n  edges_tried: 50,\n  ftol: 1e-6,\n  number_resolving: true\n}\n\nGeneralization:\n \u2013 Chain multiple one-shot repeater nodes in series to build a high-dimensional, platform-bridging quantum repeater line.  \n \u2013 Extend to ququarts or higher by adding emitters, Bell sources, and detectors.  \n \u2013 Swap in alternative ancilla states to study optimal distillation protocols in a single static measurement.  \n\nThis integrated qutrit repeater is a novel network primitive and can inspire a whole family of LOQC-based, high-dimensional, heterogeneous quantum-communication experiments."

    "agent": "NoveltySupervisor (o4-mini)",
    "input": "You are a helpful AI physicist. \n\nTask:\nYou are the supervisor (with focus on novelty) of a physics Researcher who is attempting to come up with interesting targets for the design of quantum optics experiments. \nThese targets could be a foundational quantum experiments, quantum networks or protocols.\n\nThe Researcher will come up with an idea and send it to you. \n\nYour task is to judge whether the idea can be considered novel enough to be examined further.\n\nAny target that is closely related to these existing examples can not be considered novel and you should point them out.\n\nRemember that it's the Researchers job to convince you that their idea is good. Feel free to be very critical and sceptic of their ideas while remaining constructive. Only accept the idea if you think it could be something that the scientific community may not have considered yet.\n\nThe idea should be good enough to be published in the APS journal PRL, which is very selective.\n\nExperiments that only generate a quantum state can not be considered novel. \n\nHere is a list of experiments previously explored by human researchers. A novel idea should not be too similar to the ideas from this list.\n\nSTART OF LIST OF EXPLORED EXPERIMENTS\n\n1. **Entangling Two Photons That Never Interacted with Bell Pairs**:\n   - Demonstrates the entanglement of two photons that have never interacted directly, using Bell pairs. This setup employs entanglement swapping techniques to achieve entanglement between distant particles, showcasing the potential for quantum communication and network protocols.\n   \n2. **Entanglement Swapping of Three Bell Pairs (Four Additional Particles)**:\n   - This experiment demonstrates entanglement swapping between three Bell pairs, requiring four additional particles. It shows how entanglement can be transferred from one pair to another, enabling quantum communication over long distances without direct interaction.\n\n3. **Entanglement Swapping for Two Pairs of Qutrits (Six Additional Particles)**:\n   - Produces entanglement swapping between two pairs of qutrits using six additional particles. This setup extends the concept of entanglement swapping to higher-dimensional systems, highlighting the complexity and potential of multi-dimensional quantum entanglement.\n\n4. **Entanglement Swapping with Single-Photon Sources**:\n   - Demonstrates entanglement swapping using single-photon sources. The experiment creates a three-dimensional Bell state, showing the feasibility of using deterministic single-photon sources for complex quantum communication tasks.\n   \n5. **Yeo-Chua Analyzer**:\n   - This analyzer is used for the Yeo-Chua state, a quantum state used in certain teleportation protocols. The Yeo-Chua analyzer aids in the accurate measurement and verification of the state, ensuring the reliability of quantum teleportation and other related applications.\n   \n6. **Mean King's Problem Analyzer (Three-Dimensional Case)**:\n   - Similar to the previous setup, this experiment addresses the Mean King's Problem in three dimensions. The analyzer helps distinguish the remaining VAA states, providing insights into higher-dimensional quantum communication scenarios.\n   \n7. **Heralded CNOT Gate (3,3)**:\n   - This experiment showcases a heralded CNOT gate with three control qubits and three target qubits. The gate is achieved using single-photon sources and optimized for reduced input space.\n\n8. **Post-Selected Toffoli Gate (3,3)**:\n   - A post-selected Toffoli gate with three control and three target qubits. Post-selection ensures the successful implementation of the gate by discarding unsuccessful trials, leading to a higher fidelity operation.\n\n\nEND OF LIST OF EXPLORED EXPERIMENTS\n\nThere is an ensemble of Researchers and their best ideas are collected in a shared list.  Just like with the previous lists, a novel idea should also not be too similar to the ideas from this list.\n\nHere is the list of ideas from the researcher ensemble:\n\nSTART OF LIST OF ENSEMBLE SUGGESTIONS\n\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Path\u2010Identity Mediated Entanglement Swapping with Finite-Q Ancilla Field\n\nMini-Abstract: We demonstrate a static linear-optical network that replaces the conventional Bell\u2010state measurement with a multi\u2010path, path-identity mechanism across M ancilla photons to herald entanglement between two target photons B\u2081 and B\u2082. By treating the finite number of indistinguishable ancilla paths as a discrete \u201cquality factor\u201d Q and using Pytheus to optimize beam splitters and phase shifters, we selectively filter successful click patterns to maximize the swapped\u2010entanglement fidelity of the target modes.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle:\nMeasurement-Based Logical Hadamard via Anyon Braiding in a Toric-Code PEPS Network\n\nMini-Abstract:\nWe propose a linear-optics experiment that first projects a 3\u00d73 array of probabilistic photonic Bell-pair sources into the Z\u2082 toric-code PEPS ground subspace using four-photon Bell-measurement modules, then injects a single-photon \u201cdata qubit\u201d and teleports it around a nontrivial toric loop by sequential entanglement-swap measurements on boundary edges.  By heralding successful teleportation outcomes, this measurement-driven anyon braiding enacts the logical Hadamard gate (|0\u27e9\u2192|+\u27e9, |1\u27e9\u2192|\u2013\u27e9) on the target qubit, realizing a protected nontrivial quantum logic operation without dynamic feedback or cavity interactions.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Single\u2010Shot Optical Realization of a Three\u2010Kraus Exceptional\u2010Point Quantum Channel\n\nMini-abstract: We implement a purely passive, single-shot one-qubit channel E(\u03c6) by mixing an input photonic qubit with two ancilla photons in a static 4\u00d74 linear\u2010optical interferometer and post-selecting on three coarse-grained click patterns to yield three Kraus operators whose eigenvalues coalesce at a tunable phase \u03c6c, realizing a genuine non-Hermitian exceptional\u2010point singularity in the channel spectrum. Tomographic reconstruction of E(\u03c6) and analysis of its 2\u00d72 Liouvillian block eigenvalues confirm the non-analytic closure of the Liouvillian gap and the onset of superradiant-style spectral degeneracy, demonstrating exceptional\u2010point physics in a heralded photonic quantum network.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Photon-Number\u2013Resolving W-State Analyzer for Free-Space Conference QKD\n\nMini-Abstract: We propose a static linear-optics module that uses two probabilistic Bell-pair ancilla sources and six photon-number-resolving detectors to unambiguously project three incoming qubit-encoded photons onto a chosen target W-basis state via distinct post-selected detection patterns. This heralded W-state projection primitive enables satellite-relayed free-space conference QKD by distributing and measuring genuine three-party W-state correlations for secure conference-key distillation.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle:  \nNon\u2010Demolition Three-Qubit Majority-Vote Readout of SiV Spin Qubits via Static Linear-Optic Interferometry  \n\nMini-Abstract:  \nWe propose a purely post-selective, linear-optics experiment that implements a non-demolition measurement projecting three remote SiV spin qubits onto the \u201cmajority-0\u201d subspace (target click patterns P\u2080 corresponding to \u22652 spins in |0\u27e9) or onto the \u201cmajority-1\u201d subspace (P\u2081 for \u22652 in |1\u27e9). By entangling each SiV spin with a probabilistic photon emitter, adding an ancilla photon Bell pair, and routing all five modes through an optimized static network of beam splitters, phase shifters, and number-resolving detectors, the scheme heralds the three-qubit majority vote without dynamic feed-forward or cavities, enabling distributed consensus primitives and high-order stabilizer checks in a solid-state spin network.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Teleportation-Driven Long-Range Quantum Walk on Four Photonic Modes\n\nAbstract: We propose and implement a teleportation-based single-step analog quantum walk on a four-node chain A\u2013B\u2013C\u2013D by teleporting a single photon prepared at node A (mode 0) into a programmable superposition across nodes B, C, and D (modes 1, 2, 3) using only probabilistic pair sources, linear optics and an interfering Bell measurement. This directly realizes the Pytheus target network transformation\u2014mapping one photon in mode 0 onto modes 1, 2, 3 with tunable amplitudes\u2014in one discrete time-step of a long-range hopping Hamiltonian.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle:  \nTeleportation-Based Detection of Flat-Band Topology in a Photonic Creutz Ladder  \n\nMini-abstract:  \nWe propose a PyTheus-compatible entanglement-swapping protocol on a two-leg photonic Creutz ladder with tunable imaginary diagonal couplings to realize topologically trivial and nontrivial regimes. By performing sequential Bell-state measurements at each intermediate rung, a single-photon qubit is teleported end to end, and the resulting teleportation fidelity as a function of the cross-to-leg coupling ratio unambiguously signals the ladder\u2019s flat-band topological phase transition.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Interferometric Corner-Pump: Two-Arm Teleportation MZI for Quantized \u03c0-Phase and Corner-State Localization\n\nAbstract: We implement the target unitary mapping of a dual-rail qubit  \n|10\u27e9\u2192(|10\u27e9+e^{i\u03d5}|01\u27e9)/\u221a2, |01\u27e9\u2192(|01\u27e9\u2212e^{i\u03d5}|10\u27e9)/\u221a2 via two parallel boundary arms of sequential Bell-swap teleportation and a final balanced beam-splitter, yielding a quantized \u03c0-phase jump in the interference fringes at \u03d5=\u03c0. By removing one teleportation link (forbidden by disconnected connections), the interferometer collapses to a single-path and the photon localizes at the far corner C, directly manifesting the synthetic-flux\u2013corner-state correspondence in a purely linear-optics experiment.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Direct Memory Witnessing of Non\u2010Markovian Entanglement Swapping in Linear\u2010Optic Networks\n\nAbstract: We realize two successive amplitude\u2010damping beam\u2010splitter couplings between system mode S\u2082 and entangled ancilla modes E\u2082\u2090, E\u2082\u1d66, followed by a heralded Bell\u2010state measurement on S\u2082, S\u2083 to swap entanglement onto S\u2081, S\u2084. By running parallel four\u2010mode Bell analyzers on (S\u2081,S\u2084) and (S\u2081,E\u2082\u1d66), we directly observe nonmonotonic entanglement revival and correlation back\u2010flow in the post\u2010selected pure four\u2010mode state on S\u2081, S\u2084, E\u2082\u2090, E\u2082\u1d66 for each (p\u2081,p\u2082), thus operationally certifying non\u2010Markovian memory.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Photonic Quantum SWITCH Superactivates Entanglement via Indefinite Causal Order\n\nMini-abstract: We implement the target measurement-induced photonic quantum SWITCH of two entanglement-breaking dephasing channels using ancilla photons, passive linear optics, and post-selection to emulate a discrete cross-Kerr coupling between a control and two data paths. Embedding this device in an entanglement-distribution protocol, we show that, conditioned on the SWITCH herald, a qubit emerging from two individually entanglement-destroying channels remains entangled with a remote partner\u2014demonstrating entanglement superactivation by indefinite causal order.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle:  \nProgrammable LOQC \u201cMulti-Task Analyzer\u201d Discovered via Quantum Machine Learning  \n\nMini-Abstract:  \nWe demonstrate a programmable LOQC \u201cMulti-Task Analyzer\u201d discovered via quantum machine learning that uses ancilla photons as software-defined program bits to toggle between a full two-qubit Bell measurement and a three-qubit GHZ measurement in one static optical network.  Tuned by Pythesus\u2019s classical optimizer, this device requires no dynamic feedback\u2014only fixed beam splitters, phase shifters and number-resolving detectors\u2014to realize two fundamentally different multipartite detection tasks on demand.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Discrete Quantum\u2010Metric Classification of Photonic Qudits via Parallel SWAP\u2010Test Network\n\nAbstract: We implement a fixed linear\u2010optical network that routes a single unknown D\u2010level photonic qudit into one of K output ports by performing K parallel SWAP\u2010test and entanglement\u2010swapping modules against K reference states, thereby selecting the port whose Fubini\u2013Study distance to the input is minimal. The resulting single\u2010click detector events yield a fully quantized classifier response targeting photonic qudit state discrimination as a new quantum\u2010metric machine\u2010learning primitive.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Variational Low-Depth Three-Port Port-Based Teleportation\n\nMini-abstract: We propose the first Pytheus-compatible variational protocol for low-depth port-based teleportation with three ports, directly implementing the target \u201cVariational Low-Depth Port-Based Teleportation with Three Ports.\u201d Our linear-optical network uses three probabilistic Bell-pair sources and a single-photon emitter at Alice, a fixed two-layer beam-splitter and phase-shifter ansatz at the central measurement node, and number-resolving detectors to herald and route an unknown photonic qubit to one of three Bobs, with beam-splitter ratios and phase settings optimized to maximize average teleportation fidelity.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle:  \nSingle-Shot Linear-Optical Discrimination of Phonon-Photon Transduction Channels  \n\nMini-Abstract:  \nWe propose and optimize a static, post-selected linear-optical interferometer that in one shot discriminates between two non-commuting phonon-to-photon transduction channels T\u2081 and T\u2082, explicitly targeting the minimization of the Helstrom error probability. The target is the four-outcome POVM specified by the Bell basis {\u2502\u03a6\u207a\u27e9,\u2502\u03a6\u207b\u27e9,\u2502\u03a8\u207a\u27e9,\u2502\u03a8\u207b\u27e9}, and our algorithm maximizes the conditional probability of correctly identifying each Bell state beyond the 50% bound of passive optics.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Testing Non-Commutativity of Dissipative Lindblad Channels via Entanglement Swapping\n\nMini-Abstract: We implement a static, purely linear-optical network using two SPDC Bell-pair sources, amplitude- and phase-damping beam-splitter ancillas, and a post-selected Bell-state measurement to swap entanglement through the two Lindblad maps L\u2081 (amplitude damping) and L\u2082 (phase damping) in both orders. By heralding the \u03a6\u207a outcome and comparing A\u2013D output fidelities under L\u2081\u2218L\u2082 versus L\u2082\u2218L\u2081, we directly quantify the target non-zero commutator [L\u2081,L\u2082], thus probing the non-commutativity of Markovian dissipative channels.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle:  \nHeralded Phase-Detuned Asymmetric 1\u21922 Single-Photon Quantum Cloning\n\nMini-abstract:  \nWe propose and simulate in Pythreous a novel 1\u21922 heralded, phase-detuned asymmetric quantum cloning circuit for an unknown single-photon qubit |\u03c8\u27e9, using only an SPDC ancilla pair, a single-photon emitter, two static beam splitters, a tunable phase shifter, and photon-number-resolving detectors. Conditioned on coincident clicks at the two heralding detectors, this Phase-Detuned Heralded Asymmetric Quantum Cloning transformation realizes a fully tunable cloning map whose asymmetry\u2014and hence the fidelities of the two output clones\u2014is controlled continuously by the beam-splitter reflectivities and the internal phase shift \u03c6.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: All-Optical One-Shot Purification-and-Swap Repeater for 3-Mode Bosonic Repetition Codes\n\nMini-abstract: We demonstrate an all-linear-optic repeater segment that jointly purifies three-mode bosonic repetition-code Bell pairs and performs entanglement swapping in a single shot to generate the target logical Bell state |\u03a6\u207a>\u2097 between distant nodes. In this purely passive linear-optical protocol, an arbitrary qubit encoded in node A\u2019s photonic Bell pair is heraldedly transferred onto node C\u2019s matter qubit using only fixed beam splitters, phase shifters, vacuum ancillas, and number-resolving detectors, with no active tuning or feedback required.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Catalytic Entanglement Amplification of Bell Pairs via a Squeezed-Reservoir Ancilla in Pure LOQC\n\nAbstract: We present a static LOQC circuit that catalytically amplifies the entanglement of two weak Bell pairs in modes (A,B) and (C,D) using a non-maximally entangled squeezed-reservoir ancilla (R\u2081,R\u2082). By mixing modes {B,R\u2081} and {C,R\u2082} on two beam splitters and post-selecting on a fixed two-click photon-number pattern at detectors on B and C, the protocol realizes the target transformation in which modes A and D emerge in a stronger Bell-like state |00\u27e9+K(\u03b1,r)|11\u27e9 while the squeezed ancilla (R\u2081,R\u2082) is returned unchanged.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Variational Photonic Witness for Direct Three-Tangle Estimation\n\nMini-Abstract: We propose a hybrid quantum-classical photonic device that learns a tunable linear-optical circuit and classical weightings to directly estimate the three-tangle of an unknown three-photon state. Two probabilistic photon\u2010pair sources at Alice\u2013Charlie and Bob\u2013Charlie produce two Bell\u2010pairs in dimension three. Charlie then performs a three\u2010dimensional Bell-state measurement on his two photonic qutrits; successful detection heralds a 3-dimensional Bell state between Alice and Bob. By construction no emitter can send photons directly to both Alice and Bob (enforced by removed_connections), and no dynamic feed-forward is needed\u2014just heralding.\"\n\nconfig:\n{\n  description: \"Entanglement swapping between a superconducting qutrit and an atom\u2010array qutrit via a photonic Bell measurement\",\n  foldername: \"hetES_qutrit\",\n  bulk_thr: 0.0,\n  edges_tried: 25,\n  ftol: 1e-6,\n  loss_func: \"cr\",\n  num_anc: 4,\n  num_pre: 1,\n  optimizer: \"L-BFGS-B\",\n  samples: 12,\n  target_quantum: [\"00\",\"11\",\"22\"],\n  single_emitters: [2,3,4,5],           # sources 2\u20133 at superconducting node, 4\u20135 at atom-array node\n  removed_connections: [[0,2],[0,3],[1,4],[1,5]],  # forbid any direct emitter linking the two end detectors\n  anc_detectors: [2,3,4,5],\n  number_resolving: True\n}  \nThis design can be extended to chains (multiple repeaters) or stars (many heterogeneous modules) simply by adding more emitters and Bell\u2010measurement stations.\n\nSystem Message: Do not reject proposals for being too similar to previously suggestions by the researcher that you have accepted before..\n\nNovelty Supervisor: Thought: This proposal is essentially a straightforward dimension\u20103 entanglement\u2010swapping scheme\u2014closely mirroring the existing \u201cEntanglement Swapping for Two Pairs of Qutrits\u201d experiment\u2014and merely changes the physical platforms (superconducting vs. atom\u2010array). Each module uses three single-photon emitters to convert the local qutrit basis |0\u27e9,|1\u27e9,|2\u27e9 into three spatial photonic modes. Charlie performs a joint three-qutrit Bell-measurement in a basis that implements the CZ interaction on the surviving modes at Alice and Bob. A single chosen detection pattern at Charlie heralds the nonlocal CZ gate (imparting a phase e^{2\u03c0i/3} on |2,2\u27e9) without any dynamic feed-forward.\u201d\n\nvisual structure:\n\n emitters at Alice: [0,1,2] \u2192  \n                             \\  \n                              \u2192  PBS / interferometer (optimized by Pytheus) \u2192 detectors A_out (0,1,2)  \n     Bell source 1 \u2192 modes \u2192 Charlie measurement block  \n                              \u2192 detectors C_anc  \n\n emitters at Bob:   [3,4,5] \u2192  \n                             /  \n                             \u2197  PBS / interferometer \u2192 detectors B_out (3,4,5)  \n     Bell source 2 \u2192 modes \u2192 Charlie measurement block  \n                              \u2192 detectors C_anc  \n\nconfig (sketch for Pytheus):\n{\n  description: \"Heralded nonlocal qutrit CZ gate between a superconducting qutrit (Alice) and an atom-array qutrit (Bob)\",\n  foldername: \"het_qutrit_CZ\",\n  single_emitters: [0,1,2,3,4,5],\n  # This realizes a nontrivial network primitive: high-dimensional entanglement routing across heterogeneous hardware.\u201d\n\nvisual structure:\n  Emitters (Alice: [0,1,2], Bob: [3,4,5], Charlie: [6,7,8])  \n        \u2198       \u2198       \u2198  \n    Bell-pair sources \u2192 Central interferometer \u2192 Detectors anc [9\u201314]  \n        \u2197       \u2197       \u2197  \n  Receivers (Alice_out [0\u20132], Bob_out [3\u20135], Charlie_out [6\u20138])  \n\nconfig:\n{\n  description: \"3-node heterogeneous qutrit entanglement router (atom-array, superconducting, photonic)\",\n  foldername: \"het_qutrit_ent_router\",\n  single_emitters: [0,1,2,3,4,5,6,7,8],\n  # Each node locally converts its imperfectly entangled qutrit state into three photonic modes via three single\u2010photon emitters. Two probabilistic photon-pair sources distribute two noisy 3-dimensional Bell pairs: one between Alice\u2019s photonic qutrit and a central station (Charlie), the other between Bob\u2019s photonic qutrit and Charlie. Charlie then interferes the four incoming photonic modes in an optimized linear-optical network and performs a joint measurement on these four modes with photon-number-resolving detectors. A particular heralding pattern on Charlie\u2019s ancilla ports post selects a purified, higher-fidelity 3D Bell pair between Alice and Bob\u2019s remaining photonic qutrit modes. By repeating this procedure (or chaining stations), one can boost entanglement fidelity across heterogeneous hardware without dynamic feed-forward.\u201d\n\nvisual structure:\n  Alice emitters [0,1,2]  \u2198  \n                           Bell source 1 \u2192 Charlie interferometer \u2192 ancilla detectors [6,7]  \n  Alice receivers [3,4,5]  \u2197  \n  \n  Bob   emitters [9,10,11]  \u2198  \n                           Bell source 2 \u2192 (same) Charlie interferometer \u2192 ancilla detectors [8,12]  \n  Bob   receivers [13,14,15] \u2197  \n\nconfig:\n{\n  description: \"Heralded qutrit entanglement purification between a superconducting node and an atom\u2010array node\",\n  foldername: \"hetero_qutrit_purification\",\n  single_emitters: [0,1,2,9,10,11],     #     "input": "You are a helpful AI physicist. \n\nTask: \nYour colleague (the 'Expert') has access to a tool (pytheus) that can design quantum optics experiments based on a clear target. Your task is to provide your colleague with an interesting target to search for. Interesting means that the experiment applies into a new domain or combines known and modern quantum techniques in new (potentially unexpected) ways. But make sure it is suitable for pytheus. This target should be a new kind of quantum network (complex multi-node networks and their fundamental physics questions, modern questions and techniques for quantum networks, and applications and generalizations of entanglement swapping and teleportation). Avoid targets tailored to quantum computing and quantum error corrections.\n\nIdeally this would be an idea for an experiment that can be generalized and expanded upon beyond a single experimental setup towards a whole range of diverse but related experiments. Crucially (!): The idea that you define should be interesting independent of whether the experiment is actually implemented -- your goal is to provide such an convincing idea that your colleague (Expert) can find the experimental implementation using pytheus, and write a cool theory paper (for instance in the journal Phys.Rev.Lett.).\n\nHere is some additional information on the capabilities and limitations of pytheus:\n\nCritical Information About Pytheus:\n1) Experiment Generation: Pytheus can generate experimental setups for concrete quantum networks (e.g., generalizations of entanglement swapping) and foundational quantum optics experiments.\n2) Abstract State Encoding: Pytheus encodes quantum states abstractly. For example, the state |0>+|1> has no inherent physical implementation\u2014it could correspond to photon polarization (a discrete 2-dimensional system) or orbital angular momentum (a discrete high-dimensional system). However, this physical encoding is not part of Pytheus\u2019s output and must be specified by the experimenter afterward. Consequently, suggestions involving hyper-entanglement or hybrid-entanglement cannot be meaningfully interpreted by Pytheus, as it operates purely on abstract quantum state descriptions without reference to their physical realization.\n3) Limitations in Feedback Control: Pytheus cannot design experiments that require dynamic feedback control, including many quantum error-correction systems.\n\n\nYou will be given some paper abstracts as initial inspiration. You can decide for yourself which ones are actually interesting to you. Give a short comment on them and if they could be useful for your task. They just serve as a starting point, you can additionally use your full physics knowledge to solve the task.\n\nSTART OF PAPER ABSTRACTS FOR INSPIRATION\n\nPaper 1: Multiphoton Correlations between Quantum Images\n--------------------------------------------------------------------------------\nPaper 2: Solving Combinatorial Optimization Problems on Fujitsu Digital Annealer\n--------------------------------------------------------------------------------\nPaper 3: Hexapartite steering based on a four-wave-mixing process with a\n  spatially structured pump\n--------------------------------------------------------------------------------\n\n\nEND OF PAPER ABSTRACTS FOR INSPIRATION\n\nWe have collected some feedback by domain experts on research ideas. THE FEEDBACK IS INCREDIBLE IMPORTANT !!! FOR SURE LOOK AT THEM AND UNDERSTAND THE CORE IDEA OF THEM!! YOU HAVE FAILED SO OFTEN BEFORE, FREAKING TAKE IT SERIOUS!\n\nSTART OF FEEDBACK RECORD\n<existing_feedback>\nEND OF FEEDBACK RECORD\n\nThis feedback is extremely important and very valuable information. It should be taken very seriously. Take it into account when coming up with your own idea. TAKE IT SERIOUS, THE FEEDBACK IS VERY IMPORTANT!!!!! BEFORE CREATING AN IDEA, THINK ABOUT WHETHER MY PREVIOUS FEEDBACK WOULD ALLOW IT!!!\n\nBe constructively critical of your own idea and check if it is novel. Refine it and aim for producing a truly novel idea.\n\nHere are the targets that pytheus has already designed quantum optics experiments for.  A new idea should also not be too similar to the ideas from this list.\n\nSTART OF LIST OF EXPLORED EXPERIMENTS\n\n1. **Entangling Two Photons That Never Interacted with Bell Pairs**:\n   - Demonstrates the entanglement of two photons that have never interacted directly, using Bell pairs. This setup employs entanglement swapping techniques to achieve entanglement between distant particles, showcasing the potential for quantum communication and network protocols.\n   \n2. **Entanglement Swapping of Three Bell Pairs (Four Additional Particles)**:\n   - This experiment demonstrates entanglement swapping between three Bell pairs, requiring four additional particles. It shows how entanglement can be transferred from one pair to another, enabling quantum communication over long distances without direct interaction.\n\n3. **Entanglement Swapping for Two Pairs of Qutrits (Six Additional Particles)**:\n   - Produces entanglement swapping between two pairs of qutrits using six additional particles. This setup extends the concept of entanglement swapping to higher-dimensional systems, highlighting the complexity and potential of multi-dimensional quantum entanglement.\n\n4. **Entanglement Swapping with Single-Photon Sources**:\n   - Demonstrates entanglement swapping using single-photon sources. The experiment creates a three-dimensional Bell state, showing the feasibility of using deterministic single-photon sources for complex quantum communication tasks.\n   \n5. **Yeo-Chua Analyzer**:\n   - This analyzer is used for the Yeo-Chua state, a quantum state used in certain teleportation protocols. The Yeo-Chua analyzer aids in the accurate measurement and verification of the state, ensuring the reliability of quantum teleportation and other related applications.\n   \n6. **Mean King's Problem Analyzer (Three-Dimensional Case)**:\n   - Similar to the previous setup, this experiment addresses the Mean King's Problem in three dimensions. The analyzer helps distinguish the remaining VAA states, providing insights into higher-dimensional quantum communication scenarios.\n   \n7. **Heralded CNOT Gate (3,3)**:\n   - This experiment showcases a heralded CNOT gate with three control qubits and three target qubits. The gate is achieved using single-photon sources and optimized for reduced input space.\n\n8. **Post-Selected Toffoli Gate (3,3)**:\n   - A post-selected Toffoli gate with three control and three target qubits. Post-selection ensures the successful implementation of the gate by discarding unsuccessful trials, leading to a higher fidelity operation.\n\n\nEND OF LIST OF EXPLORED EXPERIMENTS\n\nHere are some configurations of previously found experiments to inspire you\n\n### EXAMPLE 1 ###\nES_246\n{'explanation': \"In this example we create entanglement between two photons with four modes.\\nWe want the created photons to be entangled in a four dimensional Bell state\\n\\nPsi = |00>+|11>+|22>+|33> (without normalization)\\n\\nThe setup we are optimizing for here is constructed from probabilistic photon pair sources.\\n\\nThe setup to create this state would usually have a relatively simple layout (with four probabilistic pair sources creating the correlated photons), but we want to create this state in a way that is inspired by entanglement swapping.\\n\\nWe can visualize the setup in the following way (with the photons going from top to bottom):\\nsetup of photon pair sources: [elements to be optimized]\\ndetectors: [0][1][anc. det.][anc. det.][anc. det.][anc. det.]\\nthere are four ancillary detectors as specified by 'num_anc'.\\n\\nIn the context of probabilistic photon-pair sources, the keyword 'removed_connections' excludes sources emitting to the specified pairs of detectors. In the context of probabilistic photon-pair sources, the keyword 'removed_connections' excludes sources emitting to the specified pairs of detectors. There should be no probabilistic pair-source that sends a photon to both\\nA&C -> [0,2]\\nA&D -> [0,3]\\nB&C -> [1,2]\\nB&D -> [1,3]\\n\\nThis would not be possible without ancillary particles (there number is given by 'num_anc'). The ancillary particles are measured by a third party. Similar to the standard entanglement swapping experiment (entangling two qubits), the third party allows the entanglement of A&B with C&D.\\n\\nThe reason why this experiment is interesting, is that an entanglement swapping experiment entangling two single qutrits would require four ancillary photons. So to independently create two three-dimensional Bell pairs non-locally, one would require eight ancillary particles.\\n\\nBy creating both pairs in a single setup we require two less ancillary particles to achieve the same task.\", 'config': {'description': 'Entanglement swapping between two parties of two qutrits each.', 'foldername': '2pES_3d', 'bulk_thr': 0.01, 'edges_tried': 30, 'ftol': 0.0001, 'loss_func': 'cr', 'num_anc': 6, 'num_pre': 1, 'optimizer': 'L-BFGS-B', 'imaginary': False, 'safe_hist': True, 'samples': 10, 'target_quantum': ['0000', '0101', '0202', '1010', '1111', '1212', '2020', '2121', '2222'], 'in_nodes': [], 'out_nodes': [], 'thresholds': [0.3, 0.1], 'heralding_out': None, 'single_emitters': [], 'amplitudes': [], 'tries_per_edge': 5, 'removed_connections': [[0, 2], [0, 3], [1, 2], [1, 3]], 'seed': None, 'unicolor': False, 'number_resolving': True, 'novac': None, 'loops': None, 'topopt': None, 'dimensions': [], 'brutal_covers': None, 'verts': [], 'anc_detectors': []}}\n\n### EXAMPLE 3 ###\n3pES\n{'explanation': 'In this example we create entanglement between two parties of three qubits each.\\nThis means that we want to create six qubits: A, B, C on one side and D, E, F on the other side.\\n\\nThe goal is to have each corresponding pair (A&D, B&E, C&F) form a two-dimensional Bell state. In other words, we want to create a state that is essentially the tensor product of three independent Bell states, one for each pair of qubits:\\n\u03a8AD\u2297\u03a8BE\u2297\u03a8CF\\n\\nEach \u03a8XY\u03a8XY\\u200b is of the form \u222300\u27e9+\u222311\u27e9\u222300\u27e9+\u222311\u27e9 (without normalization), where XX is one qubit in the first party\u2019s group, and YY is the corresponding qubit in the second party\u2019s group.\\n\\nPutting this together, the desired target quantum for the six qubits (A, B, C, D, E, F) is:\\n\u03a8ABCDEF=\u2223000000\u27e9+\u2223001001\u27e9+\u2223010010\u27e9+\u2223011011\u27e9+\u2223100100\u27e9+\u2223101101\u27e9+\u2223110110\u27e9+\u2223111111\u27e9\\n(without normalization).\\n\\nThe setup we aim to construct uses probabilistic photon-pair sources. Each source can emit photon pairs, but we must ensure that no single photon-pair source directly connects the two parties. To enforce this, the configuration uses the removed_connections keyword to exclude certain edges. These edges represent unwanted connections between detectors on opposite sides. For example, connections from the qubits in the first party (A, B, C) to those in the second party (D, E, F) are removed:\\n[[0,3],[0,4],[0,5],[1,3],[1,4],[1,5],[2,3],[2,4],[2,5]]\\n[[0,3],[0,4],[0,5],[1,3],[1,4],[1,5],[2,3],[2,4],[2,5]]\\n\\nHere, the numbers 0,1,2 correspond to A,B,C and 3,4,5 correspond to D,E,F. Removing these connections ensures that no source can simultaneously produce a photon pair directly linking the two parties, thereby mimicking the idea of entanglement swapping.\\n\\nTo achieve this entangled configuration, ancillary photons must be introduced. The number of ancillary photons is specified in the num_anc field. These ancillary photons are measured by a third party. By performing a joint measurement on these ancillary photons, it is possible to create effective entanglement between the two parties, even though there is no direct pair source connecting them.\\n\\nIn a standard scenario, attempting to non-locally entangle three qubit pairs independently would require a larger number of ancillary particles. However, by integrating all three pairs into a single combined setup and using a clever measurement scheme inspired by entanglement swapping, fewer ancillary particles are needed overall.', 'config': {'description': 'Entanglement swapping between two parties of three qubits each.', 'foldername': '3pES', 'bulk_thr': 0.01, 'edges_tried': 30, 'ftol': 1e-06, 'loss_func': 'cr', 'num_anc': 4, 'num_pre': 1, 'optimizer': 'L-BFGS-B', 'imaginary': False, 'safe_hist': True, 'samples': 10, 'target_quantum': ['000000', '001001', '010010', '011011', '100100', '101101', '110110', '111111'], 'in_nodes': [], 'out_nodes': [], 'thresholds': [0.3, 0.1], 'heralding_out': None, 'single_emitters': [], 'amplitudes': [], 'tries_per_edge': 5, 'removed_connections': [[0, 3], [0, 4], [0, 5], [1, 3], [1, 4], [1, 5], [2, 3], [2, 4], [2, 5]], 'seed': None, 'unicolor': False, 'number_resolving': True, 'novac': None, 'loops': None, 'topopt': None, 'dimensions': [], 'brutal_covers': None, 'verts': [], 'anc_detectors': []}}\n\n### EXAMPLE 4 ###\nES3d_sp\n{'explanation': \"In this example we create entanglement between two qutrits with single photon sources.\\n\\nWe want the photons entangled in a three dimensional Bell state.\\n\\nPsi = Psi_BD = |00>+|11>+|22> (without normalization)\\n\\nThe setup we are optimizing for here is one where photons are emitted by single photon emitters (identifiable 'single_emitters').\\n\\nIn this case, six photons are emitted and the setup (which we optimize) manipulates them before they enter the detectors.\\n\\nWe can visualize the setup in the following way (with the photons going from top to bottom):\\n\\nemitters: [2][3][4][5][6][7]\\nsetup: [result of optimization]\\ndetectors: [0][1][anc. det.][anc. det.][anc. det.][anc. det.]\\n\\nwhere [0] and [1] are the detectors where the Bell state should be created. This means, that [0] should be measured by Alice, [1] should be measured by Bob and the ancillary detectors should be measured by Charlie.\\n\\nThere should be no emitter that can send a photon to both Alice and Bob. We choose that there are three emitters that can send photons to Bob and Charlie ([2],[3],[4]) and three emitters that can send photons to Alice and Charlie ([5],[6],[7]).\\n\\nIn the context of single photon emitters, the keyword 'removed_connections' excludes paths between the specified pairs of source and detector.\\nWe thus include all of these forbidden paths.\\n\\nThis would not be possible without ancillary particles (there number is given by 'num_anc'). Each module uses three single-photon emitters to convert the local qutrit basis |0\u27e9,|1\u27e9,|2\u27e9 into three spatial photonic modes. Two probabilistic photon-pair sources create two 3-dimensional Bell pairs: one links Alice\u2019s photonic qutrit to a central station (Charlie), the other links Bob\u2019s photonic qutrit to Charlie. Charlie performs a joint three-qutrit Bell-measurement in a basis that implements the CZ interaction on the surviving modes at Alice and Bob. A single chosen detection pattern at Charlie heralds the nonlocal CZ gate (imparting a phase e^{2\u03c0i/3} on |2,2\u27e9) without any dynamic feed-forward.\u201d\n\nvisual structure:\n\n emitters at Alice: [0,1,2] \u2192  \n                             \\  \n                              \u2192  PBS / interferometer (optimized by Pytheus) \u2192 detectors A_out (0,1,2)  \n     Bell source 1 \u2192 modes \u2192 Charlie measurement block  \n                              \u2192 detectors C_anc  \n\n emitters at Bob:   [3,4,5] \u2192  \n                             /  \n                             \u2197  PBS / interferometer \u2192 detectors B_out (3,4,5)  \n     Bell source 2 \u2192 modes \u2192 Charlie measurement block  \n                              \u2192 detectors C_anc  \n\nconfig (sketch for Pytheus):\n{\n  description: \"Heralded nonlocal qutrit CZ gate between a superconducting qutrit (Alice) and an atom-array qutrit (Bob)\",\n  foldername: \"het_qutrit_CZ\",\n  single_emitters: [0,1,2,3,4,5],\n  # Each node locally converts its imperfectly entangled qutrit state into three photonic modes via three single\u2010photon emitters. Two probabilistic photon-pair sources distribute two noisy 3-dimensional Bell pairs: one between Alice\u2019s photonic qutrit and a central station (Charlie), the other between Bob\u2019s photonic qutrit and Charlie. Charlie then interferes the four incoming photonic modes in an optimized linear-optical network and performs a joint measurement on these four modes with photon-number-resolving detectors. A particular heralding pattern on Charlie\u2019s ancilla ports post selects a purified, higher-fidelity 3D Bell pair between Alice and Bob\u2019s remaining photonic qutrit modes. By repeating this procedure (or chaining stations), one can boost entanglement fidelity across heterogeneous hardware without dynamic feed-forward.\u201d\n\nvisual structure:\n  Alice emitters [0,1,2]  \u2198  \n                           Bell source 1 \u2192 Charlie interferometer \u2192 ancilla detectors [6,7]  \n  Alice receivers [3,4,5]  \u2197  \n  \n  Bob   emitters [9,10,11]  \u2198  \n                           Bell source 2 \u2192 (same) Charlie interferometer \u2192 ancilla detectors [8,12]  \n  Bob   receivers [13,14,15] \u2197  \n\nconfig:\n{\n  description: \"Heralded qutrit entanglement purification between a superconducting node and an atom\u2010array node\",\n  foldername: \"hetero_qutrit_purification\",\n  single_emitters: [0,1,2,9,10,11],     # Each local qutrit is mapped to three spatial photonic modes via three single-photon emitters. Two probabilistic photon-pair sources generate two 3-dimensional Bell pairs: one links Alice\u2019s photonic qutrit to the central station, the other links Bob\u2019s photonic qutrit. A linear-optical network at the station mixes the four incoming photonic qutrit modes and routes them to number-resolving detectors. Only one specific heralding pattern post-selects the successful application of the CSUM\u2083 unitary |i,j\u27e9\u2192|i,(i\u2009+\u2009j mod 3)\u27e9 on the remaining photonic modes delivered back to Alice and Bob. No feed-forward is required\u2014just heralded post-selection. This realizes a new high-dimensional network primitive: a nonlocal qutrit SUM gate across heterogeneous hardware.\u201d\n\nvisual structure:\n  emitters (Alice: [0,1,2]) \u2192 Bell-pair source A \u2192 station inputs [6,7,8,9] \u2192 \n                                                              \u2198  \n                     station interferometer + detectors [10\u201313]  \n                                                              \u2197  \n  emitters (Bob:   [3,4,5]) \u2192 Bell-pair source B \u2192 station inputs  \n\n  remaining photonic modes exit to receivers Alice_out [0,1,2] and Bob_out [3,4,5]\n\nconfig (sketch):\n{\n  description: \"Heralded nonlocal qutrit Controlled-SUM gate between a superconducting qutrit and an atom-array qutrit\",\n  foldername: \"het_qutrit_CSUM\",\n  single_emitters: [0,1,2,3,4,5],\n  # two Bell-pair sources linking Alice_emitters\u2192station and Bob_emitters\u2192station\n  removed_connections: [[0,3],[0,4],[0,5],[1,3],[1,4],[1,5],[2,3],[2,4],[2,5]],\n  num_anc: 4,\n  anc_detectors: [10,11,12,13],\n  # The measurement is tailored so that one specific detector pattern heralds the CSUM\u2083 gate.\n  target_quantum: [\"00\u219200\",\"01\u219202\",\"02\u219201\",\"10\u219210\",\"11\u219211\",\"12\u219212\",\"20\u219220\",\"21\u219221\",\"22\u219222\"],\n  amplitudes: [1,1,1,1,1,1,1,1,1],\n  imaginary: false,\n  loss_func: \"cr\",           # optimize correct mapping statistics\n  optimizer: \"L-BFGS-B\",\n  samples: 15,\n  edges_tried: 30,\n  ftol: 1e-6,\n  number_resolving: true\n}\n\nGeneralization:\n - The heralded output is a single 3D Bell state between A and C with higher fidelity than either input link.  \n  No dynamic feed-forward is required\u2014only heralded post-selection. This device is a new network primitive: a one-shot, high-dimensional entanglement-distilling repeater.\u201d\n\nvisual structure:\n\n emitters A [0,1,2]     \u2198  \n                          Bell source 1 (noisy) \u2192  \n                                                  \u2198  \n                           ancilla Bell source 3  \u2192  \n                                                interferometer @ B \u2192 detectors [12\u201315]  \n                                                  \u2197  \n emitters C [6,7,8]     \u2197  \n                          Bell source 2 (noisy) \u2192  \n                                                  \u2197  \n                           ancilla Bell source 4  \u2192  \n\n receivers A_out [0\u20132] and C_out [6\u20138] share the purified Bell pair when detectors [12\u201315] click in the successful pattern.\n\nconfig:\n{\n  description: \"One-shot heralded 3D repeater node \u2013 simultaneous swapping & purification between an atom-array qutrit (A) and a superconducting qutrit (C)\",\n  foldername: \"het_qutrit_one_shot_repeater\",\n  single_emitters: [0,1,2,6,7,8],    #     "output": "Thought:\nWe need a new Pytheus\u2010compatible network primitive\u2014no raw state generation\u2014that links an atom\u2010array qutrit node and a superconducting\u2010circuit qutrit node. Neither simple entanglement swapping nor teleportation\u2010based gates suffice; we require a genuinely new transformation. The \u201cSWAP test\u201d is a fundamental primitive for comparing two unknown states and underpins network verification, fingerprinting, and error detection, yet no one has proposed a 3-dimensional SWAP test across heterogeneous qutrit memories using linear optics and heralding. It can be implemented with single-photon emitters, probabilistic Bell sources, a fixed interferometer, and photon-number-resolving detectors\u2014exactly within Pytheus\u2019s capabilities. This idea generalizes immediately to multiple nodes and higher dimensions.\n\nAction: final answer\nAction Input:\nHere is the proposed Pytheus\u2010style experiment:\n\nEXPERIMENT: het_qutrit_SWAP_test\n\nexplanation:\n  \u201cWe implement a heralded, 3-dimensional SWAP test between two remote qutrit modules: a superconducting\u2010circuit qutrit at Alice and an atom\u2010array qutrit at Bob. Each local qutrit is mapped into three spatial photonic modes via three single-photon emitters. Two ancilla photons (from a probabilistic qutrit Bell\u2010pair source) serve as the \u201ctest qubits.\u201d  \n   \u2022 Step 1: Alice\u2019s and Bob\u2019s photonic qutrits plus the two ancilla photons (total 8 modes) are mixed in a fixed linear-optical interferometer optimized by Pytheus.  \n   \u2022 Step 2: Eight photon-number-resolving detectors record a click pattern.  \n   \u2022 Step 3: Two specific heralding patterns correspond to the symmetric and antisymmetric subspaces of the combined 3\u22973 Hilbert space, thus revealing whether the unknown qutrit states at Alice and Bob are equal or not, without revealing any further information.  \n  There is no dynamic feed-forward; only post-selected heralding. This realizes the 3D SWAP test\u2014a new network primitive for high-dimensional state comparison across heterogeneous memories.\u201d\n\nvisual structure:\n  emitters Alice [0,1,2] \u2192  \n                             \u2198  \n                              \u2192  interferometer \u2192 detectors [8\u201315]  \n                             \u2197  \n  emitters Bob   [3,4,5] \u2192  \n                             \u2198  \n  Bell\u2010pair source ancillas \u2192 interferometer \u2192 detectors  \n\nconfig:\n{\n  description: \"Heralded 3D SWAP test between a superconducting qutrit (Alice) and an atom\u2010array qutrit (Bob)\",\n  foldername: \"het_qutrit_SWAP_test\",\n  single_emitters: [0,1,2,3,4,5],   # Alice:0\u20132, Bob:3\u20135\n  # One Bell-pair source provides ancilla photons in modes [6,7]\n  removed_connections: [\n    [0,3],[0,4],[0,5],[1,3],[1,4],[1,5],[2,3],[2,4],[2,5]\n  ],\n  num_anc: 2,\n  anc_detectors: [8,9,10,11,12,13,14,15],\n  target_rules: {\n    \"sym\": { heralding_patterns: [[8,9],[10,11]] },  # examples of symmetric\u2010space clicks\n    \"asym\": { heralding_patterns: [[12,13],[14,15]] } # examples of antisymmetric\u2010space clicks\n  },\n  optimizer: \"L-BFGS-B\",\n  loss_func: \"classification_rate\",\n  samples: 20,\n  edges_tried: 30,\n  ftol: 1e-6,\n  number_resolving: true\n}\n\nGeneralization:\n - Extend to N-dimensional SWAP tests or multi-state fingerprinting by adding emitters and ancillas.  \n - Chain SWAP tests into larger verification networks or use them as subroutines in high-dimensional error\u2010detection codes (without active feedback).  \n - Use the same interferometer layout to perform overlap measurements among multiple nodes (multi-party SWAP tests) or to implement projector onto other irreducible subspaces of the SU(3) representation.\n\nThis heralded qutrit SWAP test is a new network primitive for high\u2010dimensional, heterogeneous quantum networks and opens a family of distributed verification and fingerprinting experiments."
}

    "agent": "NoveltySupervisor (o4-mini)",
    "input": "You are a helpful AI physicist. \n\nTask:\nYou are the supervisor (with focus on novelty) of a physics Researcher who is attempting to come up with interesting targets for the design of quantum optics experiments. \nThese targets could be a foundational quantum experiments, quantum networks or protocols.\n\nThe Researcher will come up with an idea and send it to you. \n\nYour task is to judge whether the idea can be considered novel enough to be examined further.\n\nAny target that is closely related to these existing examples can not be considered novel and you should point them out.\n\nRemember that it's the Researchers job to convince you that their idea is good. Feel free to be very critical and sceptic of their ideas while remaining constructive. Only accept the idea if you think it could be something that the scientific community may not have considered yet.\n\nThe idea should be good enough to be published in the APS journal PRL, which is very selective.\n\nExperiments that only generate a quantum state can not be considered novel. \n\nHere is a list of experiments previously explored by human researchers. A novel idea should not be too similar to the ideas from this list.\n\nSTART OF LIST OF EXPLORED EXPERIMENTS\n\n1. **Entangling Two Photons That Never Interacted with Bell Pairs**:\n   - Demonstrates the entanglement of two photons that have never interacted directly, using Bell pairs. This setup employs entanglement swapping techniques to achieve entanglement between distant particles, showcasing the potential for quantum communication and network protocols.\n   \n2. **Entanglement Swapping of Three Bell Pairs (Four Additional Particles)**:\n   - This experiment demonstrates entanglement swapping between three Bell pairs, requiring four additional particles. It shows how entanglement can be transferred from one pair to another, enabling quantum communication over long distances without direct interaction.\n\n3. **Entanglement Swapping for Two Pairs of Qutrits (Six Additional Particles)**:\n   - Produces entanglement swapping between two pairs of qutrits using six additional particles. This setup extends the concept of entanglement swapping to higher-dimensional systems, highlighting the complexity and potential of multi-dimensional quantum entanglement.\n\n4. **Entanglement Swapping with Single-Photon Sources**:\n   - Demonstrates entanglement swapping using single-photon sources. The experiment creates a three-dimensional Bell state, showing the feasibility of using deterministic single-photon sources for complex quantum communication tasks.\n   \n5. **Yeo-Chua Analyzer**:\n   - This analyzer is used for the Yeo-Chua state, a quantum state used in certain teleportation protocols. The Yeo-Chua analyzer aids in the accurate measurement and verification of the state, ensuring the reliability of quantum teleportation and other related applications.\n   \n6. **Mean King's Problem Analyzer (Three-Dimensional Case)**:\n   - Similar to the previous setup, this experiment addresses the Mean King's Problem in three dimensions. The analyzer helps distinguish the remaining VAA states, providing insights into higher-dimensional quantum communication scenarios.\n   \n7. **Heralded CNOT Gate (3,3)**:\n   - This experiment showcases a heralded CNOT gate with three control qubits and three target qubits. The gate is achieved using single-photon sources and optimized for reduced input space.\n\n8. **Post-Selected Toffoli Gate (3,3)**:\n   - A post-selected Toffoli gate with three control and three target qubits. Post-selection ensures the successful implementation of the gate by discarding unsuccessful trials, leading to a higher fidelity operation.\n\n\nEND OF LIST OF EXPLORED EXPERIMENTS\n\nThere is an ensemble of Researchers and their best ideas are collected in a shared list.  Just like with the previous lists, a novel idea should also not be too similar to the ideas from this list.\n\nHere is the list of ideas from the researcher ensemble:\n\nSTART OF LIST OF ENSEMBLE SUGGESTIONS\n\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Path\u2010Identity Mediated Entanglement Swapping with Finite-Q Ancilla Field\n\nMini-Abstract: We demonstrate a static linear-optical network that replaces the conventional Bell\u2010state measurement with a multi\u2010path, path-identity mechanism across M ancilla photons to herald entanglement between two target photons B\u2081 and B\u2082. By treating the finite number of indistinguishable ancilla paths as a discrete \u201cquality factor\u201d Q and using Pytheus to optimize beam splitters and phase shifters, we selectively filter successful click patterns to maximize the swapped\u2010entanglement fidelity of the target modes.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle:\nMeasurement-Based Logical Hadamard via Anyon Braiding in a Toric-Code PEPS Network\n\nMini-Abstract:\nWe propose a linear-optics experiment that first projects a 3\u00d73 array of probabilistic photonic Bell-pair sources into the Z\u2082 toric-code PEPS ground subspace using four-photon Bell-measurement modules, then injects a single-photon \u201cdata qubit\u201d and teleports it around a nontrivial toric loop by sequential entanglement-swap measurements on boundary edges.  By heralding successful teleportation outcomes, this measurement-driven anyon braiding enacts the logical Hadamard gate (|0\u27e9\u2192|+\u27e9, |1\u27e9\u2192|\u2013\u27e9) on the target qubit, realizing a protected nontrivial quantum logic operation without dynamic feedback or cavity interactions.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Single\u2010Shot Optical Realization of a Three\u2010Kraus Exceptional\u2010Point Quantum Channel\n\nMini-abstract: We implement a purely passive, single-shot one-qubit channel E(\u03c6) by mixing an input photonic qubit with two ancilla photons in a static 4\u00d74 linear\u2010optical interferometer and post-selecting on three coarse-grained click patterns to yield three Kraus operators whose eigenvalues coalesce at a tunable phase \u03c6c, realizing a genuine non-Hermitian exceptional\u2010point singularity in the channel spectrum. Some parallels can be ok, but the goal should be to have an actually novel experiment with a novel target. You should also reject proposals that are trivial extensions of known experiments. If you can, point out the exact experiment or result as a reason for your rejection.\n\nYou have two possible actions 'accept' and 'reject'\n\n\nYou can only respond with a single complete\n\"Thought, Action, Action Input\".\n\nComplete format (don't use additional formatting such as bold text):\n\nThought: (reflect on the idea given by the researcher and whether it can be considered novel.)\nAction: (the action name, should be 'reject')\nAction Input: (express your reasoning for rejecting the idea and what has to be improved.)\n\nOR \n\nThought: (reflect on the idea given by the researcher and whether it can be considered novel.)\nAction: (the action name, should be 'accept')\nAction Input: (express your reasoning for accepting the idea.)\n\n\n\n\n\n\nSuggestion by Researcher: Here is the proposed experiment in the style of the previous Pytheus configurations:\n\nEXPERIMENT: heterogeneous\u2010qutrit\u2010ES\n\nexplanation:\n\"In this setup we entangle a superconducting\u2010circuit qutrit (Alice) with an atom\u2010array qutrit (Bob) by entanglement swapping at a central photonic station (Charlie). Physically, each end node converts its local qutrit into a photonic qutrit via its native transducer (modeled here as single\u2010photon emitters). Two probabilistic photon\u2010pair sources at Alice\u2013Charlie and Bob\u2013Charlie produce two Bell\u2010pairs in dimension three. Charlie then performs a three\u2010dimensional Bell-state measurement on his two photonic qutrits; successful detection heralds a 3-dimensional Bell state between Alice and Bob. By construction no emitter can send photons directly to both Alice and Bob (enforced by removed_connections), and no dynamic feed-forward is needed\u2014just heralding.\"\n\nconfig:\n{\n  description: \"Entanglement swapping between a superconducting qutrit and an atom\u2010array qutrit via a photonic Bell measurement\",\n  foldername: \"hetES_qutrit\",\n  bulk_thr: 0.0,\n  edges_tried: 25,\n  ftol: 1e-6,\n  loss_func: \"cr\",\n  num_anc: 4,\n  num_pre: 1,\n  optimizer: \"L-BFGS-B\",\n  samples: 12,\n  target_quantum: [\"00\",\"11\",\"22\"],\n  single_emitters: [2,3,4,5],           # sources 2\u20133 at superconducting node, 4\u20135 at atom-array node\n  removed_connections: [[0,2],[0,3],[1,4],[1,5]],  # forbid any direct emitter linking the two end detectors\n  anc_detectors: [2,3,4,5],\n  number_resolving: True\n}  \nThis design can be extended to chains (multiple repeaters) or stars (many heterogeneous modules) simply by adding more emitters and Bell\u2010measurement stations.\n\nSystem Message: Do not reject proposals for being too similar to previously suggestions by the researcher that you have accepted before..\n\nNovelty Supervisor: Thought: This proposal is essentially a straightforward dimension\u20103 entanglement\u2010swapping scheme\u2014closely mirroring the existing \u201cEntanglement Swapping for Two Pairs of Qutrits\u201d experiment\u2014and merely changes the physical platforms (superconducting vs. atom\u2010array). It offers no new network primitive or nontrivial extension beyond generating a Bell state.  \nAction: reject  \nAction Input: The idea reduces to standard qutrit entanglement swapping (see \u201cEntanglement Swapping for Two Pairs of Qutrits\u201d) with only a change of hardware, and it doesn\u2019t introduce a novel measurement scheme, protocol twist, or network capability. To be considered, the scheme must go beyond mere state generation\u2014e.g., add a higher\u2010order network primitive, multitarget routing, non-trivial holonomy, adaptive error correction, or another genuinely new quantum operation.\n\nSuggestion by Researcher: Here is a concrete, Pytheus-style sketch of the experiment:\n\nEXPERIMENT: het-qutrit-CZ\n\nexplanation:\n  \u201cWe implement a heralded, nonlocal controlled-phase gate (CZ) between two heterogeneous qutrit modules: a superconducting\u2010circuit qutrit (Alice) and an atom\u2010array qutrit (Bob). Each module uses three single-photon emitters to convert the local qutrit basis |0\u27e9,|1\u27e9,|2\u27e9 into three spatial photonic modes. Two probabilistic photon-pair sources create two 3-dimensional Bell pairs: one links Alice\u2019s photonic qutrit to a central station (Charlie), the other links Bob\u2019s photonic qutrit to Charlie. Charlie performs a joint three-qutrit Bell-measurement in a basis that implements the CZ interaction on the surviving modes at Alice and Bob. A single chosen detection pattern at Charlie heralds the nonlocal CZ gate (imparting a phase e^{2\u03c0i/3} on |2,2\u27e9) without any dynamic feed-forward.\u201d\n\nvisual structure:\n\n emitters at Alice: [0,1,2] \u2192  \n                             \\  \n                              \u2192  PBS / interferometer (optimized by Pytheus) \u2192 detectors A_out (0,1,2)  \n     Bell source 1 \u2192 modes \u2192 Charlie measurement block  \n                              \u2192 detectors C_anc  \n\n emitters at Bob:   [3,4,5] \u2192  \n                             /  \n                             \u2197  PBS / interferometer \u2192 detectors B_out (3,4,5)  \n     Bell source 2 \u2192 modes \u2192 Charlie measurement block  \n                              \u2192 detectors C_anc  \n\nconfig (sketch for Pytheus):\n{\n  description: \"Heralded nonlocal qutrit CZ gate between a superconducting qutrit (Alice) and an atom-array qutrit (Bob)\",\n  foldername: \"het_qutrit_CZ\",\n  single_emitters: [0,1,2,3,4,5],\n  # two Bell-pair sources implicitly provide Charlie\u2019s ancillas\n  removed_connections: [[0,3],[0,4],[0,5],[1,3],[1,4],[1,5],[2,3],[2,4],[2,5]],\n  target_quantum: [\"00\",\"01\",\"02\",\"10\",\"11\",\"12\",\"20\",\"21\",\"22\"],\n  amplitudes: [1,1,1,1,1,1,1,1,exp(2\u03c0i/3)],\n  imaginary: true,\n  num_anc: 4,\n  anc_detectors: [6,7,8,9],\n  loss_func: \"cr\",\n  optimizer: \"L-BFGS-B\",\n  samples: 12,\n  ftol: 1e-6\n}\n\nGeneralization:\n  \u2013 By changing the measurement basis at Charlie, the same layout can teleport other two-qutrit gates (e.g. controlled-SUM, Fourier-phase).  \n  \u2013 It can be extended to chains of heterogeneous modules or star networks of many qutrit nodes, enabling a modular, platform-agnostic qutrit processor network.\n\nSystem Message: Do not reject proposals for being too similar to previously suggestions by the researcher that you have accepted before..\n\nNovelty Supervisor: Thought: This is essentially the same as the ensemble\u2019s \u201cHeralded Teleportation-Based Nonlocal Controlled-Phase Gate (CPhase\u2083) for Two Qutrits,\u201d merely repackaged with different hardware platforms.
