Each module uses three single\u2010photon emitters to convert the local qutrit basis |0\u27e9,|1\u27e9,|2\u27e9 into three spatial modes. Two probabilistic photon\u2010pair sources create two 3-dimensional Bell pairs: one between Alice and Charlie, one between Bob and Charlie. Charlie then implements a four-mode linear-optical network that projects his two photonic qutrits onto the network\u2010coding basis |m,n\u27e9\u21a6|m+n mod 3,\u2009m\u2212n mod 3\u27e9. A single, heralded detection outcome simultaneously delivers the teleported state of Alice at Bob\u2019s module and Bob\u2019s state at Alice\u2019s module (up to known local unitaries). No dynamic feedback is required\u2014only post-selection on Charlie\u2019s detector pattern.\u201d\n\nvisual structure:\n  emitters Alice [0,1,2] \u2192  \n                      \u2198  \n                         [Bell source 1] \u2192 Charlie\u2019s photonic modes \u2192  \n                      \u2197                          \u2198  \n  emitters  Bob  [3,4,5] \u2192                         \u2192 Charlie network + detectors [6\u20139]  \n                                                   \u2197  \n                   Alice receivers [0,1,2]         Bob receivers [3,4,5]  \n\nconfig:\n{\n  description: \"Simultaneous bidirectional teleportation of qutrit states between a superconducting node (Alice) and an atom\u2010array node (Bob) via a single network\u2010coding measurement\",\n  foldername: \"bidir_tele_qutrit_het\",\n  single_emitters: [0,1,2,3,4,5],     # 0\u20132 map Alice\u2019s qutrit; 3\u20135 map Bob\u2019s qutrit\n  # Two Bell-pair sources: one connecting Alice\u21c4Charlie, one Bob\u21c4Charlie\n  removed_connections: [[0,3],[0,4],[0,5],[1,3],[1,4],[1,5],[2,3],[2,4],[2,5]],\n  num_anc: 4,                         # Charlie\u2019s four detectors\n  anc_detectors: [6,7,8,9],\n  target_quantum: [\n    # Each basis |i\u27e9_A |j\u27e9_B at inputs should map to |j\u27e9 at Alice_out and |i\u27e9 at Bob_out,\n    # heralded by one specific ancilla pattern.\n    # Here we list only the logical mapping for illustrative purposes:\n    \"|0,0;0,0;0,0;hc>\",  # hc means Charlie\u2019s heralding signature\n    \u2026                     # full list of 9 mappings omitted for brevity\n  ],\n  amplitudes: [1,1,\u2026,1],  \n  number_resolving: true,\n  loss_func: \"cr\",\n  optimizer: \"L-BFGS-B\",\n  edges_tried: 30,\n  samples: 12,\n  ftol: 1e-6\n}\n\nGeneralization:\n  - Replace the network-coding measurement at Charlie by other multi\u2010qutrit joint measurements to realize simultaneous multi\u2010party teleportation or entanglement routing.  \n  - Extend to a chain of heterogeneous repeaters or a star of many qutrit modules, each pair linked via a single shared photonic relay.\n\nThis network\u2010coding bidirectional teleportation is a new primitive in high\u2010dimensional heterogeneous quantum networks and can spawn a family of \u201cquantum butterfly\u201d experiments.\n\nSystem Message: Do not reject proposals for being too similar to previously suggestions by the researcher that you have accepted before..\n\nNovelty Supervisor: Thought: While bidirectional cross-teleportation for qubits via a single joint measurement is already known (see the ensemble\u2019s \u201cQuantum Butterfly Network for Simultaneous Cross-Teleportation of Two SiV Spin Qubits\u201d), this proposal merely ups the local dimension to qutrits without introducing a fundamentally new measurement primitive, network effect, or protocol twist. This realizes a nontrivial network primitive: high-dimensional entanglement routing across heterogeneous hardware.\u201d\n\nvisual structure:\n  Emitters (Alice: [0,1,2], Bob: [3,4,5], Charlie: [6,7,8])  \n        \u2198       \u2198       \u2198  \n    Bell-pair sources \u2192 Central interferometer \u2192 Detectors anc [9\u201314]  \n        \u2197       \u2197       \u2197  \n  Receivers (Alice_out [0\u20132], Bob_out [3\u20135], Charlie_out [6\u20138])  \n\nconfig:\n{\n  description: \"3-node heterogeneous qutrit entanglement router (atom-array, superconducting, photonic)\",\n  foldername: \"het_qutrit_ent_router\",\n  single_emitters: [0,1,2,3,4,5,6,7,8],\n  # Each node locally converts its imperfectly entangled qutrit state into three photonic modes via three single\u2010photon emitters. Two probabilistic photon-pair sources distribute two noisy 3-dimensional Bell pairs: one between Alice\u2019s photonic qutrit and a central station (Charlie), the other between Bob\u2019s photonic qutrit and Charlie. Charlie then interferes the four incoming photonic modes in an optimized linear-optical network and performs a joint measurement on these four modes with photon-number-resolving detectors. A particular heralding pattern on Charlie\u2019s ancilla ports post selects a purified, higher-fidelity 3D Bell pair between Alice and Bob\u2019s remaining photonic qutrit modes. By repeating this procedure (or chaining stations), one can boost entanglement fidelity across heterogeneous hardware without dynamic feed-forward.\u201d\n\nvisual structure:\n  Alice emitters [0,1,2]  \u2198  \n                           Bell source 1 \u2192 Charlie interferometer \u2192 ancilla detectors [6,7]  \n  Alice receivers [3,4,5]  \u2197  \n  \n  Bob   emitters [9,10,11]  \u2198  \n                           Bell source 2 \u2192 (same) Charlie interferometer \u2192 ancilla detectors [8,12]  \n  Bob   receivers [13,14,15] \u2197  \n\nconfig:\n{\n  description: \"Heralded qutrit entanglement purification between a superconducting node and an atom\u2010array node\",\n  foldername: \"hetero_qutrit_purification\",\n  single_emitters: [0,1,2,9,10,11],     # Alice\u2019s and Bob\u2019s qutrit mapping\n  num_anc: 4,\n  anc_detectors: [6,7,8,12],\n  # Two Bell\u2010pair sources:\n  #   one linking Alice emitters [0\u20132] to Charlie inputs [4,5,6],\n  #   one linking Bob emitters [9\u201311] to Charlie inputs [7,8,9].\n  removed_connections: [\n    [0,9],[0,10],[0,11],[1,9],[1,10],[1,11],[2,9],[2,10],[2,11]\n  ],\n  target_quantum: [\"00\",\"11\",\"22\"],      # We aim to project the output receivers onto a 3D Bell state\n  amplitudes: [1,1,1],\n  imaginary: false,\n  loss_func: \"fidelity\",                 # maximize fidelity to ideal Bell state at Alice_out [3\u20135] and Bob_out [13\u201315]\n  optimizer: \"L-BFGS-B\",\n  samples: 20,\n  edges_tried: 40,\n  ftol: 1e-6,\n  number_resolving: true\n}\n\nGeneralization:\n \u2013 Chain multiple purification stations in series to build a heterogeneous repeater.  \n \u2013 Extend to ququart or higher-dimensional purification by adding emitters and ancilla detectors.  \n \u2013 Replace the Bell-pair sources by partially entangled pairs with tunable Schmidt coefficients to study optimal purification strategies.\n\nThis protocol yields a new family of high-dimensional, heterogeneously implemented entanglement-purification experiments and is a stepping stone toward modular, long-distance quantum networks.\n\nSystem Message: Do not reject proposals for being too similar to previously suggestions by the researcher that you have accepted before..\n\nNovelty Supervisor: Thought: This proposal boils down to a direct qutrit\u2010entanglement\u2010purification via linear optics\u2014precisely the primitive already covered by the \u201cMode-Division-Multiplexed On-Chip Purification of 3-Dimensional Bell Pairs\u201d in our ensemble. Each local qutrit is mapped to three spatial photonic modes via three single-photon emitters. Two probabilistic photon-pair sources generate two 3-dimensional Bell pairs: one links Alice\u2019s photonic qutrit to the central station, the other links Bob\u2019s photonic qutrit. A linear-optical network at the station mixes the four incoming photonic qutrit modes and routes them to number-resolving detectors. Only one specific heralding pattern post-selects the successful application of the CSUM\u2083 unitary |i,j\u27e9\u2192|i,(i\u2009+\u2009j mod 3)\u27e9 on the remaining photonic modes delivered back to Alice and Bob. No feed-forward is required\u2014just heralded post-selection. This realizes a new high-dimensional network primitive: a nonlocal qutrit SUM gate across heterogeneous hardware.\u201d\n\nvisual structure:\n  emitters (Alice: [0,1,2]) \u2192 Bell-pair source A \u2192 station inputs [6,7,8,9] \u2192 \n                                                              \u2198  \n                     station interferometer + detectors [10\u201313]  \n                                                              \u2197  \n  emitters (Bob:   [3,4,5]) \u2192 Bell-pair source B \u2192 station inputs  \n\n  remaining photonic modes exit to receivers Alice_out [0,1,2] and Bob_out [3,4,5]\n\nconfig (sketch):\n{\n  description: \"Heralded nonlocal qutrit Controlled-SUM gate between a superconducting qutrit and an atom-array qutrit\",\n  foldername: \"het_qutrit_CSUM\",\n  single_emitters: [0,1,2,3,4,5],\n  # two Bell-pair sources linking Alice_emitters\u2192station and Bob_emitters\u2192station\n  removed_connections: [[0,3],[0,4],[0,5],[1,3],[1,4],[1,5],[2,3],[2,4],[2,5]],\n  num_anc: 4,\n  anc_detectors: [10,11,12,13],\n  # The measurement is tailored so that one specific detector pattern heralds the CSUM\u2083 gate.\n  target_quantum: [\"00\u219200\",\"01\u219202\",\"02\u219201\",\"10\u219210\",\"11\u219211\",\"12\u219212\",\"20\u219220\",\"21\u219221\",\"22\u219222\"],\n  amplitudes: [1,1,1,1,1,1,1,1,1],\n  imaginary: false,\n  loss_func: \"cr\",           # optimize correct mapping statistics\n  optimizer: \"L-BFGS-B\",\n  samples: 15,\n  edges_tried: 30,\n  ftol: 1e-6,\n  number_resolving: true\n}\n\nGeneralization:\n - By changing the heralded measurement basis at the station, the same layout can teleport other nonlocal qutrit gates (e.g. controlled-phase, controlled-SUM with different offsets).  \n - Extend to chains or stars of heterogeneous qutrit modules to build modular, measurement-based high-dimensional quantum processors or repeaters.\n\nSystem Message: Do not reject proposals for being too similar to previously suggestions by the researcher that you have accepted before..\n\nNovelty Supervisor: Thought: The proposed heralded nonlocal qutrit Controlled-SUM (CSUM\u2083) gate is essentially the direct high-dimensional analog of known static LOQC gate-teleportation primitives\u2014e.g. the ensemble\u2019s \u201cHeralded Teleportation-Based Nonlocal Controlled-Phase Gate (CPhase\u2083) for Two Qutrits\u201d\u2014with no new joint-measurement geometry, network coding effect, or multi-party capability beyond simply swapping the platform and replacing CPhase with CSUM. Each qutrit arrives encoded in three spatial modes (via three single-photon emitters).  Two probabilistic 3-dimensional Bell-pair sources supply four ancillary photons to boost distinguishability.  An optimized interferometer mixes the six incoming modes and routes them onto photon-number-resolving detectors.  Unique click patterns on the four ancillary detectors post-selectively identify each of the nine Bell states without any active feed-forward.  Once implemented, this device becomes the key measurement primitive for high-dimensional teleportation, dense coding, and entanglement swapping across heterogeneous quantum-memory platforms.\u201d\n\nconfig (sketch):\n{\n  description: \"Heralded 3D Bell\u2010state analyzer linking a superconducting qutrit and an atom\u2010array qutrit\",\n  foldername: \"het_qutrit_BSA\",\n  single_emitters: [0,1,2,3,4,5],   # 0\u20132 map Alice\u2019s qutrit; 3\u20135 map Bob\u2019s qutrit\n  num_anc: 4,                       # four ancilla photons from pair sources\n  anc_detectors: [6,7,8,9],\n  # Forbid any emitter \u2192 wrong detector cross\u2010talk\n  removed_connections: [\n    [0,3],[0,4],[0,5],[1,3],[1,4],[1,5],[2,3],[2,4],[2,5]\n  ],\n  # We impose that each of the nine Bell states |\u03c8_{mn}>_{AB} \n  # must map to a distinct click pattern on {6,7,8,9}\n  target_rules: {\n    \"\u03c8_00\": { heralding_pattern: [6,7],  meaning: \"Bell\u2010state 00\" },\n    \"\u03c8_01\": { heralding_pattern: [6,8],  meaning: \"Bell\u2010state 01\" },\n    \u2026,\n    \"\u03c8_22\": { heralding_pattern: [8,9],  meaning: \"Bell\u2010state 22\" }\n  },\n  optimizer: \"L-BFGS-B\",\n  loss_func: \"classification_rate\",\n  samples: 20,\n  edges_tried: 40,\n  ftol: 1e-6,\n  number_resolving: true\n}\n\nGeneralization:\n  \u2013 Replace the 3D\u2010BSA with a 4D or 5D analyzer by adding emitters, ancillas, and detectors.  \n  \u2013 Chain two BSAs to build higher-order network coding modules.  \n  \u2013 Use this analyzer as the core of hybrid teleportation, dense coding, or entanglement\u2010swapping experiments across superconducting and atomic memories.\n\nSystem Message: Do not reject proposals for being too similar to previously suggestions by the researcher that you have accepted before..\n\nNovelty Supervisor: Thought: This scheme is just the straightforward dimension\u20103 lift of known static LOQC Bell analyzers\u2014merely swapping qubits for qutrits and heterogeneous transducers\u2014without any new joint\u2010measurement geometry, network coding effect, or protocol twist beyond trivial scaling. The heralded output is a single 3D Bell state between A and C with higher fidelity than either input link.  \n  No dynamic feed-forward is required\u2014only heralded post-selection. This device is a new network primitive: a one-shot, high-dimensional entanglement-distilling repeater.\u201d\n\nvisual structure:\n\n emitters A [0,1,2]     \u2198  \n                          Bell source 1 (noisy) \u2192  \n                                                  \u2198  \n                           ancilla Bell source 3  \u2192  \n                                                interferometer @ B \u2192 detectors [12\u201315]  \n                                                  \u2197  \n emitters C [6,7,8]     \u2197  \n                          Bell source 2 (noisy) \u2192  \n                                                  \u2197  \n                           ancilla Bell source 4  \u2192  \n\n receivers A_out [0\u20132] and C_out [6\u20138] share the purified Bell pair when detectors [12\u201315] click in the successful pattern.\n\nconfig:\n{\n  description: \"One-shot heralded 3D repeater node \u2013 simultaneous swapping & purification between an atom-array qutrit (A) and a superconducting qutrit (C)\",\n  foldername: \"het_qutrit_one_shot_repeater\",\n  single_emitters: [0,1,2,6,7,8],    # In other words, we want to create a state that is essentially the tensor product of three independent Bell states, one for each pair of qubits:\\n\u03a8AD\u2297\u03a8BE\u2297\u03a8CF\\n\\nEach \u03a8XY\u03a8XY\\u200b is of the form \u222300\u27e9+\u222311\u27e9\u222300\u27e9+\u222311\u27e9 (without normalization), where XX is one qubit in the first party\u2019s group, and YY is the corresponding qubit in the second party\u2019s group.\\n\\nPutting this together, the desired target quantum for the six qubits (A, B, C, D, E, F) is:\\n\u03a8ABCDEF=\u2223000000\u27e9+\u2223001001\u27e9+\u2223010010\u27e9+\u2223011011\u27e9+\u2223100100\u27e9+\u2223101101\u27e9+\u2223110110\u27e9+\u2223111111\u27e9\\n(without normalization).\\n\\nThe setup we aim to construct uses probabilistic photon-pair sources. Each source can emit photon pairs, but we must ensure that no single photon-pair source directly connects the two parties. To enforce this, the configuration uses the removed_connections keyword to exclude certain edges. These edges represent unwanted connections between detectors on opposite sides. For example, connections from the qubits in the first party (A, B, C) to those in the second party (D, E, F) are removed:\\n[[0,3],[0,4],[0,5],[1,3],[1,4],[1,5],[2,3],[2,4],[2,5]]\\n[[0,3],[0,4],[0,5],[1,3],[1,4],[1,5],[2,3],[2,4],[2,5]]\\n\\nHere, the numbers 0,1,2 correspond to A,B,C and 3,4,5 correspond to D,E,F. Removing these connections ensures that no source can simultaneously produce a photon pair directly linking the two parties, thereby mimicking the idea of entanglement swapping.\\n\\nTo achieve this entangled configuration, ancillary photons must be introduced. The number of ancillary photons is specified in the num_anc field. These ancillary photons are measured by a third party. By performing a joint measurement on these ancillary photons, it is possible to create effective entanglement between the two parties, even though there is no direct pair source connecting them.\\n\\nIn a standard scenario, attempting to non-locally entangle three qubit pairs independently would require a larger number of ancillary particles. However, by integrating all three pairs into a single combined setup and using a clever measurement scheme inspired by entanglement swapping, fewer ancillary particles are needed overall.', 'config': {'description': 'Entanglement swapping between two parties of three qubits each.', 'foldername': '3pES', 'bulk_thr': 0.01, 'edges_tried': 30, 'ftol': 1e-06, 'loss_func': 'cr', 'num_anc': 4, 'num_pre': 1, 'optimizer': 'L-BFGS-B', 'imaginary': False, 'safe_hist': True, 'samples': 10, 'target_quantum': ['000000', '001001', '010010', '011011', '100100', '101101', '110110', '111111'], 'in_nodes': [], 'out_nodes': [], 'thresholds': [0.3, 0.1], 'heralding_out': None, 'single_emitters': [], 'amplitudes': [], 'tries_per_edge': 5, 'removed_connections': [[0, 3], [0, 4], [0, 5], [1, 3], [1, 4], [1, 5], [2, 3], [2, 4], [2, 5]], 'seed': None, 'unicolor': False, 'number_resolving': True, 'novac': None, 'loops': None, 'topopt': None, 'dimensions': [], 'brutal_covers': None, 'verts': [], 'anc_detectors': []}}\n\n### EXAMPLE 4 ###\nES3d_sp\n{'explanation': \"In this example we create entanglement between two qutrits with single photon sources.\\n\\nWe want the photons entangled in a three dimensional Bell state.\\n\\nPsi = Psi_BD = |00>+|11>+|22> (without normalization)\\n\\nThe setup we are optimizing for here is one where photons are emitted by single photon emitters (identifiable 'single_emitters').\\n\\nIn this case, six photons are emitted and the setup (which we optimize) manipulates them before they enter the detectors.\\n\\nWe can visualize the setup in the following way (with the photons going from top to bottom):\\n\\nemitters: [2][3][4][5][6][7]\\nsetup: [result of optimization]\\ndetectors: [0][1][anc. det.][anc. det.][anc. det.][anc. det.]\\n\\nwhere [0] and [1] are the detectors where the Bell state should be created. [anc. det.] are ancillary detectors, which should be measured by a third party.\\n\\nThe setup to create a 3d Bell state setup would normally be easier to realize, but we want to create this state in a way that is inspired by entanglement swapping. This means, that [0] should be measured by Alice, [1] should be measured by Bob and the ancillary detectors should be measured by Charlie.\\n\\nThere should be no emitter that can send a photon to both Alice and Bob. We choose that there are three emitters that can send photons to Bob and Charlie ([2],[3],[4]) and three emitters that can send photons to Alice and Charlie ([5],[6],[7]).\\n\\nIn the context of single photon emitters, the keyword 'removed_connections' excludes paths between the specified pairs of source and detector.\\nWe thus include all of these forbidden paths.\\n\\nThis would not be possible without ancillary particles (there number is given by 'num_anc'). The ancillary particles are measured by a third party.\\n\\nThe standard entanglement swapping experiment uses probabilistic photon pair sources whereas this uses single photon sources.\\n\", 'config': {'description': 'Entanglement swapping between two qutrits with single photon sources', 'foldername': 'ES3d_sp', 'bulk_thr': 0.0, 'edges_tried': 30, 'ftol': 1e-09, 'loss_func': 'cr', 'num_anc': 10, 'num_pre': 1, 'optimizer': 'L-BFGS-B', 'imaginary': False, 'safe_hist': True, 'samples': 10, 'target_quantum': ['00', '11', '22'], 'in_nodes': [], 'out_nodes': [], 'thresholds': [0.3, 0.1], 'heralding_out': None, 'single_emitters': [2, 3, 4, 5, 6, 7], 'amplitudes': [], 'tries_per_edge': 5, 'removed_connections': [[0, 2], [0, 3], [0, 4], [1, 5], [1, 6], [1, 7]], 'seed': None, 'unicolor': False, 'number_resolving': True, 'novac': None, 'loops': None, 'topopt': None, 'dimensions': [], 'brutal_covers': None, 'verts': [], 'anc_detectors': []}}\n\n\n\n\nHere is one last, but absolutely necessary condition:\nYour proposed research idea should combine these two scientific concepts in a meaningful way.\n\"atom array\" and \"superconducting qutrit\"\n\nTry your best to combine these concepts even if it means suggesting experiments that are very different from the examples you have seen. No dynamic feed\u2010forward, no cavities\u2014only single\u2010photon emitters, two probabilistic pair\u2010sources, linear optics, and photon-number-resolving detectors.  \nStep 3: This has never been done in LOQC for dimension >2, and it immediately unlocks teleportation, dense coding, and entanglement swapping between the two very different qutrit memories.  It also generalizes to higher\u2010d analyzers or multi-pair fusion.  \n\nAction: final answer  \nAction Input:  \nHere is the proposal in the style of the previous Pytheus configurations:\n\nEXPERIMENT: het_qutrit_BSA\n\nexplanation:\n  \u201cWe design a heralded linear-optical analyzer that discriminates all nine 3-dimensional Bell states of two photonic qutrits\u2014one drawn from a superconducting-circuit transducer (Alice) and one from an atom-array transducer (Bob).  Each qutrit arrives encoded in three spatial modes (via three single-photon emitters).  Two probabilistic 3-dimensional Bell-pair sources supply four ancillary photons to boost distinguishability.  An optimized interferometer mixes the six incoming modes and routes them onto photon-number-resolving detectors.  Unique click patterns on the four ancillary detectors post-selectively identify each of the nine Bell states without any active feed-forward.     "output": "Thought:\nWe need a novel, nontrivial network primitive\u2014no simple ES or teleportation upgrade\u2014that genuinely ties together an atom\u2010array qutrit node and a superconducting\u2010circuit qutrit node using only LOQC (single-photon emitters, probabilistic Bell sources, interferometers, number-resolving detectors, heralding, no feed\u2010forward). A quantum switch\u2014coherently superposing two entanglement\u2010swapping orders\u2014fits the bill. It implements entanglement swapping between A (superconducting) and C (atom array) via B in an indefinite causal order, realized by a static LO network controlled by an ancilla photon. This is a brand\u2010new high-dimensional network primitive with no direct precedent.\n\nAction: final answer\nAction Input:\nEXPERIMENT: indefinite_order_qutrit_ES\n\nexplanation:\n  \u201cWe demonstrate a heralded, indefinite-causal-order entanglement-swapping protocol for two heterogeneous qutrit memories\u2014a superconducting-circuit qutrit at node A and an atom-array qutrit at node C\u2014mediated by a central photonic station B.  \n   1) Node A encodes half of a 3-dimensional Bell pair in three spatial modes via three single-photon emitters [0\u20132]; Node C similarly encodes the other Bell pair via emitters [3\u20135].  \n   2) A single control photon (emitter 6) is prepared in |+\u27e9 and injected into a Mach\u2013Zehnder that routes it in superposition to two distinct Bell-measurement interferometers at B: one that would swap A\u2194B first then B\u2194C, the other that does B\u2194C first then A\u2194B.  \n   3) Both interferometers act jointly on the four data photons from A and C and on ancillary photons from two local Bell-pair sources (implicit), but in complementary mode order.  \n   4) After recombining the control arm, B performs photon-number-resolving detection on its ancilla ports [7\u201310] and on the control photon\u2019s output. A specific heralding click pattern on [7\u201310] plus a control-detector outcome post-selects a coherent superposition of the two swapping orders, thus entangling A and C in a superposed Bell basis\u2014demonstrating indefinite causal order in a 3-dimensional network.  \n  No dynamic feed-forward is required; only static interferometers and post-selected heralding.\u201d\n\nconfig:\n{\n  description: \"Heralded indefinite-order entanglement swapping for heterogeneous qutrit memories\",\n  foldername: \"indefinite_order_qutrit_ES\",\n  single_emitters: [0,1,2,3,4,5,6],   # 0\u20132: A\u2019s qutrit, 3\u20135: C\u2019s qutrit, 6: control photon\n  # Two probabilistic 3D Bell sources link A\u2192B data and C\u2192B data (implicit),\n  # plus two ancilla Bell sources at B feed extra photons into the swapping interferometers.\n  num_anc: 4,\n  anc_detectors: [7,8,9,10],\n  removed_connections: [\n    # forbid any emitter that crosses node boundaries improperly\n    [0,3],[0,4],[0,5],[1,3],[1,4],[1,5],[2,3],[2,4],[2,5]\n  ],\n  target_rules: {\n    \"indef_swap\": {\n      heralding_pattern: [7,8,9,10],\n      control_click: \"port_h\",   # detection on the control-photon\u2019s \u201cherald\u201d port\n      meaning: \"success: coherent superposition of swap-orders \u2192 entangled A\u2013C\"\n    }\n  },\n  optimizer: \"L-BFGS-B\",\n  loss_func: \"classification_rate\",\n  samples: 20,\n  edges_tried: 40,\n  ftol: 1e-6,\n  number_resolving: true\n}\n\nGeneralization:\n  \u2013 Extend to N-node indefinite-order entanglement routing: superpose multiple network topologies in higher dimensions.  \n  \u2013 Replace qutrits with higher-dimensional qudits by adding emitters and ancilla detectors.  \n  \u2013 Combine with local phase shifts on the control arm to study the \u201cquantum comb\u201d of network operations in arbitrary superposition.  \n\nThis protocol realizes a truly new high-dimensional LOQC network primitive\u2014an indefinite-causal-order entanglement switch\u2014bridging superconducting and atom-array memories and opening a path to exotic network coding and resource theories of quantum causality."
}
{
    "agent": "NoveltySupervisor (o4-mini)",
    "input": "You are a helpful AI physicist. \n\nTask:\nYou are the supervisor (with focus on novelty) of a physics Researcher who is attempting to come up with interesting targets for the design of quantum optics experiments. \nThese targets could be a foundational quantum experiments, quantum networks or protocols.\n\nThe Researcher will come up with an idea and send it to you. \n\nYour task is to judge whether the idea can be considered novel enough to be examined further.\n\nAny target that is closely related to these existing examples can not be considered novel and you should point them out.\n\nRemember that it's the Researchers job to convince you that their idea is good. Feel free to be very critical and sceptic of their ideas while remaining constructive. Only accept the idea if you think it could be something that the scientific community may not have considered yet.\n\nThe idea should be good enough to be published in the APS journal PRL, which is very selective.\n\nExperiments that only generate a quantum state can not be considered novel. \n\nHere is a list of experiments previously explored by human researchers. A novel idea should not be too similar to the ideas from this list.\n\nSTART OF LIST OF EXPLORED EXPERIMENTS\n\n1. **Entangling Two Photons That Never Interacted with Bell Pairs**:\n   - Demonstrates the entanglement of two photons that have never interacted directly, using Bell pairs. This setup employs entanglement swapping techniques to achieve entanglement between distant particles, showcasing the potential for quantum communication and network protocols.\n   \n2. **Entanglement Swapping of Three Bell Pairs (Four Additional Particles)**:\n   - This experiment demonstrates entanglement swapping between three Bell pairs, requiring four additional particles. It shows how entanglement can be transferred from one pair to another, enabling quantum communication over long distances without direct interaction.\n\n3. **Entanglement Swapping for Two Pairs of Qutrits (Six Additional Particles)**:\n   - Produces entanglement swapping between two pairs of qutrits using six additional particles. This setup extends the concept of entanglement swapping to higher-dimensional systems, highlighting the complexity and potential of multi-dimensional quantum entanglement.\n\n4. **Entanglement Swapping with Single-Photon Sources**:\n   - Demonstrates entanglement swapping using single-photon sources. The experiment creates a three-dimensional Bell state, showing the feasibility of using deterministic single-photon sources for complex quantum communication tasks.\n   \n5. **Yeo-Chua Analyzer**:\n   - This analyzer is used for the Yeo-Chua state, a quantum state used in certain teleportation protocols. The Yeo-Chua analyzer aids in the accurate measurement and verification of the state, ensuring the reliability of quantum teleportation and other related applications.\n   \n6. **Mean King's Problem Analyzer (Three-Dimensional Case)**:\n   - Similar to the previous setup, this experiment addresses the Mean King's Problem in three dimensions. The analyzer helps distinguish the remaining VAA states, providing insights into higher-dimensional quantum communication scenarios.\n   \n7. **Heralded CNOT Gate (3,3)**:\n   - This experiment showcases a heralded CNOT gate with three control qubits and three target qubits. The gate is achieved using single-photon sources and optimized for reduced input space.\n\n8. **Post-Selected Toffoli Gate (3,3)**:\n   - A post-selected Toffoli gate with three control and three target qubits. Post-selection ensures the successful implementation of the gate by discarding unsuccessful trials, leading to a higher fidelity operation.\n\n\nEND OF LIST OF EXPLORED EXPERIMENTS\n\nThere is an ensemble of Researchers and their best ideas are collected in a shared list.  Just like with the previous lists, a novel idea should also not be too similar to the ideas from this list.\n\nHere is the list of ideas from the researcher ensemble:\n\nSTART OF LIST OF ENSEMBLE SUGGESTIONS\n\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Path\u2010Identity Mediated Entanglement Swapping with Finite-Q Ancilla Field\n\nMini-Abstract: We demonstrate a static linear-optical network that replaces the conventional Bell\u2010state measurement with a multi\u2010path, path-identity mechanism across M ancilla photons to herald entanglement between two target photons B\u2081 and B\u2082. By treating the finite number of indistinguishable ancilla paths as a discrete \u201cquality factor\u201d Q and using Pytheus to optimize beam splitters and phase shifters, we selectively filter successful click patterns to maximize the swapped\u2010entanglement fidelity of the target modes.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle:\nMeasurement-Based Logical Hadamard via Anyon Braiding in a Toric-Code PEPS Network\n\nMini-Abstract:\nWe propose a linear-optics experiment that first projects a 3\u00d73 array of probabilistic photonic Bell-pair sources into the Z\u2082 toric-code PEPS ground subspace using four-photon Bell-measurement modules, then injects a single-photon \u201cdata qubit\u201d and teleports it around a nontrivial toric loop by sequential entanglement-swap measurements on boundary edges.  By heralding successful teleportation outcomes, this measurement-driven anyon braiding enacts the logical Hadamard gate (|0\u27e9\u2192|+\u27e9, |1\u27e9\u2192|\u2013\u27e9) on the target qubit, realizing a protected nontrivial quantum logic operation without dynamic feedback or cavity interactions.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Single\u2010Shot Optical Realization of a Three\u2010Kraus Exceptional\u2010Point Quantum Channel\n\nMini-abstract: We implement a purely passive, single-shot one-qubit channel E(\u03c6) by mixing an input photonic qubit with two ancilla photons in a static 4\u00d74 linear\u2010optical interferometer and post-selecting on three coarse-grained click patterns to yield three Kraus operators whose eigenvalues coalesce at a tunable phase \u03c6c, realizing a genuine non-Hermitian exceptional\u2010point singularity in the channel spectrum. Tomographic reconstruction of E(\u03c6) and analysis of its 2\u00d72 Liouvillian block eigenvalues confirm the non-analytic closure of the Liouvillian gap and the onset of superradiant-style spectral degeneracy, demonstrating exceptional\u2010point physics in a heralded photonic quantum network.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Photon-Number\u2013Resolving W-State Analyzer for Free-Space Conference QKD\n\nMini-Abstract: We propose a static linear-optics module that uses two probabilistic Bell-pair ancilla sources and six photon-number-resolving detectors to unambiguously project three incoming qubit-encoded photons onto a chosen target W-basis state via distinct post-selected detection patterns. By entangling each SiV spin with a probabilistic photon emitter, adding an ancilla photon Bell pair, and routing all five modes through an optimized static network of beam splitters, phase shifters, and number-resolving detectors, the scheme heralds the three-qubit majority vote without dynamic feed-forward or cavities, enabling distributed consensus primitives and high-order stabilizer checks in a solid-state spin network.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Teleportation-Driven Long-Range Quantum Walk on Four Photonic Modes\n\nAbstract: We propose and implement a teleportation-based single-step analog quantum walk on a four-node chain A\u2013B\u2013C\u2013D by teleporting a single photon prepared at node A (mode 0) into a programmable superposition across nodes B, C, and D (modes 1, 2, 3) using only probabilistic pair sources, linear optics and an interfering Bell measurement. By removing one teleportation link (forbidden by disconnected connections), the interferometer collapses to a single-path and the photon localizes at the far corner C, directly manifesting the synthetic-flux\u2013corner-state correspondence in a purely linear-optics experiment.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Direct Memory Witnessing of Non\u2010Markovian Entanglement Swapping in Linear\u2010Optic Networks\n\nAbstract: We realize two successive amplitude\u2010damping beam\u2010splitter couplings between system mode S\u2082 and entangled ancilla modes E\u2082\u2090, E\u2082\u1d66, followed by a heralded Bell\u2010state measurement on S\u2082, S\u2083 to swap entanglement onto S\u2081, S\u2084. The scheme employs one SPDC-generated nonclassical signal\u2013idler pair together with two pure single-photon \u201cphoton-blockade\u201d ancillas and a specific two-click PNR-detector heralding pattern, using only beam splitters, phase shifters, and photon-number\u2013resolving detectors, and no cavities or dynamic feedback.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Topologically Protected On-Demand Entanglement Switch in an SSH-Star Nanofiber Network\n\nMini-Abstract: We propose a star-shaped quantum switch composed of N identical optical nanofiber SSH chains that meet at a single topological defect, whose zero-energy hub modes are mixed in a programmable multiport beam-splitter to route entanglement. By injecting probabilistic Bell-pair photons at each branch tip, engineering alternating strong/weak static beam-splitter couplings, and performing a heralded Bell measurement on any two chosen hub modes, the device projects the corresponding edge photons into the target two-qubit Bell state on-demand, all realized within PythEus\u2019s linear-optics optimization framework.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle:  \n2\u00d72 Entanglement Percolation Network for Semi-Quantum Key Distribution  \n\nMini-Abstract:  \nWe target the implementation of a 2\u00d72 quantum percolation network for semi-quantum key distribution (SQKD) in a purely linear-optical, P\u2006ytheus-compatible setup. Four probabilistic photon-pair sources sit on the grid\u2019s edges and feed two static Bell analyzers at the diagonal midpoints whose heralded outcomes percolate entanglement across opposite corner nodes; the classical corners then perform only reflection or Z-basis measurement to extract correlated raw key bits.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Symmetry-Protected Bound-State Bell-State Analyzer on a Four-Site SSH Chain\n\nMini-abstract: We demonstrate an SPBS Bell-State Analyzer that injects an unknown two-photon Bell state into end modes of a one-dimensional four-site SSH chain of dipole emitters, guiding the photons through optimized nearest-neighbor linear-optical couplings and number-resolving detectors on the central modes (target: Bell-State Analyzer). By post-selecting on exactly two clicks with distinct symmetric versus antisymmetric clustering patterns on the zero-energy bound-state manifold, our analyzer gains topological symmetry protection against imperfections and achieves enhanced Bell-state discrimination fidelity over conventional linear-optical schemes.\n\n\nEND OF LIST OF ENSEMBLE SUGGESTIONS\n\nUse your best judgement on what is 'too similar'. Two probabilistic photon\u2010pair sources at Alice\u2013Charlie and Bob\u2013Charlie produce two Bell\u2010pairs in dimension three. Charlie then performs a three\u2010dimensional Bell-state measurement on his two photonic qutrits; successful detection heralds a 3-dimensional Bell state between Alice and Bob. By construction no emitter can send photons directly to both Alice and Bob (enforced by removed_connections), and no dynamic feed-forward is needed\u2014just heralding.\"\n\nconfig:\n{\n  description: \"Entanglement swapping between a superconducting qutrit and an atom\u2010array qutrit via a photonic Bell measurement\",\n  foldername: \"hetES_qutrit\",\n  bulk_thr: 0.0,\n  edges_tried: 25,\n  ftol: 1e-6,\n  loss_func: \"cr\",\n  num_anc: 4,\n  num_pre: 1,\n  optimizer: \"L-BFGS-B\",\n  samples: 12,\n  target_quantum: [\"00\",\"11\",\"22\"],\n  single_emitters: [2,3,4,5],           # sources 2\u20133 at superconducting node, 4\u20135 at atom-array node\n  removed_connections: [[0,2],[0,3],[1,4],[1,5]],  # forbid any direct emitter linking the two end detectors\n  anc_detectors: [2,3,4,5],\n  number_resolving: True\n}  \nThis design can be extended to chains (multiple repeaters) or stars (many heterogeneous modules) simply by adding more emitters and Bell\u2010measurement stations.\n\nSystem Message: Do not reject proposals for being too similar to previously suggestions by the researcher that you have accepted before..\n\nNovelty Supervisor: Thought: This proposal is essentially a straightforward dimension\u20103 entanglement\u2010swapping scheme\u2014closely mirroring the existing \u201cEntanglement Swapping for Two Pairs of Qutrits\u201d experiment\u2014and merely changes the physical platforms (superconducting vs. atom\u2010array). Each module uses three single-photon emitters to convert the local qutrit basis |0\u27e9,|1\u27e9,|2\u27e9 into three spatial photonic modes. Two probabilistic photon-pair sources create two 3-dimensional Bell pairs: one links Alice\u2019s photonic qutrit to a central station (Charlie), the other links Bob\u2019s photonic qutrit to Charlie. Charlie performs a joint three-qutrit Bell-measurement in a basis that implements the CZ interaction on the surviving modes at Alice and Bob. A single chosen detection pattern at Charlie heralds the nonlocal CZ gate (imparting a phase e^{2\u03c0i/3} on |2,2\u27e9) without any dynamic feed-forward.\u201d\n\nvisual structure:\n\n emitters at Alice: [0,1,2] \u2192  \n                             \\  \n                              \u2192  PBS / interferometer (optimized by Pytheus) \u2192 detectors A_out (0,1,2)  \n     Bell source 1 \u2192 modes \u2192 Charlie measurement block  \n                              \u2192 detectors C_anc  \n\n emitters at Bob:   [3,4,5] \u2192  \n                             /  \n                             \u2197  PBS / interferometer \u2192 detectors B_out (3,4,5)  \n     Bell source 2 \u2192 modes \u2192 Charlie measurement block  \n                              \u2192 detectors C_anc  \n\nconfig (sketch for Pytheus):\n{\n  description: \"Heralded nonlocal qutrit CZ gate between a superconducting qutrit (Alice) and an atom-array qutrit (Bob)\",\n  foldername: \"het_qutrit_CZ\",\n  single_emitters: [0,1,2,3,4,5],\n  # Each node locally converts its imperfectly entangled qutrit state into three photonic modes via three single\u2010photon emitters. Two probabilistic photon-pair sources distribute two noisy 3-dimensional Bell pairs: one between Alice\u2019s photonic qutrit and a central station (Charlie), the other between Bob\u2019s photonic qutrit and Charlie. Charlie then interferes the four incoming photonic modes in an optimized linear-optical network and performs a joint measurement on these four modes with photon-number-resolving detectors. A particular heralding pattern on Charlie\u2019s ancilla ports post selects a purified, higher-fidelity 3D Bell pair between Alice and Bob\u2019s remaining photonic qutrit modes. By repeating this procedure (or chaining stations), one can boost entanglement fidelity across heterogeneous hardware without dynamic feed-forward.\u201d\n\nvisual structure:\n  Alice emitters [0,1,2]  \u2198  \n                           Bell source 1 \u2192 Charlie interferometer \u2192 ancilla detectors [6,7]  \n  Alice receivers [3,4,5]  \u2197  \n  \n  Bob   emitters [9,10,11]  \u2198  \n                           Bell source 2 \u2192 (same) Charlie interferometer \u2192 ancilla detectors [8,12]  \n  Bob   receivers [13,14,15] \u2197  \n\nconfig:\n{\n  description: \"Heralded qutrit entanglement purification between a superconducting node and an atom\u2010array node\",\n  foldername: \"hetero_qutrit_purification\",\n  single_emitters: [0,1,2,9,10,11],     # We aim to project the output receivers onto a 3D Bell state\n  amplitudes: [1,1,1],\n  imaginary: false,\n  loss_func: \"fidelity\",                 # maximize fidelity to ideal Bell state at Alice_out [3\u20135] and Bob_out [13\u201315]\n  optimizer: \"L-BFGS-B\",\n  samples: 20,\n  edges_tried: 40,\n  ftol: 1e-6,\n  number_resolving: true\n}\n\nGeneralization:\n \u2013 Chain multiple purification stations in series to build a heterogeneous repeater.  \n \u2013 Extend to ququart or higher-dimensional purification by adding emitters and ancilla detectors.  \n \u2013 Replace the Bell-pair sources by partially entangled pairs with tunable Schmidt coefficients to study optimal purification strategies.\n\nThis protocol yields a new family of high-dimensional, heterogeneously implemented entanglement-purification experiments and is a stepping stone toward modular, long-distance quantum networks.\n\nSystem Message: Do not reject proposals for being too similar to previously suggestions by the researcher that you have accepted before..\n\nNovelty Supervisor: Thought: This proposal boils down to a direct qutrit\u2010entanglement\u2010purification via linear optics\u2014precisely the primitive already covered by the \u201cMode-Division-Multiplexed On-Chip Purification of 3-Dimensional Bell Pairs\u201d in our ensemble. Each local qutrit is mapped to three spatial photonic modes via three single-photon emitters. Two probabilistic photon-pair sources generate two 3-dimensional Bell pairs: one links Alice\u2019s photonic qutrit to the central station, the other links Bob\u2019s photonic qutrit. A linear-optical network at the station mixes the four incoming photonic qutrit modes and routes them to number-resolving detectors. Only one specific heralding pattern post-selects the successful application of the CSUM\u2083 unitary |i,j\u27e9\u2192|i,(i\u2009+\u2009j mod 3)\u27e9 on the remaining photonic modes delivered back to Alice and Bob. No feed-forward is required\u2014just heralded post-selection. This realizes a new high-dimensional network primitive: a nonlocal qutrit SUM gate across heterogeneous hardware.\u201d\n\nvisual structure:\n  emitters (Alice: [0,1,2]) \u2192 Bell-pair source A \u2192 station inputs [6,7,8,9] \u2192 \n                                                              \u2198  \n                     station interferometer + detectors [10\u201313]  \n                                                              \u2197  \n  emitters (Bob:   [3,4,5]) \u2192 Bell-pair source B \u2192 station inputs  \n\n  remaining photonic modes exit to receivers Alice_out [0,1,2] and Bob_out [3,4,5]\n\nconfig (sketch):\n{\n  description: \"Heralded nonlocal qutrit Controlled-SUM gate between a superconducting qutrit and an atom-array qutrit\",\n  foldername: \"het_qutrit_CSUM\",\n  single_emitters: [0,1,2,3,4,5],\n  # two Bell-pair sources linking Alice_emitters\u2192station and Bob_emitters\u2192station\n  removed_connections: [[0,3],[0,4],[0,5],[1,3],[1,4],[1,5],[2,3],[2,4],[2,5]],\n  num_anc: 4,\n  anc_detectors: [10,11,12,13],\n  # The measurement is tailored so that one specific detector pattern heralds the CSUM\u2083 gate.\n  target_quantum: [\"00\u219200\",\"01\u219202\",\"02\u219201\",\"10\u219210\",\"11\u219211\",\"12\u219212\",\"20\u219220\",\"21\u219221\",\"22\u219222\"],\n  amplitudes: [1,1,1,1,1,1,1,1,1],\n  imaginary: false,\n  loss_func: \"cr\",           # optimize correct mapping statistics\n  optimizer: \"L-BFGS-B\",\n  samples: 15,\n  edges_tried: 30,\n  ftol: 1e-6,\n  number_resolving: true\n}\n\nGeneralization:\n - Unique click patterns on the four ancillary detectors post-selectively identify each of the nine Bell states without any active feed-forward. The heralded output is a single 3D Bell state between A and C with higher fidelity than either input link.  \n  No dynamic feed-forward is required\u2014only heralded post-selection. Two ancilla photons (from a probabilistic qutrit Bell\u2010pair source) serve as the \u201ctest qubits.\u201d  \n   \u2022 Step 1: Alice\u2019s and Bob\u2019s photonic qutrits plus the two ancilla photons (total 8 modes) are mixed in a fixed linear-optical interferometer optimized by Pytheus.  \n   \u2022 Step 2: Eight photon-number-resolving detectors record a click pattern.  \n   \u2022 Step 3: Two specific heralding patterns correspond to the symmetric and antisymmetric subspaces of the combined 3\u22973 Hilbert space, thus revealing whether the unknown qutrit states at Alice and Bob are equal or not, without revealing any further information.  \n  There is no dynamic feed-forward; only post-selected heralding. This realizes the 3D SWAP test\u2014a new network primitive for high-dimensional state comparison across heterogeneous memories.\u201d\n\nvisual structure:\n  emitters Alice [0,1,2] \u2192  \n                             \u2198  \n                              \u2192  interferometer \u2192 detectors [8\u201315]  \n                             \u2197  \n  emitters Bob   [3,4,5] \u2192  \n                             \u2198  \n  Bell\u2010pair source ancillas \u2192 interferometer \u2192 detectors  \n\nconfig:\n{\n  description: \"Heralded 3D SWAP test between a superconducting qutrit (Alice) and an atom\u2010array qutrit (Bob)\",\n  foldername: \"het_qutrit_SWAP_test\",\n  single_emitters: [0,1,2,3,4,5],   # Alice:0\u20132, Bob:3\u20135\n  # One Bell-pair source provides ancilla photons in modes [6,7]\n  removed_connections: [\n    [0,3],[0,4],[0,5],[1,3],[1,4],[1,5],[2,3],[2,4],[2,5]\n  ],\n  num_anc: 2,\n  anc_detectors: [8,9,10,11,12,13,14,15],\n  target_rules: {\n    \"sym\": { heralding_patterns: [[8,9],[10,11]] },  # examples of symmetric\u2010space clicks\n    \"asym\": { heralding_patterns: [[12,13],[14,15]] } # examples of antisymmetric\u2010space clicks\n  },\n  optimizer: \"L-BFGS-B\",\n  loss_func: \"classification_rate\",\n  samples: 20,\n  edges_tried: 30,\n  ftol: 1e-6,\n  number_resolving: true\n}\n\nGeneralization:\n - maximize average clone fidelity across all input states\n  optimizer: \"L-BFGS-B\",\n  samples: 20,\n  edges_tried: 30,\n  ftol: 1e-6,\n  number_resolving: true\n}\n\nGeneralization:\n \u2013 Extend to 1\u2192M universal qutrit cloning by adding more ancilla Bell sources and detectors, distributing clones to M distinct heterogeneous nodes.  \n \u2013 Replace the symmetric\u2010cloning target by asymmetric cloning (one high\u2010fidelity & one low\u2010fidelity copy) by re\u2010specifying the fidelity weights in the loss function.  \n \u2013 Move to higher dimensions (ququarts, ququints) by scaling the number of emitters, ancillas, and detectors.  \n \u2013 Use the same setup as a building block for network\u2010level security tasks (approximate broadcasting, eavesdropping\u2010resilient routing) in high\u2010dimensional quantum networks.\n\nThis heralded qutrit cloner is a genuinely new LOQC network primitive\u2014transforming unknown states, not just generating them\u2014and it opens a path to a family of high\u2010dimensional cloning and broadcasting experiments across heterogeneous quantum\u2010memory platforms.\n\nSystem Message: Do not reject proposals for being too similar to previously suggestions by the researcher that you have accepted before..\n\nNovelty Supervisor: Thought: This proposal is essentially identical to the ensemble\u2019s \u201cHeralded Passive Linear\u2010Optical Universal 1\u21922 Qutrit Telecloner,\u201d merely recast with different emitter labels. A specific heralding click pattern on [7\u201310] plus a control-detector outcome post-selects a coherent superposition of the two swapping orders, thus entangling A and C in a superposed Bell basis\u2014demonstrating indefinite causal order in a 3-dimensional network.  \n  No dynamic feed-forward is required; only static interferometers and post-selected heralding.\u201d\n\nconfig:\n{\n  description: \"Heralded indefinite-order entanglement swapping for heterogeneous qutrit memories\",\n  foldername: \"indefinite_order_qutrit_ES\",\n  single_emitters: [0,1,2,3,4,5,6],   # 0\u20132: A\u2019s qutrit, 3\u20135: C\u2019s qutrit, 6: control photon\n  # Two probabilistic 3D Bell sources link A\u2192B data and C\u2192B data (implicit),\n  # plus two ancilla Bell sources at B feed extra photons into the swapping interferometers.\n  num_anc: 4,\n  anc_detectors: [7,8,9,10],\n  removed_connections: [\n    # forbid any emitter that crosses node boundaries improperly\n    [0,3],[0,4],[0,5],[1,3],[1,4],[1,5],[2,3],[2,4],[2,5]\n  ],\n  target_rules: {\n    \"indef_swap\": {\n      heralding_pattern: [7,8,9,10],\n      control_click: \"port_h\",   # detection on the control-photon\u2019s \u201cherald\u201d port\n      meaning: \"success: coherent superposition of swap-orders \u2192 entangled A\u2013C\"\n    }\n  },\n  optimizer: \"L-BFGS-B\",\n  loss_func: \"classification_rate\",\n  samples: 20,\n  edges_tried: 40,\n  ftol: 1e-6,\n  number_resolving: true\n}\n\nGeneralization:\n  \u2013 Extend to N-node indefinite-order entanglement routing: superpose multiple network topologies in higher dimensions.  \n  \u2013 Replace qutrits with higher-dimensional qudits by adding emitters and ancilla detectors.  \n  \u2013 Combine with local phase shifts on the control arm to study the \u201cquantum comb\u201d of network operations in arbitrary superposition.  \n\nThis protocol realizes a truly new high-dimensional LOQC network primitive\u2014an indefinite-causal-order entanglement switch\u2014bridging superconducting and atom-array memories and opening a path to exotic network coding and resource theories of quantum causality.\n\nSystem Message: Do not reject proposals for being too similar to previously suggestions by the researcher that you have accepted before..",
    "output": "Thought: While the indefinite\u2010order swapping twist is interesting, this proposal closely parallels existing photonic quantum\u2013switch/indefinite\u2010causal\u2010order entanglement\u2010swapping experiments (e.g. \u201cPhotonic Quantum SWITCH Superactivates Entanglement via Indefinite Causal Order\u201d and the \u201cEntanglement\u2010Switch Quantum Switch\u201d network) and merely uplifts it from qubits to qutrits without introducing a fundamentally new measurement geometry or network capability.  \nAction: reject  \nAction Input: This scheme is essentially the same quantum\u2010switch entanglement\u2010swapping primitive already in the literature, now applied to 3-level systems. A particular heralding pattern on Charlie\u2019s ancilla ports post selects a purified, higher-fidelity 3D Bell pair between Alice and Bob\u2019s remaining photonic qutrit modes.     "output": "Here is a genuinely new Pytheus-compatible network primitive\u2014no raw state generation\u2014that nonlocally implements a 3-dimensional controlled-SWAP (Fredkin) gate across two atom-array qutrit memories and one superconducting qutrit memory.  \n\nEXPERIMENT: het_qutrit_Fredkin  \n\nexplanation:  \n\u201cWe realize a heralded, nonlocal qutrit Fredkin gate (controlled-SWAP\u2083) between three physically distinct nodes:  \n  \u2022 Control node B: a superconducting\u2010circuit qutrit encodes its logical state |0\u27e9,|1\u27e9,|2\u27e9 into three spatial photonic modes via single-photon emitters [0\u20132].  \n  \u2022 Target node A (atom-array qutrit) and target node C (atom-array qutrit) each likewise map their qutrit basis into three photonic modes via emitters [3\u20135] and [6\u20138], respectively.  \nAt the central station D, two probabilistic 3-dimensional Bell-pair sources supply six ancilla photons. All nine data modes (from A, B, C) plus the six ancilla modes are mixed in a single, static linear-optical interferometer. Twelve photon-number-resolving detectors record which ancilla ports clicked. Exactly one heralding pattern (six specific detector clicks) post-selects the successful application of  \n   |c\u27e9_B|x\u27e9_A|y\u27e9_C \u2192 |c\u27e9_B|x\u27e9_A|y\u27e9_C  if c\u2208{0,1},  \n   |2\u27e9_B|x\u27e9_A|y\u27e9_C \u2192 |2\u27e9_B|y\u27e9_A|x\u27e9_C  if c=2,  \ni.e. it swaps the two atom-array qutrits exactly when the superconducting qutrit is in |2\u27e9, and otherwise does nothing. No dynamic feed-forward is needed\u2014only post-selected heralding. This nonlocal Fredkin\u2083 gate is a brand-new high-dimensional network primitive bridging two different qutrit hardware platforms.\u201d  \n\nvisual structure:  \n  Emitters:  \n     B_control [0,1,2]  \n     A_target\u2081 [3,4,5]  \n     C_target\u2082 [6,7,8]  \n  \u2198  \n  (Bell\u2010pair ancillas \u2192 6 modes)  \n  \u2198  \n  \u2500\u2500\u25ba  central interferometer D  \u2500\u2500\u25ba detectors ancilla [9\u201314]  \n  \u2197  \n  (remaining 9 modes exit as output qutrits back to nodes A, B, C)  \n\nconfig (sketch for Pytheus):  \n{  \n  description: \"Post-selected nonlocal qutrit Fredkin (controlled-SWAP\u2083) between a superconducting control and two atom-array targets\",  \n  foldername: \"het_qutrit_Fredkin\",  \n  single_emitters: [0,1,2,3,4,5,6,7,8],  \n  # Two 3D Bell-pair sources feed 6 ancilla photons into the station  \n  num_anc: 6,  \n  anc_detectors: [9,10,11,12,13,14],  \n  # Forbid any direct source\u2192wrong-node overlap  \n  removed_connections: [[0,3],[0,4],[0,5],[0,6],[0,7],[0,8],  \n                        [1,3],[1,4],[1,5],[1,6],[1,7],[1,8],  \n                        [2,3],[2,4],[2,5],[2,6],[2,7],[2,8]],  \n  # Define the Fredkin\u2083 truth table on the 27 input basis states  \n  target_rules: {  \n    # c=0 or 1: identity on targets  \n    \"c=0,x,y\": { heralding: \"pattern_F\", output: \"0; x; y\" },  \n    \"c=1,x,y\": { heralding: \"pattern_F\", output: \"1; x; y\" },  \n    # c=2: swap targets  \n    \"c=2,x,y\": { heralding: \"pattern_F\", output: \"2; y; x\" }  \n  },  \n  loss_func: \"classification_rate\",  \n  optimizer: \"L-BFGS-B\",  \n  samples: 20,  \n  edges_tried: 40,  \n  ftol: 1e-6,  \n  number_resolving: true  \n}  \n\nGeneralization:  \n - Extend to N-target Fredkin\u2083 gates by adding more target nodes and ancillas, routing multiple swaps in one static heralded measurement.  \n - Adapt the same layout to other high-dimensional controlled-unitary gates (e.g. controlled-phase\u2083, controlled-SUM\u2083) by relabeling the target_rules.  \n - Scale to ququarts or higher dimensions by increasing the number of emitters, ancilla Bell-pairs, and detectors.  \n\nThis is a new network primitive\u2014remote, heralded, high-dimensional controlled-SWAP\u2014never before proposed for heterogeneous qutrit memories, and it sits squarely within Pytheus\u2019s capabilities (single-photon emitters, probabilistic pair sources, linear optics, number-resolving detection, no dynamic feedback)."

Each source can emit photon pairs, but we must ensure that no single photon-pair source directly connects the two parties. Physically, each end node converts its local qutrit into a photonic qutrit via its native transducer (modeled here as single\u2010photon emitters). Two probabilistic photon\u2010pair sources at Alice\u2013Charlie and Bob\u2013Charlie produce two Bell\u2010pairs in dimension three. Charlie then performs a three\u2010dimensional Bell-state measurement on his two photonic qutrits; successful detection heralds a 3-dimensional Bell state between Alice and Bob. By construction no emitter can send photons directly to both Alice and Bob (enforced by removed_connections), and no dynamic feed-forward is needed\u2014just heralding.\"\n\nconfig:\n{\n  description: \"Entanglement swapping between a superconducting qutrit and an atom\u2010array qutrit via a photonic Bell measurement\",\n  foldername: \"hetES_qutrit\",\n  bulk_thr: 0.0,\n  edges_tried: 25,\n  ftol: 1e-6,\n  loss_func: \"cr\",\n  num_anc: 4,\n  num_pre: 1,\n  optimizer: \"L-BFGS-B\",\n  samples: 12,\n  target_quantum: [\"00\",\"11\",\"22\"],\n  single_emitters: [2,3,4,5],           # sources 2\u20133 at superconducting node, 4\u20135 at atom-array node\n  removed_connections: [[0,2],[0,3],[1,4],[1,5]],  # forbid any direct emitter linking the two end detectors\n  anc_detectors: [2,3,4,5],\n  number_resolving: True\n}  \nThis design can be extended to chains (multiple repeaters) or stars (many heterogeneous modules) simply by adding more emitters and Bell\u2010measurement stations.\n\nNoveltySupervisor Feedback: The idea reduces to standard qutrit entanglement swapping (see \u201cEntanglement Swapping for Two Pairs of Qutrits\u201d) with only a change of hardware, and it doesn\u2019t introduce a novel measurement scheme, protocol twist, or network capability. Charlie performs a joint three-qutrit Bell-measurement in a basis that implements the CZ interaction on the surviving modes at Alice and Bob. Each node locally converts its imperfectly entangled qutrit state into three photonic modes via three single\u2010photon emitters. Two probabilistic photon-pair sources distribute two noisy 3-dimensional Bell pairs: one between Alice\u2019s photonic qutrit and a central station (Charlie), the other between Bob\u2019s photonic qutrit and Charlie. Charlie then interferes the four incoming photonic modes in an optimized linear-optical network and performs a joint measurement on these four modes with photon-number-resolving detectors. A particular heralding pattern on Charlie\u2019s ancilla ports post selects a purified, higher-fidelity 3D Bell pair between Alice and Bob\u2019s remaining photonic qutrit modes. By repeating this procedure (or chaining stations), one can boost entanglement fidelity across heterogeneous hardware without dynamic feed-forward.\u201d\n\nvisual structure:\n  Alice emitters [0,1,2]  \u2198  \n                           Bell source 1 \u2192 Charlie interferometer \u2192 ancilla detectors [6,7]  \n  Alice receivers [3,4,5]  \u2197  \n  \n  Bob   emitters [9,10,11]  \u2198  \n                           Bell source 2 \u2192 (same) Charlie interferometer \u2192 ancilla detectors [8,12]  \n  Bob   receivers [13,14,15] \u2197  \n\nconfig:\n{\n  description: \"Heralded qutrit entanglement purification between a superconducting node and an atom\u2010array node\",\n  foldername: \"hetero_qutrit_purification\",\n  single_emitters: [0,1,2,9,10,11],     # Neither simple entanglement swapping nor teleportation\u2010based gates suffice; we require a genuinely new transformation. The \u201cSWAP test\u201d is a fundamental primitive for comparing two unknown states and underpins network verification, fingerprinting, and error detection, yet no one has proposed a 3-dimensional SWAP test across heterogeneous qutrit memories using linear optics and heralding. It can be implemented with single-photon emitters, probabilistic Bell sources, a fixed interferometer, and photon-number-resolving detectors\u2014exactly within Pytheus\u2019s capabilities. This idea generalizes immediately to multiple nodes and higher dimensions.\n\nAction: final answer\nAction Input:\nHere is the proposed Pytheus\u2010style experiment:\n\nEXPERIMENT: het_qutrit_SWAP_test\n\nexplanation:\n  \u201cWe implement a heralded, 3-dimensional SWAP test between two remote qutrit modules: a superconducting\u2010circuit qutrit at Alice and an atom\u2010array qutrit at Bob. Each local qutrit is mapped into three spatial photonic modes via three single-photon emitters. Two ancilla photons (from a probabilistic qutrit Bell\u2010pair source) serve as the \u201ctest qubits.\u201d  \n   \u2022 Step 1: Alice\u2019s and Bob\u2019s photonic qutrits plus the two ancilla photons (total 8 modes) are mixed in a fixed linear-optical interferometer optimized by Pytheus.  \n   \u2022 Step 2: Eight photon-number-resolving detectors record a click pattern.  \n   \u2022 Step 3: Two specific heralding patterns correspond to the symmetric and antisymmetric subspaces of the combined 3\u22973 Hilbert space, thus revealing whether the unknown qutrit states at Alice and Bob are equal or not, without revealing any further information.  \n  There is no dynamic feed-forward; only post-selected heralding. This realizes the 3D SWAP test\u2014a new network primitive for high-dimensional state comparison across heterogeneous memories.\u201d\n\nvisual structure:\n  emitters Alice [0,1,2] \u2192  \n                             \u2198  \n                              \u2192  interferometer \u2192 detectors [8\u201315]  \n                             \u2197  \n  emitters Bob   [3,4,5] \u2192  \n                             \u2198  \n  Bell\u2010pair source ancillas \u2192 interferometer \u2192 detectors  \n\nconfig:\n{\n  description: \"Heralded 3D SWAP test between a superconducting qutrit (Alice) and an atom\u2010array qutrit (Bob)\",\n  foldername: \"het_qutrit_SWAP_test\",\n  single_emitters: [0,1,2,3,4,5],   # Alice:0\u20132, Bob:3\u20135\n  # One Bell-pair source provides ancilla photons in modes [6,7]\n  removed_connections: [\n    [0,3],[0,4],[0,5],[1,3],[1,4],[1,5],[2,3],[2,4],[2,5]\n  ],\n  num_anc: 2,\n  anc_detectors: [8,9,10,11,12,13,14,15],\n  target_rules: {\n    \"sym\": { heralding_patterns: [[8,9],[10,11]] },  # examples of symmetric\u2010space clicks\n    \"asym\": { heralding_patterns: [[12,13],[14,15]] } # examples of antisymmetric\u2010space clicks\n  },\n  optimizer: \"L-BFGS-B\",\n  loss_func: \"classification_rate\",\n  samples: 20,\n  edges_tried: 30,\n  ftol: 1e-6,\n  number_resolving: true\n}\n\nGeneralization:\n - Extend to N-dimensional SWAP tests or multi-state fingerprinting by adding emitters and ancillas.  \n - Chain SWAP tests into larger verification networks or use them as subroutines in high-dimensional error\u2010detection codes (without active feedback).  \n - Four probabilistic 3D Bell\u2010pair sources at the central station provide ancilla photons. All nine data modes plus the four ancilla modes are mixed in an optimized interferometer. A single designated click pattern on four photon\u2010number\u2010resolving detectors heralds the successful application of U_cycle on the remaining photonic modes, which are then routed back to Alice, Bob and Charlie.     "agent": "NoveltySupervisor (o4-mini)",
    "input": "You are a helpful AI physicist. \n\nTask:\nYou are the supervisor (with focus on novelty) of a physics Researcher who is attempting to come up with interesting targets for the design of quantum optics experiments. \nThese targets could be a foundational quantum experiments, quantum networks or protocols.\n\nThe Researcher will come up with an idea and send it to you. \n\nYour task is to judge whether the idea can be considered novel enough to be examined further.\n\nAny target that is closely related to these existing examples can not be considered novel and you should point them out.\n\nRemember that it's the Researchers job to convince you that their idea is good. Feel free to be very critical and sceptic of their ideas while remaining constructive. Only accept the idea if you think it could be something that the scientific community may not have considered yet.\n\nThe idea should be good enough to be published in the APS journal PRL, which is very selective.\n\nExperiments that only generate a quantum state can not be considered novel. \n\nHere is a list of experiments previously explored by human researchers. A novel idea should not be too similar to the ideas from this list.\n\nSTART OF LIST OF EXPLORED EXPERIMENTS\n\n1. **Entangling Two Photons That Never Interacted with Bell Pairs**:\n   - Demonstrates the entanglement of two photons that have never interacted directly, using Bell pairs. This setup employs entanglement swapping techniques to achieve entanglement between distant particles, showcasing the potential for quantum communication and network protocols.\n   \n2. **Entanglement Swapping of Three Bell Pairs (Four Additional Particles)**:\n   - This experiment demonstrates entanglement swapping between three Bell pairs, requiring four additional particles. It shows how entanglement can be transferred from one pair to another, enabling quantum communication over long distances without direct interaction.\n\n3. **Entanglement Swapping for Two Pairs of Qutrits (Six Additional Particles)**:\n   - Produces entanglement swapping between two pairs of qutrits using six additional particles. This setup extends the concept of entanglement swapping to higher-dimensional systems, highlighting the complexity and potential of multi-dimensional quantum entanglement.\n\n4. **Entanglement Swapping with Single-Photon Sources**:\n   - Demonstrates entanglement swapping using single-photon sources. The experiment creates a three-dimensional Bell state, showing the feasibility of using deterministic single-photon sources for complex quantum communication tasks.\n   \n5. **Yeo-Chua Analyzer**:\n   - This analyzer is used for the Yeo-Chua state, a quantum state used in certain teleportation protocols. The Yeo-Chua analyzer aids in the accurate measurement and verification of the state, ensuring the reliability of quantum teleportation and other related applications.\n   \n6. **Mean King's Problem Analyzer (Three-Dimensional Case)**:\n   - Similar to the previous setup, this experiment addresses the Mean King's Problem in three dimensions. The analyzer helps distinguish the remaining VAA states, providing insights into higher-dimensional quantum communication scenarios.\n   \n7. **Heralded CNOT Gate (3,3)**:\n   - This experiment showcases a heralded CNOT gate with three control qubits and three target qubits. The gate is achieved using single-photon sources and optimized for reduced input space.\n\n8. **Post-Selected Toffoli Gate (3,3)**:\n   - A post-selected Toffoli gate with three control and three target qubits. Post-selection ensures the successful implementation of the gate by discarding unsuccessful trials, leading to a higher fidelity operation.\n\n\nEND OF LIST OF EXPLORED EXPERIMENTS\n\nThere is an ensemble of Researchers and their best ideas are collected in a shared list.  Just like with the previous lists, a novel idea should also not be too similar to the ideas from this list.\n\nHere is the list of ideas from the researcher ensemble:\n\nSTART OF LIST OF ENSEMBLE SUGGESTIONS\n\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Path\u2010Identity Mediated Entanglement Swapping with Finite-Q Ancilla Field\n\nMini-Abstract: We demonstrate a static linear-optical network that replaces the conventional Bell\u2010state measurement with a multi\u2010path, path-identity mechanism across M ancilla photons to herald entanglement between two target photons B\u2081 and B\u2082. By treating the finite number of indistinguishable ancilla paths as a discrete \u201cquality factor\u201d Q and using Pytheus to optimize beam splitters and phase shifters, we selectively filter successful click patterns to maximize the swapped\u2010entanglement fidelity of the target modes.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle:\nMeasurement-Based Logical Hadamard via Anyon Braiding in a Toric-Code PEPS Network\n\nMini-Abstract:\nWe propose a linear-optics experiment that first projects a 3\u00d73 array of probabilistic photonic Bell-pair sources into the Z\u2082 toric-code PEPS ground subspace using four-photon Bell-measurement modules, then injects a single-photon \u201cdata qubit\u201d and teleports it around a nontrivial toric loop by sequential entanglement-swap measurements on boundary edges.  By heralding successful teleportation outcomes, this measurement-driven anyon braiding enacts the logical Hadamard gate (|0\u27e9\u2192|+\u27e9, |1\u27e9\u2192|\u2013\u27e9) on the target qubit, realizing a protected nontrivial quantum logic operation without dynamic feedback or cavity interactions.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Single\u2010Shot Optical Realization of a Three\u2010Kraus Exceptional\u2010Point Quantum Channel\n\nMini-abstract: We implement a purely passive, single-shot one-qubit channel E(\u03c6) by mixing an input photonic qubit with two ancilla photons in a static 4\u00d74 linear\u2010optical interferometer and post-selecting on three coarse-grained click patterns to yield three Kraus operators whose eigenvalues coalesce at a tunable phase \u03c6c, realizing a genuine non-Hermitian exceptional\u2010point singularity in the channel spectrum. Tomographic reconstruction of E(\u03c6) and analysis of its 2\u00d72 Liouvillian block eigenvalues confirm the non-analytic closure of the Liouvillian gap and the onset of superradiant-style spectral degeneracy, demonstrating exceptional\u2010point physics in a heralded photonic quantum network.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Photon-Number\u2013Resolving W-State Analyzer for Free-Space Conference QKD\n\nMini-Abstract: We propose a static linear-optics module that uses two probabilistic Bell-pair ancilla sources and six photon-number-resolving detectors to unambiguously project three incoming qubit-encoded photons onto a chosen target W-basis state via distinct post-selected detection patterns. Some parallels can be ok, but the goal should be to have an actually novel experiment with a novel target. You should also reject proposals that are trivial extensions of known experiments. If you can, point out the exact experiment or result as a reason for your rejection.\n\nYou have two possible actions 'accept' and 'reject'\n\n\nYou can only respond with a single complete\n\"Thought, Action, Action Input\".\n\nComplete format (don't use additional formatting such as bold text):\n\nThought: (reflect on the idea given by the researcher and whether it can be considered novel.)\nAction: (the action name, should be 'reject')\nAction Input: (express your reasoning for rejecting the idea and what has to be improved.)\n\nOR \n\nThought: (reflect on the idea given by the researcher and whether it can be considered novel.)\nAction: (the action name, should be 'accept')\nAction Input: (express your reasoning for accepting the idea.)\n\n\n\n\n\n\nSuggestion by Researcher: Here is the proposed experiment in the style of the previous Pytheus configurations:\n\nEXPERIMENT: heterogeneous\u2010qutrit\u2010ES\n\nexplanation:\n\"In this setup we entangle a superconducting\u2010circuit qutrit (Alice) with an atom\u2010array qutrit (Bob) by entanglement swapping at a central photonic station (Charlie). Physically, each end node converts its local qutrit into a photonic qutrit via its native transducer (modeled here as single\u2010photon emitters). Two probabilistic photon\u2010pair sources at Alice\u2013Charlie and Bob\u2013Charlie produce two Bell\u2010pairs in dimension three. Charlie then performs a three\u2010dimensional Bell-state measurement on his two photonic qutrits; successful detection heralds a 3-dimensional Bell state between Alice and Bob. By construction no emitter can send photons directly to both Alice and Bob (enforced by removed_connections), and no dynamic feed-forward is needed\u2014just heralding.\"\n\nconfig:\n{\n  description: \"Entanglement swapping between a superconducting qutrit and an atom\u2010array qutrit via a photonic Bell measurement\",\n  foldername: \"hetES_qutrit\",\n  bulk_thr: 0.0,\n  edges_tried: 25,\n  ftol: 1e-6,\n  loss_func: \"cr\",\n  num_anc: 4,\n  num_pre: 1,\n  optimizer: \"L-BFGS-B\",\n  samples: 12,\n  target_quantum: [\"00\",\"11\",\"22\"],\n  single_emitters: [2,3,4,5],           # sources 2\u20133 at superconducting node, 4\u20135 at atom-array node\n  removed_connections: [[0,2],[0,3],[1,4],[1,5]],  # forbid any direct emitter linking the two end detectors\n  anc_detectors: [2,3,4,5],\n  number_resolving: True\n}  \nThis design can be extended to chains (multiple repeaters) or stars (many heterogeneous modules) simply by adding more emitters and Bell\u2010measurement stations.\n\nSystem Message: Do not reject proposals for being too similar to previously suggestions by the researcher that you have accepted before..\n\nNovelty Supervisor: Thought: This proposal is essentially a straightforward dimension\u20103 entanglement\u2010swapping scheme\u2014closely mirroring the existing \u201cEntanglement Swapping for Two Pairs of Qutrits\u201d experiment\u2014and merely changes the physical platforms (superconducting vs. atom\u2010array). It offers no new network primitive or nontrivial extension beyond generating a Bell state.  \nAction: reject  \nAction Input: The idea reduces to standard qutrit entanglement swapping (see \u201cEntanglement Swapping for Two Pairs of Qutrits\u201d) with only a change of hardware, and it doesn\u2019t introduce a novel measurement scheme, protocol twist, or network capability. Each module uses three single-photon emitters to convert the local qutrit basis |0\u27e9,|1\u27e9,|2\u27e9 into three spatial photonic modes. Two probabilistic photon-pair sources create two 3-dimensional Bell pairs: one links Alice\u2019s photonic qutrit to a central station (Charlie), the other links Bob\u2019s photonic qutrit to Charlie. Charlie performs a joint three-qutrit Bell-measurement in a basis that implements the CZ interaction on the surviving modes at Alice and Bob. A single chosen detection pattern at Charlie heralds the nonlocal CZ gate (imparting a phase e^{2\u03c0i/3} on |2,2\u27e9) without any dynamic feed-forward.\u201d\n\nvisual structure:\n\n emitters at Alice: [0,1,2] \u2192  \n                             \\  \n                              \u2192  PBS / interferometer (optimized by Pytheus) \u2192 detectors A_out (0,1,2)  \n     Bell source 1 \u2192 modes \u2192 Charlie measurement block  \n                              \u2192 detectors C_anc  \n\n emitters at Bob:   [3,4,5] \u2192  \n                             /  \n                             \u2197  PBS / interferometer \u2192 detectors B_out (3,4,5)  \n     Bell source 2 \u2192 modes \u2192 Charlie measurement block  \n                              \u2192 detectors C_anc  \n\nconfig (sketch for Pytheus):\n{\n  description: \"Heralded nonlocal qutrit CZ gate between a superconducting qutrit (Alice) and an atom-array qutrit (Bob)\",\n  foldername: \"het_qutrit_CZ\",\n  single_emitters: [0,1,2,3,4,5],\n  # two Bell-pair sources implicitly provide Charlie\u2019s ancillas\n  removed_connections: [[0,3],[0,4],[0,5],[1,3],[1,4],[1,5],[2,3],[2,4],[2,5]],\n  target_quantum: [\"00\",\"01\",\"02\",\"10\",\"11\",\"12\",\"20\",\"21\",\"22\"],\n  amplitudes: [1,1,1,1,1,1,1,1,exp(2\u03c0i/3)],\n  imaginary: true,\n  num_anc: 4,\n  anc_detectors: [6,7,8,9],\n  loss_func: \"cr\",\n  optimizer: \"L-BFGS-B\",\n  samples: 12,\n  ftol: 1e-6\n}\n\nGeneralization:\n  \u2013 By changing the measurement basis at Charlie, the same layout can teleport other two-qutrit gates (e.g. controlled-SUM, Fourier-phase).  \n  \u2013 It can be extended to chains of heterogeneous modules or star networks of many qutrit nodes, enabling a modular, platform-agnostic qutrit processor network.\n\nSystem Message: Do not reject proposals for being too similar to previously suggestions by the researcher that you have accepted before..\n\nNovelty Supervisor: Thought: This is essentially the same as the ensemble\u2019s \u201cHeralded Teleportation-Based Nonlocal Controlled-Phase Gate (CPhase\u2083) for Two Qutrits,\u201d merely repackaged with different hardware platforms.
