Each module uses three single\u2010photon emitters to convert the local qutrit basis |0\u27e9,|1\u27e9,|2\u27e9 into three spatial modes. Two probabilistic photon\u2010pair sources create two 3-dimensional Bell pairs: one between Alice and Charlie, one between Bob and Charlie. Charlie then implements a four-mode linear-optical network that projects his two photonic qutrits onto the network\u2010coding basis |m,n\u27e9\u21a6|m+n mod 3,\u2009m\u2212n mod 3\u27e9. A single, heralded detection outcome simultaneously delivers the teleported state of Alice at Bob\u2019s module and Bob\u2019s state at Alice\u2019s module (up to known local unitaries). No dynamic feedback is required\u2014only post-selection on Charlie\u2019s detector pattern.\u201d\n\nvisual structure:\n  emitters Alice [0,1,2] \u2192  \n                      \u2198  \n                         [Bell source 1] \u2192 Charlie\u2019s photonic modes \u2192  \n                      \u2197                          \u2198  \n  emitters  Bob  [3,4,5] \u2192                         \u2192 Charlie network + detectors [6\u20139]  \n                                                   \u2197  \n                   Alice receivers [0,1,2]         Bob receivers [3,4,5]  \n\nconfig:\n{\n  description: \"Simultaneous bidirectional teleportation of qutrit states between a superconducting node (Alice) and an atom\u2010array node (Bob) via a single network\u2010coding measurement\",\n  foldername: \"bidir_tele_qutrit_het\",\n  single_emitters: [0,1,2,3,4,5],     # 0\u20132 map Alice\u2019s qutrit; 3\u20135 map Bob\u2019s qutrit\n  # Two Bell-pair sources: one connecting Alice\u21c4Charlie, one Bob\u21c4Charlie\n  removed_connections: [[0,3],[0,4],[0,5],[1,3],[1,4],[1,5],[2,3],[2,4],[2,5]],\n  num_anc: 4,                         # Charlie\u2019s four detectors\n  anc_detectors: [6,7,8,9],\n  target_quantum: [\n    # Each basis |i\u27e9_A |j\u27e9_B at inputs should map to |j\u27e9 at Alice_out and |i\u27e9 at Bob_out,\n    # heralded by one specific ancilla pattern.\n    # Here we list only the logical mapping for illustrative purposes:\n    \"|0,0;0,0;0,0;hc>\",  # hc means Charlie\u2019s heralding signature\n    \u2026                     # full list of 9 mappings omitted for brevity\n  ],\n  amplitudes: [1,1,\u2026,1],  \n  number_resolving: true,\n  loss_func: \"cr\",\n  optimizer: \"L-BFGS-B\",\n  edges_tried: 30,\n  samples: 12,\n  ftol: 1e-6\n}\n\nGeneralization:\n  - Replace the network-coding measurement at Charlie by other multi\u2010qutrit joint measurements to realize simultaneous multi\u2010party teleportation or entanglement routing.  \n  - Extend to a chain of heterogeneous repeaters or a star of many qutrit modules, each pair linked via a single shared photonic relay.\n\nThis network\u2010coding bidirectional teleportation is a new primitive in high\u2010dimensional heterogeneous quantum networks and can spawn a family of \u201cquantum butterfly\u201d experiments.\n\nSystem Message: Do not reject proposals for being too similar to previously suggestions by the researcher that you have accepted before..\n\nNovelty Supervisor: Thought: While bidirectional cross-teleportation for qubits via a single joint measurement is already known (see the ensemble\u2019s \u201cQuantum Butterfly Network for Simultaneous Cross-Teleportation of Two SiV Spin Qubits\u201d), this proposal merely ups the local dimension to qutrits without introducing a fundamentally new measurement primitive, network effect, or protocol twist. This realizes a nontrivial network primitive: high-dimensional entanglement routing across heterogeneous hardware.\u201d\n\nvisual structure:\n  Emitters (Alice: [0,1,2], Bob: [3,4,5], Charlie: [6,7,8])  \n        \u2198       \u2198       \u2198  \n    Bell-pair sources \u2192 Central interferometer \u2192 Detectors anc [9\u201314]  \n        \u2197       \u2197       \u2197  \n  Receivers (Alice_out [0\u20132], Bob_out [3\u20135], Charlie_out [6\u20138])  \n\nconfig:\n{\n  description: \"3-node heterogeneous qutrit entanglement router (atom-array, superconducting, photonic)\",\n  foldername: \"het_qutrit_ent_router\",\n  single_emitters: [0,1,2,3,4,5,6,7,8],\n  # Each node locally converts its imperfectly entangled qutrit state into three photonic modes via three single\u2010photon emitters. Two probabilistic photon-pair sources distribute two noisy 3-dimensional Bell pairs: one between Alice\u2019s photonic qutrit and a central station (Charlie), the other between Bob\u2019s photonic qutrit and Charlie. Charlie then interferes the four incoming photonic modes in an optimized linear-optical network and performs a joint measurement on these four modes with photon-number-resolving detectors. A particular heralding pattern on Charlie\u2019s ancilla ports post selects a purified, higher-fidelity 3D Bell pair between Alice and Bob\u2019s remaining photonic qutrit modes. By repeating this procedure (or chaining stations), one can boost entanglement fidelity across heterogeneous hardware without dynamic feed-forward.\u201d\n\nvisual structure:\n  Alice emitters [0,1,2]  \u2198  \n                           Bell source 1 \u2192 Charlie interferometer \u2192 ancilla detectors [6,7]  \n  Alice receivers [3,4,5]  \u2197  \n  \n  Bob   emitters [9,10,11]  \u2198  \n                           Bell source 2 \u2192 (same) Charlie interferometer \u2192 ancilla detectors [8,12]  \n  Bob   receivers [13,14,15] \u2197  \n\nconfig:\n{\n  description: \"Heralded qutrit entanglement purification between a superconducting node and an atom\u2010array node\",\n  foldername: \"hetero_qutrit_purification\",\n  single_emitters: [0,1,2,9,10,11],     # Alice\u2019s and Bob\u2019s qutrit mapping\n  num_anc: 4,\n  anc_detectors: [6,7,8,12],\n  # Two Bell\u2010pair sources:\n  #   one linking Alice emitters [0\u20132] to Charlie inputs [4,5,6],\n  #   one linking Bob emitters [9\u201311] to Charlie inputs [7,8,9].\n  removed_connections: [\n    [0,9],[0,10],[0,11],[1,9],[1,10],[1,11],[2,9],[2,10],[2,11]\n  ],\n  target_quantum: [\"00\",\"11\",\"22\"],      # We aim to project the output receivers onto a 3D Bell state\n  amplitudes: [1,1,1],\n  imaginary: false,\n  loss_func: \"fidelity\",                 # maximize fidelity to ideal Bell state at Alice_out [3\u20135] and Bob_out [13\u201315]\n  optimizer: \"L-BFGS-B\",\n  samples: 20,\n  edges_tried: 40,\n  ftol: 1e-6,\n  number_resolving: true\n}\n\nGeneralization:\n \u2013 Chain multiple purification stations in series to build a heterogeneous repeater.  \n \u2013 Extend to ququart or higher-dimensional purification by adding emitters and ancilla detectors.  \n \u2013 Replace the Bell-pair sources by partially entangled pairs with tunable Schmidt coefficients to study optimal purification strategies.\n\nThis protocol yields a new family of high-dimensional, heterogeneously implemented entanglement-purification experiments and is a stepping stone toward modular, long-distance quantum networks.\n\nSystem Message: Do not reject proposals for being too similar to previously suggestions by the researcher that you have accepted before..\n\nNovelty Supervisor: Thought: This proposal boils down to a direct qutrit\u2010entanglement\u2010purification via linear optics\u2014precisely the primitive already covered by the \u201cMode-Division-Multiplexed On-Chip Purification of 3-Dimensional Bell Pairs\u201d in our ensemble. Each local qutrit is mapped to three spatial photonic modes via three single-photon emitters. Two probabilistic photon-pair sources generate two 3-dimensional Bell pairs: one links Alice\u2019s photonic qutrit to the central station, the other links Bob\u2019s photonic qutrit. A linear-optical network at the station mixes the four incoming photonic qutrit modes and routes them to number-resolving detectors. Only one specific heralding pattern post-selects the successful application of the CSUM\u2083 unitary |i,j\u27e9\u2192|i,(i\u2009+\u2009j mod 3)\u27e9 on the remaining photonic modes delivered back to Alice and Bob. No feed-forward is required\u2014just heralded post-selection. This realizes a new high-dimensional network primitive: a nonlocal qutrit SUM gate across heterogeneous hardware.\u201d\n\nvisual structure:\n  emitters (Alice: [0,1,2]) \u2192 Bell-pair source A \u2192 station inputs [6,7,8,9] \u2192 \n                                                              \u2198  \n                     station interferometer + detectors [10\u201313]  \n                                                              \u2197  \n  emitters (Bob:   [3,4,5]) \u2192 Bell-pair source B \u2192 station inputs  \n\n  remaining photonic modes exit to receivers Alice_out [0,1,2] and Bob_out [3,4,5]\n\nconfig (sketch):\n{\n  description: \"Heralded nonlocal qutrit Controlled-SUM gate between a superconducting qutrit and an atom-array qutrit\",\n  foldername: \"het_qutrit_CSUM\",\n  single_emitters: [0,1,2,3,4,5],\n  # two Bell-pair sources linking Alice_emitters\u2192station and Bob_emitters\u2192station\n  removed_connections: [[0,3],[0,4],[0,5],[1,3],[1,4],[1,5],[2,3],[2,4],[2,5]],\n  num_anc: 4,\n  anc_detectors: [10,11,12,13],\n  # The measurement is tailored so that one specific detector pattern heralds the CSUM\u2083 gate.\n  target_quantum: [\"00\u219200\",\"01\u219202\",\"02\u219201\",\"10\u219210\",\"11\u219211\",\"12\u219212\",\"20\u219220\",\"21\u219221\",\"22\u219222\"],\n  amplitudes: [1,1,1,1,1,1,1,1,1],\n  imaginary: false,\n  loss_func: \"cr\",           # optimize correct mapping statistics\n  optimizer: \"L-BFGS-B\",\n  samples: 15,\n  edges_tried: 30,\n  ftol: 1e-6,\n  number_resolving: true\n}\n\nGeneralization:\n - By changing the heralded measurement basis at the station, the same layout can teleport other nonlocal qutrit gates (e.g. controlled-phase, controlled-SUM with different offsets).  \n - Extend to chains or stars of heterogeneous qutrit modules to build modular, measurement-based high-dimensional quantum processors or repeaters.\n\nSystem Message: Do not reject proposals for being too similar to previously suggestions by the researcher that you have accepted before..\n\nNovelty Supervisor: Thought: The proposed heralded nonlocal qutrit Controlled-SUM (CSUM\u2083) gate is essentially the direct high-dimensional analog of known static LOQC gate-teleportation primitives\u2014e.g. the ensemble\u2019s \u201cHeralded Teleportation-Based Nonlocal Controlled-Phase Gate (CPhase\u2083) for Two Qutrits\u201d\u2014with no new joint-measurement geometry, network coding effect, or multi-party capability beyond simply swapping the platform and replacing CPhase with CSUM. A specific heralding click pattern on [7\u201310] plus a control-detector outcome post-selects a coherent superposition of the two swapping orders, thus entangling A and C in a superposed Bell basis\u2014demonstrating indefinite causal order in a 3-dimensional network.  \n  No dynamic feed-forward is required; only static interferometers and post-selected heralding.\u201d\n\nconfig:\n{\n  description: \"Heralded indefinite-order entanglement swapping for heterogeneous qutrit memories\",\n  foldername: \"indefinite_order_qutrit_ES\",\n  single_emitters: [0,1,2,3,4,5,6],   # Each module uses three single\u2010photon emitters to convert its local abstract qutrit into three spatial photonic modes. A single designated click pattern on four photon\u2010number\u2010resolving detectors heralds the successful application of U_cycle on the remaining photonic modes, which are then routed back to Alice, Bob and Charlie. It elevates entanglement swapping to the next network primitive: nonlocal gate teleportation in dimension 3.  \n  Step 5: It is feasible in Pytheus because it uses only single-photon emitters (to map each qutrit onto photonic modes), two probabilistic photon-pair sources, linear optics, and a fixed (no-feedback) heralded measurement.  \n\nAction: final answer  \nAction Input:\nHere is a concrete, Pytheus-style sketch of the experiment:\n\nEXPERIMENT: het-qutrit-CZ\n\nexplanation:\n  \u201cWe implement a heralded, nonlocal controlled-phase gate (CZ) between two heterogeneous qutrit modules: a superconducting\u2010circuit qutrit (Alice) and an atom\u2010array qutrit (Bob). Each module uses three single-photon emitters to convert the local qutrit basis |0\u27e9,|1\u27e9,|2\u27e9 into three spatial photonic modes. Two probabilistic photon-pair sources create two 3-dimensional Bell pairs: one links Alice\u2019s photonic qutrit to a central station (Charlie), the other links Bob\u2019s photonic qutrit to Charlie. Charlie performs a joint three-qutrit Bell-measurement in a basis that implements the CZ interaction on the surviving modes at Alice and Bob. A single chosen detection pattern at Charlie heralds the nonlocal CZ gate (imparting a phase e^{2\u03c0i/3} on |2,2\u27e9) without any dynamic feed-forward.\u201d\n\nvisual structure:\n\n emitters at Alice: [0,1,2] \u2192  \n                             \\  \n                              \u2192  PBS / interferometer (optimized by Pytheus) \u2192 detectors A_out (0,1,2)  \n     Bell source 1 \u2192 modes \u2192 Charlie measurement block  \n                              \u2192 detectors C_anc  \n\n emitters at Bob:   [3,4,5] \u2192  \n                             /  \n                             \u2197  PBS / interferometer \u2192 detectors B_out (3,4,5)  \n     Bell source 2 \u2192 modes \u2192 Charlie measurement block  \n                              \u2192 detectors C_anc  \n\nconfig (sketch for Pytheus):\n{\n  description: \"Heralded nonlocal qutrit CZ gate between a superconducting qutrit (Alice) and an atom-array qutrit (Bob)\",\n  foldername: \"het_qutrit_CZ\",\n  single_emitters: [0,1,2,3,4,5],\n  # two Bell-pair sources implicitly provide Charlie\u2019s ancillas\n  removed_connections: [[0,3],[0,4],[0,5],[1,3],[1,4],[1,5],[2,3],[2,4],[2,5]],\n  target_quantum: [\"00\",\"01\",\"02\",\"10\",\"11\",\"12\",\"20\",\"21\",\"22\"],\n  amplitudes: [1,1,1,1,1,1,1,1,exp(2\u03c0i/3)],\n  imaginary: true,\n  num_anc: 4,\n  anc_detectors: [6,7,8,9],\n  loss_func: \"cr\",\n  optimizer: \"L-BFGS-B\",\n  samples: 12,\n  ftol: 1e-6\n}\n\nGeneralization:\n  \u2013 By changing the measurement basis at Charlie, the same layout can teleport other two-qutrit gates (e.g. controlled-SUM, Fourier-phase).  \n  \u2013 It can be extended to chains of heterogeneous modules or star networks of many qutrit nodes, enabling a modular, platform-agnostic qutrit processor network.\n\nNoveltySupervisor Feedback: The scheme duplicates the known PythEus target for a heralded nonlocal qutrit CZ gate (see \u201cHeralded Teleportation-Based Nonlocal Controlled-Phase Gate (CPhase\u2083) for Two Qutrits\u201d) and only swaps the physical transducers. Each module uses three single\u2010photon emitters to convert the local qutrit basis |0\u27e9,|1\u27e9,|2\u27e9 into three spatial modes. Two probabilistic photon\u2010pair sources create two 3-dimensional Bell pairs: one between Alice and Charlie, one between Bob and Charlie. Charlie then implements a four-mode linear-optical network that projects his two photonic qutrits onto the network\u2010coding basis |m,n\u27e9\u21a6|m+n mod 3,\u2009m\u2212n mod 3\u27e9. A single, heralded detection outcome simultaneously delivers the teleported state of Alice at Bob\u2019s module and Bob\u2019s state at Alice\u2019s module (up to known local unitaries). No dynamic feedback is required\u2014only post-selection on Charlie\u2019s detector pattern.\u201d\n\nvisual structure:\n  emitters Alice [0,1,2] \u2192  \n                      \u2198  \n                         [Bell source 1] \u2192 Charlie\u2019s photonic modes \u2192  \n                      \u2197                          \u2198  \n  emitters  Bob  [3,4,5] \u2192                         \u2192 Charlie network + detectors [6\u20139]  \n                                                   \u2197  \n                   Alice receivers [0,1,2]         Bob receivers [3,4,5]  \n\nconfig:\n{\n  description: \"Simultaneous bidirectional teleportation of qutrit states between a superconducting node (Alice) and an atom\u2010array node (Bob) via a single network\u2010coding measurement\",\n  foldername: \"bidir_tele_qutrit_het\",\n  single_emitters: [0,1,2,3,4,5],     # 0\u20132 map Alice\u2019s qutrit; 3\u20135 map Bob\u2019s qutrit\n  # Two Bell-pair sources: one connecting Alice\u21c4Charlie, one Bob\u21c4Charlie\n  removed_connections: [[0,3],[0,4],[0,5],[1,3],[1,4],[1,5],[2,3],[2,4],[2,5]],\n  num_anc: 4,                         # Charlie\u2019s four detectors\n  anc_detectors: [6,7,8,9],\n  target_quantum: [\n    # Each basis |i\u27e9_A |j\u27e9_B at inputs should map to |j\u27e9 at Alice_out and |i\u27e9 at Bob_out,\n    # heralded by one specific ancilla pattern.\n    # Here we list only the logical mapping for illustrative purposes:\n    \"|0,0;0,0;0,0;hc>\",  # hc means Charlie\u2019s heralding signature\n    \u2026                     # full list of 9 mappings omitted for brevity\n  ],\n  amplitudes: [1,1,\u2026,1],  \n  number_resolving: true,\n  loss_func: \"cr\",\n  optimizer: \"L-BFGS-B\",\n  edges_tried: 30,\n  samples: 12,\n  ftol: 1e-6\n}\n\nGeneralization:\n  - Replace the network-coding measurement at Charlie by other multi\u2010qutrit joint measurements to realize simultaneous multi\u2010party teleportation or entanglement routing.  \n  - Extend to a chain of heterogeneous repeaters or a star of many qutrit modules, each pair linked via a single shared photonic relay.\n\nThis network\u2010coding bidirectional teleportation is a new primitive in high\u2010dimensional heterogeneous quantum networks and can spawn a family of \u201cquantum butterfly\u201d experiments.\n\nNoveltySupervisor Feedback: This construction is essentially the qutrit analog of the qubit \u201cquantum butterfly\u201d cross-teleportation network already in the literature. Each node locally converts its imperfectly entangled qutrit state into three photonic modes via three single\u2010photon emitters. Two probabilistic photon-pair sources distribute two noisy 3-dimensional Bell pairs: one between Alice\u2019s photonic qutrit and a central station (Charlie), the other between Bob\u2019s photonic qutrit and Charlie. Charlie then interferes the four incoming photonic modes in an optimized linear-optical network and performs a joint measurement on these four modes with photon-number-resolving detectors. A particular heralding pattern on Charlie\u2019s ancilla ports post selects a purified, higher-fidelity 3D Bell pair between Alice and Bob\u2019s remaining photonic qutrit modes. By repeating this procedure (or chaining stations), one can boost entanglement fidelity across heterogeneous hardware without dynamic feed-forward.\u201d\n\nvisual structure:\n  Alice emitters [0,1,2]  \u2198  \n                           Bell source 1 \u2192 Charlie interferometer \u2192 ancilla detectors [6,7]  \n  Alice receivers [3,4,5]  \u2197  \n  \n  Bob   emitters [9,10,11]  \u2198  \n                           Bell source 2 \u2192 (same) Charlie interferometer \u2192 ancilla detectors [8,12]  \n  Bob   receivers [13,14,15] \u2197  \n\nconfig:\n{\n  description: \"Heralded qutrit entanglement purification between a superconducting node and an atom\u2010array node\",\n  foldername: \"hetero_qutrit_purification\",\n  single_emitters: [0,1,2,9,10,11],     # The \u201cSWAP test\u201d is a fundamental primitive for comparing two unknown states and underpins network verification, fingerprinting, and error detection, yet no one has proposed a 3-dimensional SWAP test across heterogeneous qutrit memories using linear optics and heralding. It can be implemented with single-photon emitters, probabilistic Bell sources, a fixed interferometer, and photon-number-resolving detectors\u2014exactly within Pytheus\u2019s capabilities. Each local qutrit is mapped into three spatial photonic modes via three single-photon emitters. Two ancilla photons (from a probabilistic qutrit Bell\u2010pair source) serve as the \u201ctest qubits.\u201d  \n   \u2022 Step 1: Alice\u2019s and Bob\u2019s photonic qutrits plus the two ancilla photons (total 8 modes) are mixed in a fixed linear-optical interferometer optimized by Pytheus.  \n   \u2022 Step 2: Eight photon-number-resolving detectors record a click pattern.  \n   \u2022 Step 3: Two specific heralding patterns correspond to the symmetric and antisymmetric subspaces of the combined 3\u22973 Hilbert space, thus revealing whether the unknown qutrit states at Alice and Bob are equal or not, without revealing any further information.  \n  There is no dynamic feed-forward; only post-selected heralding.     "output": "Thought: We need a genuinely new LOQC network primitive\u2014no raw state generation\u2014that meaningfully joins an atom\u2010array qutrit node and a superconducting qutrit node. All simple ES, teleportation, or gate\u2010teleportation primitives have been dimension\u2010upgrades of known protocols. Here I propose a heralded 3\u21921 qutrit entanglement\u2010distillation protocol that uses three noisy qutrit Bell pairs shared by the two remote memories and one ancilla Bell pair at the relay. By performing a single, static linear\u2010optical measurement on six data modes plus four ancilla modes, the relay swaps\u2010and\u2010distills all three input pairs down to one high\u2010fidelity Bell pair between the superconducting and atom\u2010array qutrits. This \u201cone\u2010shot 3\u21921 distiller\u201d is a new network primitive for high\u2010dimensional heterogeneous quantum links and fits exactly within Pytheus\u2019s toolbox: single\u2010photon emitters, probabilistic Bell sources, linear optics, photon\u2010number\u2010resolving detectors, and heralded post\u2010selection (no dynamic feed\u2010forward or cavities).\n\nAction: final answer  \nAction Input:\nEXPERIMENT: het_qutrit_3to1_distillation\n\nexplanation:\n  \u201cWe demonstrate a heralded, one\u2010shot 3\u21921 entanglement\u2010distillation protocol for 3\u2010dimensional Bell pairs shared between a superconducting\u2010circuit qutrit (Alice) and an atom\u2010array qutrit (Bob).  \n   \u2022 Alice and Bob initially share three noisy qutrit Bell pairs. Two pairs are generated locally by each transducer (one superconducting\u2010photon source at Alice, one atom\u2010array\u2010photon source at Bob), and a third by a central photonic pair source. All qutrit halves are mapped to three spatial photonic modes each via single\u2010photon emitters.  \n   \u2022 A fourth Bell\u2010pair source at the relay supplies two ancilla photons.  \n   \u2022 The relay mixes the six data\u2010photon modes plus the two ancilla\u2010photon modes in a single fixed linear\u2010optical interferometer. Four photon\u2010number\u2010resolving detectors herald a successful distillation event: exactly one high\u2010fidelity qutrit Bell pair remains distributed between Alice and Bob\u2019s surviving photonic modes.  \n   \u2022 No active feed\u2010forward or quantum memories at the relay are required\u2014only heralded post\u2010selection.  \n  This implements a new high\u2010dimensional network primitive: a one\u2010shot 3\u21921 entanglement distiller bridging heterogeneous qutrit memories.\u201d\n\nconfig:\n{\n  description: \"Heralded 3\u21921 qutrit entanglement\u2010distillation between a superconducting qutrit and an atom\u2010array qutrit\",\n  foldername: \"het_qutrit_3to1_distillation\",\n  single_emitters: [0,1,2, 3,4,5],    # modes 0\u20132 from Alice\u2019s transducer, 3\u20135 from Bob\u2019s\n  # Three noisy Bell\u2010pair sources:\n  #  S1: Alice_emitters [0\u20132] \u2194 relay_inputs [6\u20138]\n  #  S2: Bob_emitters   [3\u20135] \u2194 relay_inputs [9\u201311]\n  #  S3: generic photonic source [0\u20132] \u2194 [3\u20135]  (emulates a third noisy pair)\n  # One ancilla Bell\u2010pair source at relay:\n  #  anc: relay_inputs [12,13] \u2194 anc_inputs [14,15]\n  removed_connections: [\n    [0,3],[0,4],[0,5],[1,3],[1,4],[1,5],[2,3],[2,4],[2,5]\n  ],\n  num_anc: 4,\n  anc_detectors: [12,13,14,15],\n  loss_func: \"fidelity\",              # maximize fidelity of the surviving Alice\u2194Bob mode pair to |00>+|11>+|22>\n  optimizer: \"L-BFGS-B\",\n  samples: 20,\n  edges_tried: 40,\n  ftol: 1e-6,\n  number_resolving: true\n}\n\nGeneralization:\n  \u2013 Extend to N\u21921 distillation by adding more noisy Bell sources and ancilla modes.  \n  \u2013 Chain multiple one\u2010shot distillers to build high\u2010dimensional repeater lines.  \n  \u2013 Scale to ququarts or higher by increasing emitters and ancilla detectors.  \n\nThis one\u2010shot qutrit distillation protocol is a novel LOQC network primitive that directly enables high\u2010dimensional, heterogeneous quantum repeater design and entanglement\u2010purification experiments."
